Praefatio.	Prefatory.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have finished with you, my Son, this book which is the most recent of my works in medicine, completed with the addition of the present treatise, and following the exposition of its parts and the statements of its author, I have deemed it fitting to present to you this work which is a part of the art of surgery, namely surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgery with the hand is a matter of great importance in our times and in our age, and since it is a subject which has been neglected for a long time: except for a few scattered descriptions in the ancient books, which have been altered by the hand itself: there has arisen a great error and hesitation, until the intentions of the art have been closed and its science prolonged. It seemed good to me to restore life to this art with the help of the ordination of this treatise according to its position, declaration and abbreviation: and to bring together the forms of the instruments of cautery and other implements of the art, with the addition of their declaration and the improvement of their preparation which is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why one does not easily find a good surgeon of his hand in our time is that the art of medicine is long, and the author must exercise himself beforehand in the science of anatomy as Galen has narrated, until he knows the movements of the limbs, their forms, and their connection, and separation, and has knowledge of the bones, nerves, lacerations, and the number of each, and their exit, and the pulse of the veins, and quietness, and the locations of their exits
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for this reason Hippocrates said, "A name is nothing in itself, but in its work it is much.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have indeed mentioned this in the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For he who is ignorant of the science of anatomy will fall into error, and will endanger human life. As for me, I have seen many who have puffed up with pride about this science without any knowledge or experience
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	Why did the doctor order the securing of the swelling in the woman's neck with a scrofula, since it involved the incisions of some arteries in the neck? Because of this, blood flowed from the woman until she died between her hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And the other physician thought that he should remove a stone which was in the urine, which was causing her pain, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	Therefore he came to him and extracted it with the bladder stone
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Because the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And indeed I was called to extract it: and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the patient that he would die
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And another physician saw that a certain Duke of our land had taken a medicine: and it happened to the black eunuch who was with him that he fractured his leg near the ankle: and the physician, with his ignorance, bound the fracture with nails and pins, and did not allow the wound to drain.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	And he died according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Then he dismissed him after a few days and commanded him not to move the ligament: and he stood thus until the swelling of his leg was gone, and his foot and leg together, and he came to his end
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was called to him again: and I set about resolving the ligament: and there was peace, and he was freed from his pains
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	But indeed the corruption was confirmed in the limb: and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore the corruption ceased to advance in the limb until it died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And another physician saw that he perforated a cancerous swelling: and it ulcerated after a few days, until the malignancy of the disease increased with the master himself
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	When the cancer is pure and arises from melancholic humour, it must not be held together with iron throughout, except in the member which can tolerate it, in order that the whole of it may be excised.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for this reason, my son, you must know that an operation is divided into two parts: namely, the operation which is associated with health, and the operation which carries the risk in various conditions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	I am excited about all the places in this book where the operation is mentioned which carries terror and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore you must be careful about this, and fear it: so that they do not find pride in speaking falsely, and be dishonest
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Receive therefore measure with humility and protection, and the sick with ease and firmness, and use the better way that brings glory to God for the healing and praiseworthy succession: and send away the terrifying diseases that are difficult to cure: and take away the spirits of those who make you fear, so that there should appear no hesitation in your faith and comfort for you
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For in this way remains the measure of your glory, and the sublimation in this world, and afterwards to the quantity of your souls
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen has said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	You do not heal a bad disease: do not call a bad doctor by name
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have however divided this treatise into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	First chapter.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Of cautery with fire, and cautery with acute medicine, a chapter, and arranged from the head to the feet, and forms of instruments, and materials for cautery: and everything that is necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Second Chapter.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On section and perforation, phlebotomy and packing, wounds: and the extraction of arrows, and things of that sort: and the whole chapter, arranged in the form of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Third Chapter.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration, and dislocation, and the treatment of twisting, and things of that sort: the whole chapter, arranged from the head to the feet, and the form of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory be to God.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the application of a dressing, and the use of the cautery: and on what complexion it is suitable, and when: and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter I
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before anything else that we remember of an operation, it is necessary to say what is the quality of the dressings and instruments: and in what complexion it should be shown
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that the discourse concerning the quality of the cautery dressing and instrument is a profound, subtle, scientific, and occult discourse.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	And it has been spoken by many learned men in this matter, and they have disagreed among themselves: and indeed little is sufficient from their discourses, fearing the prolongation of the discourse.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore, that the cautery is universal in all complexion, which is with matter and without matter: except for two complexions, which are the hot complexion without matter, and the dry complexion without matter
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	In the hot and dry complexion with matter they disagree among themselves.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some indeed say that the cautery is useful in these.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	Others have also said that Cauterium is not suitable for an ailment caused by heat and dryness, because the nature of fire is heat: and it is inappropriate to cure a heat and dry ailment with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	Others have also said that Cauterium causes injury in all heat and dry ailments which occur in the bodies of men: for when you compare the body of a man with fire, and moisten it, you find the body of a man to be cold
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	I too have heard from experience that this is the case.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	It is true that one must not proceed without first having learned, practiced in the last exercise of the Cauterium chapter, recognized the diversity of human complexions, and become acquainted with the causes and effects of ailments, and their times
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	The rest, however, of complexions is not dangerous: especially in cold and wet ailments.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	I myself have seen all physicians agree about this: and they do not refrain from using Cauterium in these ailments.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And behold, the sons have said: The secret of treatment by Cauterium with fire is better than the secret of treatment with burning medicine: for fire is simple, whose action does not remain except on the member which is cauterized: and it does not harm any other connected member except for a slight burn.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	Burning medicine, however, has an action that extends beyond the member which is being cauterized: and perhaps causes difficulty in the healing of the ailment in the member itself, and perhaps brings about death.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, on account of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not do this, except in excess.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	I am now convinced by experience, through the length of my service and study with art, and the position over truth of things: and because of this, I am excused from the length of the oration.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if this is not sufficient, since it is not permitted for this book of mine, I will declare a secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in the bodies expelled by it, which expels diseases with philosophical demonstration, agreeable to the thoughts of the wise.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know ye, my sons, that they themselves dissent in the time when it becomes necessary to make the cautery, and they advise me to make a better time of your work.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	I say that the cautery is suitable for all times: for indeed the document grows dull through the passage of time, which is attracted by the cautery.</start_of_turn>
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And above all, if the cautery is for necessary and severe pains, which are urgent, which do not tolerate delay: for indeed they fear from the fire that arises from the evil which increases more than the slight dullness which the document suffers through the passage of time.</start_of_turn>
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let it not be thought by anyone, my sons, or any doctor, that because of this I do not esteem the learned and skilled physicians, for indeed the sickness which is cured by the cautery is not always the same: and they put this in consequence, and it is not so as they think: for the cautery is not, except in the place of medicine, which alters the complexion and dries up humours which are the causes of the disease.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	But indeed the cautery surpasses medicine by the swiftness of its action, the excellence of its operation, and the extent of its mastery: and it is possible that the disease will vanish at some later time according to the complexion of the patient, the location of the disease, and the excellence of the treatment: and that which is prepared in his body from the collection of superfluous humours in him: and that which proceeds from the disease itself in its acquisition from foods and like things, except in the case of those diseases in which the cautery is administered.</start_of_turn
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Acute pain in a limb with few superficial wounds, and moisture, like a tooth cautery due to pain, is possible, lest it return in that place with pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this is done in few cases.</start_of_turn>
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	Indeed, the word often returns, for the cautery is the most recent of medicine. It is the right word: not for what they wish for it, for they believe that there is no cure that can be compared with medicine, neither with anything after the cautery.</start_of_turn>
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	The thing, however, is contrary to that. For the intention of the cautery being the most recent of medicine is not, except when we employ other modes of treatment in some ailment, and these do not confer that healing: we then apply the cautery at the end of everything, and that does confer. From that time forward, because the cautery is the most recent of medicine, not according to the intention which the vulgar people and many learned physicians understand.</start_of_turn>
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that the cautery with gold is better than with iron: and they did not say that except because of the equality of the gold and the fineness of its substance. And they said that it does not form pus at the place of the cautery.</start_of_turn>
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But this is not absolutely true. For I have seen that it does not cause this in some bodies without other things.</start_of_turn>
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cautery with the instrument itself is good, and better than with iron, as they said.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	But when you apply the cautery with fire from gold, you must not declare that it has been kindled according to the quantity you wish, because of the redness of the gold: and when it approaches the cold and you add to it the fire from below, it liquefies in the fire, and turns into plates.</start_of_turn
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Why does the artificer depart from this work in pursuit of his business? And because of this, Cauterium is made with iron among us more rapid and proximate to the operation, from rectitude to the work.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	I also command this chapter on Cauterium to be read, following the chapters: and I command these things from the head to the feet: so that they may satisfy anyone who seeks anything from this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	In the manner of cauterizing the head in the coronal suture
Caput II.	Chapter 2: On the cauterization of the head in the coronal suture
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here is cauterization is made to the lord of humidity and cold over the brain: which are two causes of sweat, and the multitude of flow of humors from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and the multitude of sleep, and toothache, and throat pain: and in general all ailments which arise from cold, such as paralysis, and sweat, and seizures, and apoplexy, and things similar to these from ailments.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is as follows: when the patient is most feverish: when he is evacuated at first with a physician who gives a medicinal salve to the head for three nights, or four, according to the nature of the patient, his age, and his habits.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then command him to make a mark on his head with a needle.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands square, so that you can put your hands on his chest
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger reaches, that is the place to make the burn with the cautery
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then ignite Cauterium with olive oil: thus is its form
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it upon the marked place with an incision, and let it descend gradually, so that your hand may withdraw it slowly.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then draw out your hand quickly and look at the place
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see any amount of bone or herb remaining, then draw out your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat drawing out your hand with the instrument, or with another one if it is cold: until you see the bones, as I have said to you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and drink from it, and put it upon the place: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then put upon it butter soaked in oil, and leave the bandage above the place until the eschar is consumed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents of four herbs, until it is healed
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	I have said that the more the wound remains open, the more pus it emits: which is better and more advantageous
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some people say that the skin should be cauterized until the bone is reached: and hold the Cauterium until something of the thickness of an os is burnt.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then withdraw after that which has been burned from the bone, and then care for it
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And some say that it is necessary that the Cauterium should remain until the very end, until it has left an imprint in the bone like a mark of the alphabet, so that the bone is fractured: or that a woman should put an instrument infused with a small letter into the wound: and they say that it should be withdrawn when the vapor of the head escapes from this place for a long time
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then he cares until consolidated.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	Neither of two kinds of cautery is used in all men, except in some in whom it is feared according to their temperaments.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And dismiss it; it is better with me for the health of the patient
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head weakens from the continuity of its natural solution: as we have witnessed in the rest of the limbs: and especially when the head of the patient is weak by nature: for the first kind of cautery is more safe and better with me, and this is what is useful: to work with it for the health of the patient.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	In the manner of cauterizing the head in the pain of the whole head.
Caput III.	Head Chapter III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When in the whole head there occurs a chronic pain that lasts in the patient, and it is accompanied by fever, and swelling, and blisters, and oils, and other things are used for it
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized once with the cautery which we mentioned, and nothing more is added to it: then consider it
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the patient is strong in creation by nature, and is not weak, and if there is inflammation: then cauterize with another cautery under that little bit
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over all the hairs of the head with the cautery, so that it does not penetrate the skin, and uncover only the quantity of bone that we have mentioned
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it once with the cautery in the nape of the neck of the head, in the place which is called the uas: and this is the place where the marrow is placed: and raise the mat of hair in this, and do not uncover the bone
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	The sick man finds it on account of that pain which he suffers, and diverse from the rest of the pains of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I say that this Cauterium is in its place: and it is necessary that it be Cauterium, with which the horns of the head and its occiput are cauterized, and the middle part of the head is cauterized more finely
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	As for the method of cauterization in hemicrania, both with drugs and with the instrument.
Caput IIII.	Chapter III
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When it happens in the part of the head that there is pain and heat, or that the pain extends to the eye, and it is evacuated with medicines that soothe the head, and the rest of the treatment is administered as I have said in the discussion of diseases, and it does not suffice for it: then cauterization is done in two ways: either with acute burning medicine or with an iron.</start_of_turn>
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	But as for cauterization with acute burning medicine, that is, that you take a tooth of the other side and burn the surface of the cauterization, and cut off its extremities from both sides.</start_of_turn
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut off the place of pain in time with a wide vein cut, until there is in that place under the skin, where the tooth is caught.</start_of_turn
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Introduce it into that place under the skin, until it is hidden: then bind up above it with a bandage of constriction, and leave it for fifteen hours, then take it out, and wash away the pus. Afterwards put over it a soaked cushion in butter, until the place has healed. Then care for it with ointment until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if anyone wishes to do this with some of the physicians who burn [medicines], as I wrote in the twelfth tractate, on Physicians who endure.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Burning with iron is indeed done in this way.</start_of_turn>
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The iron is ignited in this fashion.</start_of_turn>
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called Clavius: because its shape is like the head of a key, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle of it there is a small protrusion.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it over the place and hold your hand: and gradually withdraw the iron with speed: and let the quantity which endures from the thickness of the skin be as much as half of it.</start_of_turn
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand, so that the artery beneath does not burn, and blood flow does not occur.</start_of_turn
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak the wound in salt water, and place over the place, and leave it for three days: then place the wound with butter: afterwards care with ointment until it has healed.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if necessary, burn this hemibranium with the second extremity of the knife of Cautery.</start_of_turn
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	Burn from the incision of the artery in this half-brain, not in the old way.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	In the old way of cautery in the half-brain.</start_of_turn
Caput V.	The head of V.</start_of_turn
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you have cured the half-brain, when that which we said concerning the treatment of ailments has been done, and when we have said concerning the precautions for diseases, and it does not suffice: and if you see from the disease that it does not suffice with the first cautery with medicine, or with the cautery with fire, then you must burn the Cautery knife until the sign of relief appears on the place of pain with a line whose length is half of a digit, or like this: and put your hand away quickly once, and tighten it until you have cut the artery, and keep it until the bone.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	It is necessary to restrain you, so that you do not cause the continuation of the jaw, which moves during mastication, lest it become swollen or the nerve which moves it be damaged, from which results spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	Take also great care of the guarding of the artery which has been cut off, and of the flow of blood from it.</start_of_turn>
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	In the cutting of it there is fear, especially for the one who is ignorant of this and is careless and unlearned: he lets the operation go from his hands at the first.</start_of_turn>
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I shall come with the reminder of the regimen of the flow of blood in the event of an accident from the artery, as it is in this book of mine.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you help from the inflammation which is not sufficient for this Cauterium, and if you help the body of the sick man to tolerate Cauterium in the middle of the head, as we have said, take care of the wound, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer Cauterium, as we said in the chapter on the extraction of the artery with Cauterium having two blades.</start_of_turn
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For it is a better cautery which leaves no mark.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the manner of cauterizing in the pain of the ears.</start_of_turn
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When it happens in the ear a pain from the cold, and it is cured with solutions, and the rest of the cure as we have said in the treatise, and the pain is not removed, then ignite Cauterium: and that is called Punctum, which has this shape.</start_of_turn
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then point with it after its ignition around the whole ear, as it is turned: or around both sides, if the pain is in both.</start_of_turn
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And prolong thee with the Cauterium from the root of the ear downwards, after you have marked the place with the Cautery: and let the quantity of the Cauterium be ten points in every ear, and as much as that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	And then care for the place until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	In this way Cauterize in the Tortura.</start_of_turn>
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.</start_of_turn>
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The Torment which is cured by Cauterization is not except from the kinds which happen from phlegmas, as we said in the discourse of the causes of diseases.</start_of_turn
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And you must Cauterize the kind which happens from exication and spasm of the nerve.</start_of_turn
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you have cured this kind of torment with urine, and purging-pills, and hiccups, and the cure does not suffice, then it is necessary to Cauterize the patient three times with the Cautery: once at the root of the ear, and the second a little lower from the ear, and the third at the junction of the two lips.</start_of_turn
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And put the Cautery on the side opposite the infirm part.</start_of_turn
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For the softening does not take place except in the part which appears healthy.</start_of_turn
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of the Cauterization is that you Cauterize with the Cautery itself at the tip of the upper ear under the ear-wax of the little horn: and the other at the ear-root. The length of each is as long as the thumb.</start_of_turn
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And put your hand away with the Cautery, until the quantity of the middle part of the thickness of the skin is consumed.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	This is the form of the Cauter, and it is of the kind which has a blade whose form precedes it: it is not subtler than water in this respect. And the blade must be of such a size as to suffice for the thickness of the tissue.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place where the operation has been made: until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	As for cauterization in ancient Apoplexia.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.</start_of_turn>
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When the ancient Apoplexia has become established, and when your treatment has failed, and the patient has no fever, then cauterize four times over every horn of the head, and cauterize in the middle of the head, as we have said, and cauterize in the back of the head, as it has been shown: and the manner of cauterization must be as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	The cauterization is also done with the Cauter over the bone of the stomach: and this is the last method.</start_of_turn
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then take care of the patient, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	Regarding the cauterization in Oblision.</start_of_turn
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.</start_of_turn
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary to give in the first place for the patient barley flour and large pills which soften the brain.</start_of_turn
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the head of the patient entirely, and place over the back of his head a patch of sponges described in the treatise on patches: and put on some of it.</start_of_turn
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This is the way of the Cauter: and do it in the order which I have said.</start_of_turn
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If he is healed thereby, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then make for him three incisions on the back of his head, which shall descend from the upper part of the head down to the lower part of the eye: and place between every incision the width of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the Cauterium, as before mentioned.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If however you wish to make an addition, and the patient is tolerant of it: then make for him a Cauterium in the middle
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	Which if you wish to make an addition: then cauterize it over two horns
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then care for it until it is healed: and keep the Cauterium oiled in accordance with the form which has been given
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	In case of palsy and mollification.
Caput X.	Head X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary to proceed in the mollification of the head with lye, and as we have said
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then remove the head of the patient: afterwards cauterize the middle of the head, and the horns of the head, and the back of the head, and three on the bones of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If however you find in the softening of the body by these many, and the patient is tolerant, and the swelling is great: then make four Cauteriums over the bones of the back, and the last one with a Cauterium, until it burns from the greater part of its surface, and lift up your hand
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for it until it is healed: and keep the Cauterium oiled.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	In case of Epilepsy
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	The epileptic head is not cauterized, except for the one whose epilepsy proceeds from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	It is necessary therefore that the physician should temper the violent action of the brain in the first place with opium, and afterwards with the other treatments which we mentioned in the preceding chapter: for when the patient is great or suffers from the action of many medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If, however, the patient is young and cannot tolerate the medicines, there is administered a gargling-drink, and biting medicines which temper the action of the brain, for many days before with the restoration of the appetite of food
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then the head is treated with powder, and afterwards the cautery is applied once in the middle of the head, as has been said previously in its kind: and the cautery is applied once in the back of the head, and over every horn of the head there is applied the cautery
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient should be strong and tolerant, then the cautery is applied with oil, as has been said previously.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If the patient is young, then the cautery is applied softly, as has been said above.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	Method of cauterizing in melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupt humours, and thick phlegm, then the cautery is applied as has been said in the case of palsy
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of wine which leads to melancholy, and the body of the patient is soft and wet, then give him something which will temper the action of the brain, as has been mentioned in the preceding chapter: then treat the head of the patient, and afterwards make a circle from the centre of the head made of linen.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the sitting patient is held fast from every side.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the unguents.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is better from old butter or oil
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And warm it over gentle fire, as much as the finger tolerates when it is introduced into it
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle, and hold it until it is cold
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this to the patient every week once, with the rest of his treatment being good, until he is healed
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small holes in it, except that you hold the hand with the cautery: for it will smell.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cautery hydrates the brain with its quality
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place over it a cushion soaked in butter, or fat from a chicken
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	So cauterize in descending water to the eye
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the beginning of water in the eye is declared by the signs which I mentioned in the explanation, then begin and pour out the patient, along with what will temper his head
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep him away from all humilities, and make him sit in a bath, for a few days
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then order him to raise his head, and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it over two temples with two cauteries, if there is an incipient descent of water in both eyes simultaneously: or from one side only, if there is an incipient descent of water in one eye only: and cut off all veins and arteries which are under the skin: and let there be cauteries in them of a length equal to the width of the temples: and burn from the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see that anything from it has escaped, then immediately cut it off with whatever medicine is available: and I shall come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and the cutting off of them, and the care of the blood flow.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when it is cauterized on the bone, under two bones, two last cauterizations are produced
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	In the ancient tears, cauterize in this way
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIIIII.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient, thick: and are upon the nails, and the arteries which are in the exterior of the head, it is verified that that is from the superfluities of cold, phlegmatic: then cauterize with the same thing which I said in the beginning of the descending water, the cautery in the middle of the head, and two cauteries upon the two temporal bones, and two cauteries in the bone under two bones
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if the addition does not suffice, then cauterize itself all around carefully around the eye, over the tip of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	In the wound of the nose, cauterize in this way
Caput XV.	Chapter XV
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating that, with what we said in the instructions, and the medicine does not suffice: then cleanse, and give in the bath of the sick person three nights: then shave his head, and cauterize it with the middle cautery, with olive oil
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with the cautery claw with two cauteries, over two superciliums under the hair slightly.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard the artery, so that you do not cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	This is the form of the cautery of Claudius.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	And this is the way of cauterization in the mollification of the Palpebrae.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.</start_of_turn>
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the Palpebra of the eye is softened by humidity or by inflammation: then cauterize the Palpebra with a single cautery, like a lunar cautery.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize the upper part of the two upper eyelashes slightly with two cauteries at all times: and draw out from two times: and let the length of every cautery be as long as the length of the eyelashes: and do not bring your hand close to the cautery, but according to the quantity which you must take from the third of the Palpebra.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cautery according to this mode of lunar cautery.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	Chapter XVII.</start_of_turn
Caput XVII.	When the eyelashes are burnt away from the eye: then cauterize the Palpebra with a lunar cautery, and move the cautery from side to side until you have cauterized all of the burnt eyelashes.</start_of_turn
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	There are two kinds of cautery: either with fire or with burning medicine.</start_of_turn
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	But in the cautery with fire, it is necessary to warn the patient beforehand so that he may expel his hairs, if there are any which are moving, until they are prolonged and equal.</start_of_turn
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If, however, the patient has them at the root of their eye: then bind his eyes with wool, so that they do not move, until they have healed.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they have healed and are equal, then put the head of the patient in your lap: then sign over the Palpebra of his eye with ink, in the form of the leaf of the Myrtle: and let the beginning of the sign be near the eyelashes.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place the soaked cushion in albumin or: on the mucus of the eyelashes above the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply the cautery, which is of this shape.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then burn over the figure which you indicated gradually in many places, until the surface of the skin is burnt, which is like the figure of a myrtle leaf, throughout its appearance
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the completion of your work is: if you touch the Palpebra of the eye with your finger and pull out the hair at the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Withdraw your hand then: and discharge him in three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place upon it a cushion with butter, until the eschar is eradicated
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguent until it is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If some hair should remain after an hour, and the Palpebra be softened: then repeat the cautery over the place as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If they are in the lower parts: then burn the area until the hair is raised to its natural place: and make it even so that the hair does not pierce the eye
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	In the same way as when cautery is done with burning medicine in this case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is necessary for the sickly person to remove the hair, until they become prolonged and even
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from parchment a shape like a myrtle leaf
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from soap that has been boiled, and from burnt lime without soaking from one pound about an ounce and a quarter: then mix these together with a good hand, and make it so that it does not freeze
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take from the end of the vein above the mark which you made like the form of a myrtle leaf, and place it upon the eyeball of one, or two.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye the soaked cotton in albumin: and the head of the patient be in your hand.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your finger on the mark over the medicine, and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you will move it whenever the patient feels the biting of the medicine: because its biting is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore you have persisted in this, when you find the biting, then remove the medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the biting has ceased, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then, if the eyeball is relaxed after the expansion, like that which is raised at the contraction with fire, or with incision, it is good: and if not, then repeat over the medicine on the place where the medicine does not touch, without damaging it, until the operation be accomplished, and the eye be contracted
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place upon it a cotton ball with butter, until the skin of the wound be scraped away
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment of diaphonius, or something else, until it is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you in the operation, that you take care of the last care, that nothing of the medicine should fall into the eye
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	Because if the eyeball becomes soft after days, and there is something gritty in the eye from the hair, then repeat the medicine on the place where the eyeball is softened by itself, like you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	This is the form of the Myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that the eyes of men differ in size and shape
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, you must take this into consideration: and it is not concealed by the uprightness of the art, which is the study of this craft
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	As for the cauterization of the fistula of the tear duct
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you have treated the fistula, when you have done what we said in the instructions for the aetiologies, and the cure does not result: then you must cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Command the patient to put his head in your lap, and hold his head between your hands like this, so that it does not move or shake with his head
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then put the sponge soaked in urine or in the mucus of the hair on his eye: then apply the Cauterium, which is of this shape
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be concave, like the shape of a feather from its extremity to the other, as Cauterium is made: and if you wish it to penetrate until the other extremity, or if you wish it to be above, do so as you please
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	It is better to make it concave for your work
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and extract from it the pus, and dry it up: and if it is not open, then open it up, and extract the pus from it.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then put on it again the Cauterium, which is made burning slightly.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	Hold your hand nearby the Cauterium from the eye to the part of the nose, so that your hand does not slip or trouble the patient: and place the Cauterium on the fat of the eye, and consume it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If indeed you proceed with the Cauterization from the beginning until the bone, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Or if not: then repeat the Cauterization once or twice if it does not suffice: and discharge it in three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then apply a compress with butter, and care for it with an unguent poultice until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If after forty days it does not heal: then apply an acute corrosive medicine above it until the bone is exposed: and then proceed according to what is written in its chapter
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of Cauterization of fistulas, which some of the first men mentioned.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Aim at the location of the fistula and find it: then place under the fistula a small cushion, that is, a cannula of a small size, whose shape is this
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it the quantity of drachmas of liquid lead, and keep your hand firmly clasped with the cannula, and do not move the patient at all, so that it does not run, or that the liquid lead should not reach his eye
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary to place over the eye of the patient a compress soaked in fat or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	Lead will consume the place of the fistula, and will heal it with a miraculous healing
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	And if the fistula is healed, with what we have said concerning Cauterization and treatment, it is good
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	Or if not, it is necessary to administer a nose-opening passage, and reduce the fistula to the curvature of the nose, according to what is proper in its own place
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the manner of cauterizing of lip-fissures.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many accidents occur in the lip concerning a fissure, which are called Pili, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you are treating these fissures, as we mentioned in the discourse about ailments, and the cure does not suffice, then you must cauterize slightly with a small knife, according to this shape
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let the cavity be equal to the thickness of the knife
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then put the fire quickly on these fissures until the cauterium reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with oil until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	Thus cauterize in the fistula of the lip.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When swelling occurs in the root of the tooth, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then pus forms, and it bursts: afterwards it becomes hardened, and pus runs out, and a fistula forms: then you must treat the fistula itself, and not the swelling, then it is necessary to cauterize according to the quantity which is in the fistula
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then introduce the fire into the cavity of the fistula and hold your hand, until the fire reaches the depth of it, and the end of it: do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it afterwards as we mentioned about the cure until it heals
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If it bursts spontaneously, and heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to remove the corrupted bone according to what comes to light in the head
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	Thus cauterize in the gums and soften the teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gums are swollen from moisture, and the teeth are loosened, and care is taken with the physicians, and it does not help: then put the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then ignite the cautery, whose form will appear afterwards, so that you can place the cautery upon the tooth: and introduce the flame into it quickly: and keep your hand steady, until the patient feels the heat of the fire to have reached the root of the tooth
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift your hand: then repeat the cautery a few more times, as you please.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient rinse his mouth with salt-water, and let him rinse for one hour: and then he shall spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	The tooth will now be firm, and the gums will be softened and dried, and the moisture will be expelled.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	Thus the cautery is to be used in toothache.
Caput XXIII.	The next chapter continues...
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache is caused by cold, or if the tooth itself is cold or wet, and the treatment does not help with the physicians: then the cautery must be used in two ways: either with butter or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cautery with butter is done by taking butter of the kind which is scraped off the calf, and mixing it with the yolk of an egg, and applying it to the tooth with a spatula
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a sponge, and put it over the end of the tooth.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then plunge it into the boiling butter: and put it upon the painful tooth quickly, and hold it there until it cools: then repeat it a few more times, until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	If desired, immerse the lancet in butter, or coat the heel in cold butter, and place it over the aching tooth: and place over it a burning iron until the fire has penetrated to the depth of the cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cauterization of it with fire is useful, so as to reach the air cavity, or the iron cavity
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be in its body some breadth, so that the intensity of the fire does not reach the sound bone.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then the cautery, which will take the form of this: place it over the tooth: and hold your hand until the cautery is cold.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this quickly, for pain will depart, or in the same day, or another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary to impress the impression of the cautery, so that it may fill the sick bone with butter, and keep it for an hour: then spit it out
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	The cauterize with whatever extremity you will, as is possible: and this is the form of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	In this manner the cauterizing of the molars.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the molars are affected by phlegmas, and by cold humilities, and do not obey digestion by medicines, and you wish to accelerate their digestion: then cauterize the cavity which has this shape.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, so as to escape the smoke of the cautery from the other extremity: place the burning iron over the tooth once, and a second time, if you do not digest it, until it has penetrated to the depth of the cavity
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the fistula is small: then apply the Cauterium according to the quantity of the fistula.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then discharge it for three days, and place above it a soaked cushion in butter, until it has recovered what the fire consumed
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with ointment of teeth, until it heals in the form of a tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	In the swelling of the belly, and constriction of the breath.
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
