Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When the belly becomes moist over the passage of the wind, and especially when it is with the coldness of the complexion: then it is necessary to evacuate the patient at once with the physicians who are accustomed to such things.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it in the night at the root of the gullet in a depressed place: and burn, do not bring near the Cauterium to the gullet, nor on the skin, except for something of that sort
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another Cauterium at the juncture of the neck at the end of its last rib: and let the Cauterium be closed according to the mode which preceded it
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which preceded it, until it heals
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	In the ailments of the lungs, and of the breast.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When there is cough and pulmonary disease from cold humors, and the patient has neither fever nor phthisis, nor old cough: then cauterize it with two Cauteriums above the epiglottis in depressed places, in lenium, in the groove.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And another Cauterium in the middle of the chest between the two nipples: and let the Cauterium be in the form of a tube as it preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	If one wishes to perform a cauterization by puncturing with the cautery, which is called Punctum, whose form precedes in the puncture of the ear: there should be punctures from thirty punctures up to almost as many.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with that which precedes, until it is healed
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And if there is a cautery having three branches: according to this shape
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore the cautery will be alleviated with that which is done with the three Cauteries when you make it with that liquid one time
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	In the same way as for cauterizing in Titillico, in dislocation of the Humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.</start_of_turn>
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the adductor muscle is dislocated due to humidity, and does not settle back in its place within an hour of its dislocation, until it has become accustomed to its retraction, then it should be displaced by a slight movement, as we have testified to this. Then it is necessary to reduce the dislocation immediately.</start_of_turn>
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the diseased person is laid over his back, or on the healthy side.</start_of_turn
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then lift the skin which is in the inside of the Titillico towards the upper parts with your left hand: and if the dislocation has gone inwards.</start_of_turn
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take a cautery having two handles.</start_of_turn
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose form is like this.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it pierces the other side, and the figure of the cauterization will appear with four cauteries.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And when there is a cauterization with a cautery having three handles, because of the shape of the cauterization, there will be six cauteries in its figure: and there are two handles following the sharpness of the attempt.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	This is the shape of a cautery having three holes.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	When one adds this to that mode one, there are eight cauteries in all
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then put over the cautery the fat pigs with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make fast the sick man calmly, so that he does not move the limb for some time, until he is comfortable
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is towards the upper parts, and this rarely happens, then cauterize it upon the humerus with the hook cautery, or with many punctures
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the connection will be firm, and the moisture will be driven out: and the sick man will be healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	Method of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Head of the eighth hour.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and much moisture are brought into the Stomach, until you have extracted it from its complex, and multiplied the catarrh upon it, and applied the methods of treatment diligently, and do not fear: then it is necessary for the sick man to lie upon his back, to extend his limbs, and to stretch out his hands
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries, a cautery under the pectoralis angle measuring the quantity of one finger with a hook cautery, and two lower ones from two sides of one cautery, until the figure of the cauteries becomes triangular
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And lengthen between each other so that they do not join, when they produce pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cautery is the quantity of two-thirds of the thickness of the skin
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of the cauteries be in this shape without addition: and if you wish to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this shape: and let the cautery be as this one which makes this cautery to be one according to the shape of the circle according to this shape
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And it is cauterized with the stomach punctured, that which returns from this cautery: and it is, that signs above the stomach puncture according to quantity, as much as with encasement: then cauterize itself with the cautery of the puncture: then care for it with the care which preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	And so it is cauterized with the cold [cautery].
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When it happens in the Epate that there is pain from the cold and humidity, or from great wind, until it departs from its natural composition through excessive evacuation, and the infirm is cared for as we have said, and does not increase in it: then it is necessary that the infirm rest upon his belly, and signs with three cauteries according to this figure and this quantity over the Ep below the hypochondria, where the elbow of a man rests: and let there be space between every cauterization according to the breadth of a finger: and let the cauterization be according to the length of the body's rectum: and do not press your hand too much with the cautery.</start_of_turn>
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of the latter be such as that which is absorbed from the thickness of the skin, without adding the middle quantity: and let the infirm be standing upon his feet.</start_of_turn
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If he is not standing, then let him be lying down, who has extended his limbs and raised his arms.</start_of_turn>
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.</start_of_turn
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And indeed it is possible that these cauteries may be made with a knife when there is subtlety and prudence in the art.</start_of_turn
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And take care that you do not go too far in the cautery, and that you burn the entirety of the skin, because the body is thereby burned throughout, and reaches the intestines: for the skin there is thin, as you know.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the method of cauterizing the liver after-effects.
Caput XXX.	On the method of cauterizing the liver after-effects.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When this happens, and you are aware of it, if the after-effect is in the liver flesh or its covering: if it is in the liver flesh, there is mild pain and slight swelling without sharpness: and if it is in the liver covering, with sharp pain that extends upwards: know that the physician has become weary of its treatment.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore it is necessary for the physician to rest the patient above the navel
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the figure of the after-effect is placed with the cautery: then the cautery is applied which is readily absorbed by the rays.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with one cautery until the whole skin is burnt, and it reaches the fat, until the whole wound is healed: then care for the after-effects until healing is complete
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And do not let any other kind of cautery be used except that which is learned in the art of medicine: and by the hand of those who have experience in these matters: for otherwise you will hear of many such operations.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	In this case, I would rather leave it alone.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the method of cauterizing in the pleura.
Caput XXXI.	On the method of cauterizing in the pleura
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients say that cautery with the roots of aristolochia should be applied to the cold pleura according to this method.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is like taking from the dry roots of aristolochia a long root, which comes from it, and be as thick as the breadth of a finger
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse the limb in oil: and raise it in fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one instrument at the point where the furcula joins the neck, and with two small cautery instruments under guidance slightly depressed to the part which is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And also two cautery instruments at the point which is between the fifth and sixth ribs depressed downwards: and a cautery instrument at the middle of the chest, and one above the stomach
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cautery instruments from behind: one at the point which is between two ribs, and two at the two sides of the chest, the lower cautery being at the point which is between two ribs.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And do not press the hand with the cautery, but rather let the smell of the skin suffice.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancient writers say that there are certain men who use a cautery like a rod of iron: they burn and throw it into the place between the ribs, until it is consumed by them to the very end, and comes out whole: as we said in the case of the Epiglottis.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation with the cautery there is fear lest the patient should immediately die or that a fistula should occur in the place, which has no healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	In this way cauterize the Spleen Head as follows:
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you are treating the pain of the spleen, when that treatment which we mentioned in the enumeration of diseases has not produced a cure, then you must cauterize in three ways, all of which are straight forward
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of them is to make three cauteries or four in a row according to the length of the spleen, following the figure of the cautery which we mentioned concerning the liver.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And be between every cauterization the quantity of breadth of a finger, or more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And be the manner of cauterization as we said in the cauterization of the liver equally
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press the hand with the cauterization: and let the patient lie relaxed above his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another manner of cauterization is: that you have two rings holding the cauterization, as we said in the chapter on the dislocation of the humerus: and elevate the skin which is over the spleen, where the patient's elbow bends: and elevate your elevation as much as the width of the patient's body, so that the cauteries fall according to the length of the patient's body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert two rings with the fire alight until when the cauterization has penetrated the skin from the other side: then remove the cauterization: four cauteries will remain
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with another cauterization which has three rings.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then take care of the cauterization after you have sent it away to emit pus for many days: for it is better to confer than to leave anything remaining from the cure
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	In the case of cauterization for hydrops.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cauterization does not fall in hydrops, except as it is burned itself.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat hydrops with the methods of treatment which we said in the section on wound care, and the cure does not appear, then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauterizations around the navel, one on the stomach, one on the liver, and one on the spleen, and two on the back between the vertebrae, and one in the centre of the chest, and one in the centre of the abdomen: and let the quantity of depth of the cauterization be close to the thickness of the skin
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then discharge the opened cautery, so that pus may issue forth over a long period of time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	Do not leave the patient unattended after the cautery has been used: for two intentions must be applied to him at the same time: and it will hasten his recovery with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The shape of the cautery which is to be used for the belly is like a nail: as it has been previously described; and that which is to be used for the back is like an olive, as it has been previously described
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	As regards the cautery of the feet and legs...
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When they swell in Hydropsicus, and are filled with yellow water: it is necessary to cauterize over the back of the foot between the heel and the ankle: and hold your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then raise your hand: and do not move it at all
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	The yellow water will rise up, and the cautery must be in this shape.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make on each leg two cauteries at the ankle, and make the cautery with the tip of the cautery: and make the cautery according to the length of the leg, one below the knee and the other above it at the middle of the leg: and make two cauteries over every hip: and discharge the opened cautery without treatment over a long period of time: so that some of the water may remain from it: then care for the limb as we have said before
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	As regards the cautery in the solution of the belly...
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 5.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the belly is softened by cold and moisture until the retention and digestion of urine are weakened, which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured in the manner of treatment and not by itself: and give the patient the one who tolerates the excessive power of the cautery, then cauterize him with a great cautery over his stomach, according to what has been described in the cautery of the stomach with the circular cautery, and four cauteries around the navel, with a nail-shaped cautery under the navel, and a large cautery over the fat above the loin, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	If the moist humors are excessive, and the patient tolerates it, then burn it with the cautery over the belly and over all the intestines: and perhaps add two small cauteries near the great stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	This is a complete and accurate translation of the sentence.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	Method of cautery for haemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 6.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old haemorrhoids in the rectum, or one, and they are made by gross, cold or damp humours, and are not cured by what has been said, then burn three cauteries over the lower spine below the ribs in a triangular shape, and burn under the navel as if with two fingers
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is hardened, and that his food does not digest, and that he vomits fluid from his face, then burn him with a large cautery over the stomach according to what has been said: and burn over the spleen and the other over the tail of the pancreas, with the clamp open for a while: then care for him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	Method of cautery for the carbuncle after its excision.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 7
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you excise the carbuncle, then burn the cautery that absorbs the heat
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the burning cautery into the excised carbuncle: and move your hand until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which blood runs: do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many carbuncles, then burn each one individually as we have said
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then care for it until it heals, when whatever was given from the unguents has been administered.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	If you cauterize it with a great cautery over the burn, that is the last thing to do in treatment.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	In this way cauterize the fistula in the anus.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.</start_of_turn
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not obey the section [of the bowel] and the work which we have narrated in its place, and returns from it, perhaps it will heal with cautery.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When therefore anything happens to a fistula, and it becomes old, pus runs from it, and the putrefied parts become moist.</start_of_turn
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore it is necessary to explore it with a thin hook.</start_of_turn
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then know the extent of its depth with the hook.</start_of_turn
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then make a burn with the cautery, which is like a ray.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then enter yourself with the burning cautery into the fistula and the amount in which the clamp has entered.</start_of_turn
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the burning of the cautery until all the corrupted parts are consumed, once, or twice, or three times, according to the necessity.</start_of_turn
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And keep away from the bowels of nerves, if they are there, or great veins: or if the fistula goes to the body of the intestine, or to the body of the stomach, then keep away from these places altogether.</start_of_turn
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	Do not do this except when the fistula is in a fleshy place: and think, for it is not penetrating.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the place until it is healed.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If, however, the place is sealed and materials are removed from it, and it remains thus for a long time: then you know that it has already healed whole
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	Or if materials are not removed from it, then you know that it is penetrating, or that bone in its depth is corrupted, or as if that from those things: of which memory will come to the place itself.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	In this way the veins are cauterized.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When it happens in the kidneys that there is pain from cold, or from large wind, and they are diminished through that from which the patient is suffering, then it is necessary to cauterize them over the marrow over the kidneys, cauterizing every kidney with a cautery claw, of which there must be memory.</start_of_turn>
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we cauterize it a second time in the same place.</start_of_turn
Quare uenient tria lineata.	For there come three lines.</start_of_turn
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore there are two last things in the cautery.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	In this way the bladder is cauterized.</start_of_turn
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.</start_of_turn
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When there is weakness in the bladder, and softening from stones and humilities, until the patient does not retain urine, then cauterize it in the lower part of the belly above the bladder, where the hair of the testicles begins, and cauterize from the right side of the belly, and from the left side of it: and let the length of this cautery be as much as the thumb node: and cauterize it with a lower burn, or with two burns, if you like: and let it be according to what preceded the cautery claw.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	On how to cauterize the Matrix.
Caput XLI.	On how to cauterize the Matrix.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and moisture are present in the Matrix, and it is hindered by that from receiving impregnation, and its menstrual flow is corrupted, and its progress is delayed, and there is pain in its vicinity, then it is necessary to cauterize three times around the navel, as we mentioned in the cauterization of the uterus, and cauterize above the lower cartilage of the loin, or perform two cauterizations: and let the cauterium be blunt.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	On how to cauterize the Ancham in dislocation
Caput XLII.	On how to cauterize the Ancham in dislocation
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When moisture of the mucous is exuded at the foot of the Ancham, and is the cause of its displacement from its place: and the sign of that is when one limb hangs longer than the other when compared with the limb at the same level: and the place of dislocation is found in that cavity
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore it is necessary to cauterize the diseased part above the foot of the Ancham with a cauterium of a circle: after which you must draw a sign around the circumference of the foot: and let the foot itself fall in the middle of the circle
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cauterium be of the form that we mentioned in the cauterization of the stomach
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If you do not have this type of cauterium, then perform three cauterizations with a large olive cauterium: and make the depth of the cauterization according to the amount of thickness of the skin of the whole body.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	On how to cauterize in Sciatica
Caput XLIII.	Head Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the bone of the ankle, and the cause of that is coldness and moisture: the physician must treat the patient with that which we have mentioned in the treatise, and not otherwise; for it will vanish. Then it is necessary to remove the patient from the humours by means of foul pills, or artificial pills, or the like.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the mode of cauterization in this is by two methods: either with a cautery with burnings, or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	Cauterization with fire is according to many methods.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of them is that one should cauterize over the bone of the ankle itself with three triangular cauteries, according to this form.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make the depth good, or bad
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And there should be space between every two cauteries equal to the thickness of a finger: and let the cautery be round
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	When, however, the cautery is made in the middle over the bone of the ankle itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Then there are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you cauterize in a circle, whose shape precedes the form of the dislocation of the ankle, one: so that it should contain the whole ankle
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the whole skin
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the mode of cauterization in Sciatica, when the pain is adherent to the ankle itself, and does not extend up to the knee and leg
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If, however, it extends up to the knee and leg, then cauterize with two cauteries over the knee, over the place where the patient feels pain there, and cauterize your fourth finger towards the heel: and let the cautery be triangular
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	The depth of the burn should be in accordance with the depth of the blistering of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the patient complains that the pain extends up to the toes, then burn there where the burn of a point, or a triangle, or a square, or many, is sufficient for that area.</start_of_turn>
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	If he complains of pain under the knee, then burn there with a single lancet.</start_of_turn>
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	In all your burnings, take care that you do not reach the nerves or great artery, and that you do not cause any lasting damage to the patient's body.</start_of_turn>
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	I have seen one who was burned on the thigh by those who were burning above the knee, and they completed their burning, and the limb became swollen, until the foot was completely black, and all was perforated and corrupted. Then there followed solution of the belly and death.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If there is pain in two parts together, burn both of them in the same way.</start_of_turn>
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men have said concerning the burning of an abscess that this is its manner.</start_of_turn
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a mark like that of iron, whose diameter is half the palm: and let it be at a distance from the orifice equal to the thickness of the thumb nail, or less. And within this there is to be a third part like itself.</start_of_turn
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And there should be space between every mark equal to the quantity of the thumb joint: and let the marks be opened from two parts: and let their height be like a knot, or two knots. And make a handle of iron well adapted to the marks.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it is ignited in fire until it turns red, and shoots sparks: then it is placed upon a cushion over the painful side resting on the sound side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	So it is cauterized with three round cautery instruments in one vessel.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then it is left for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Then it is plastered with butter: and the wound is opened for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguent until it is healed
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, with regard to this kind of cautery, of the sons of the physicians, we use it little, because of its fearsome appearance: and because of this, few expect it over it
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	But indeed from the good cautery instruments it has its effect on him who uses it, and finds its place with it
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	The cautery, however, with the physicians who are burned by it, is like two companions who have a perforated arm, in which the heart of its vein comes out from the air, or from iron, the length of the wall: of which two knots or as many as are in their height.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let there be space between each of these quantities equal to the thickness of a finger, and let there be an opening below and above: and let them contain themselves inside, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it upon a cushion over the painful side resting on the sound side
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And compress your hand over the cushion much
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles of lukewarm water, which is warmed with fire a little, and keep it for an hour: and the patient will endure the biting of it, and even its touch, for indeed he finds biting like fire until it rests.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then elevate your hand with the instrument, and draw hot water from the whole basin with sweet water: then let it go for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put butter on it, until the black of the wound has subsided: then let it go for a few days, and pus will come out of it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	This is the ultimate remedy.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents, until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends up to the hip or the thigh: make for it a basin containing water, as you did in the basin before
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	This is the way of hot water: and I have written it in the treatise on the rectification of medicine.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali, and burnt lime ground together in equal parts: there should be two of each: and put them into a new basin, the lower part of which is perforated with a small hole, according to the quantity of the radius: and put under the bottom of the basin another basin filled with water: and pour over the alkali and lime sweet water, which should cover both by a finger: and when you have pressed them with your hand with a good compression: let the basin go, until the acute water of the lower basin has descended.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather up the whole water, and pour it over another lime: and cool, until it recovers
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	These are indeed strong and acute, which are administered in many medical operations, and in the cauterization of the rest of the limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Because it makes the operation of fire itself
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And among the physicians, when they cauterize the basin, even as for testicles, and mastic, and nails, and lime with soap, it is so that both are mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	Galen also reports that an ancient physician treated a wound of the anus and a sciatica: and praised his skill.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	He also says that no other treatment was needed, and that it was healed by means of a single bath.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	He is accustomed to take from the beard of a young man: if one cannot find one of these, take fat, pure and mixed: and apply it to the anus, where the pain is, or to the thigh or hip: and bind it, and leave it for three hours, or for as long as the patient feels relief from the pain
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then put him into a bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When his body is soft, put him into the bath.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain departs, and he is healed
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you know that no other caustic should be used with these medicines, except after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	Dioscorides also says that the dung of goats, when burned with vinegar, brings relief to a sciatica: and it burns in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Take wool, and soak it in old oil, and apply it to the deep place which is between the thumb of the foot and the heel, and is closer to the heel
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take the dry goat dung and burn it.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then put it on the wool and leave it until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Do this again.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Do not cease doing this until the sense of pain has passed away from the anus, and rest has been taken from the pain
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cautery is called the cautery of Vaccinum.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	Of the cautery for the pain of the back
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When there is pain in the back from many causes, or from a wound, or from a blow, or from excessive evacuation, and similar things, from the infusion of cold and moist matter: and the cautery is not useless, except for one kind alone, which is made from the infusion of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary therefore after evacuation of the patient with foetid pills, and things like these, to make three lines across the back where there is pain, as wide as the breadth of the palm of the hand, and to burn with the cautery five cauteries in every line, or more according to the tolerance of the patient or the extent of his pain: and to make the cautery with the point of the cautery
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you will, burn three or four cauteries with the middle cautery point, according to this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Of the way of cauterizing in the hernia of the abdomen
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This disease often happens to young children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its inception in children is: when there is a stricture in the bellybutton with vomiting and elevation, and movement: and you will find it in the last vertebra of the back and the nodes of the back, which begin to bulge out over the rest of the vertebrae
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you see this, and if you wish to make it better, then burn it with the cautery which is in the shape of a circle according to this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	Capture the cautery over every part of the spondilis equally: and if you wish to cauterize around the circumference of the spondilis with the cautery, make two or three lines, and let the points be close to one another.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place, until it is healed as we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And be careful, do not apply the cautery to the swelling, which is caused by a spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	In the case of podagra and joint pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of the joints are caused by cold humors, which flow to every part of the body, and when they affect the feet, it is customary among physicians to call this podagra
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When it is cured by cold causes of podagra, with the methods of treatment, and not by removing the pain, then the cautery will remove them
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is necessary to cauterize after evacuation around the joints of the feet with many cautery instruments: and let the cautery be of Olive oil
Cuius haec est forma.	This is the form of it
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you do not wish to make holes on the face of the foot, then make them with the cautery at the points
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	When the pains rise up to the knee, or affect the other joints, and this happens often, then cauterize over the whole knee with three or four cautery instruments, using the same cautery of Claudius
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If necessary, do it more often with this cautery
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	Do not immerse your hand with the cautery, but rather keep the thickness of the skin around it
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If, however, pain ascends to the knee and back: then administer what we said concerning cautery in its chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If pain is only in the hands: then prick around the focus of the nails, as two lines are unrolled.</start_of_turn>
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If pain remains in the toes: then prick throughout, over every node and over the palm of the hand.</start_of_turn>
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If pain ascends after a day to the cubits or arms: then cauterize both from every part.</start_of_turn
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not make the patient worse by improper treatment or neglect of medicines.</start_of_turn>
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if good treatment is done and the phlegm is evacuated, healing will take place with the help of God along with this cautery.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	¶ Regarding the cautery of ruptures.</start_of_turn
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin and the intestine or bladder descends to the testicles, and it is imminent: then it is necessary to expel the patient from the diet for a day.</start_of_turn
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use gentle food, from which the stool will descend from its belly.</start_of_turn
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and command him to hold his breath until the bladder or intestine comes out, or until it appears.</start_of_turn
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce it with your fingers, and sign with the cautery under the rupture over the bone of the pelvis, with the sign that its extremity is similar to half the circumference of the body.</start_of_turn
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then the cautery is applied, its form being such that it shall remain white until it has approached its target, and shall emit sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then the intestine, or the bladder to its cavity
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then the hand of the minister is placed over the place, so that the intestine does not escape: and you have opened between the ribs of the patient, and placed under it powder, and a servant over the ribs of him, and another over his chest which holds the hand.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then the cautery is placed upon the very sign, your hand with the cautery being held straight
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it there until you reach the bone: or repeat it with it another time if you have not succeeded in reaching the bone from the first attempt until the bone itself
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And cautiously observe the escape of the intestine during the process of your cautery, that you do not burn it, and that it escapes through that over the patient or the blood, or great harm.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not reach the bone with the cautery, your work is in vain.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery be fine for infants, according to their measure
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the remaining parts, until they are healed
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the patient rest upon his back for forty days, until the wound is healed
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you give him nourishment during the time of his recovery, which will soften his bowels: that the intestine does not escape from its place at the concavities and evacuation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when you wish him to rise after forty days, then manage the loosened ligament and keep it for another forty days
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And they do not return from work, neither from the repletion of food and drink, nor from the use of strong medicines.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	When one uses this regimen, the body is healed whole
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I shall say that the treatment of ruptures is with an incision in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When, however, the ruptures happen in the rest of the belly and are beginning, and one wishes that they should not be added, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to its quantity: and let that which is cauterized be as much as three-fourths of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then care for the itself, as we have said: and do not add to it.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some people say that the rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautery, according to this shape.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	When it has been signed with the cautery, and a line is drawn which is along the width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line is drawn to the lower side
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And put your hand in the middle with the cautery clamp
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easier and better
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	In the case of pains caused by falling or percussion.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When in some limb there is pain from a fall or percussion, and the pain persists for a long time, and does not yield to treatment with physicians: then it is necessary to cauterize with a Puncti cautery
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And the cautery must be of the size of the limb, and of its proportion, and of its flexibility, and of its toughness, and of the twisting of the part, and of the pain from it
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If he has recovered from the first cautery, it is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat over the said cautery.</start_of_turn>
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For the custom of these aches is that they change from member to member approaching them.</start_of_turn>
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore you must follow them with the cautery until the patient has recovered.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	About the manner of cautery in Lepra.</start_of_turn
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLVIX.</start_of_turn>
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Leprosy, however, sometimes requires great cautery.</start_of_turn
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the kind of Leprosy which is caused by putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: with such a kind you must consider the cautery itself.</start_of_turn
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If the Lepra is not serious, and you wish to do something with it as we have said before, and it does not progress: and times over the patient, which includes corruption over his whole face: then cauterize him over the head five times: one in the middle of the head known as the nuchal, and the second below it facing the front near the end of the hair, and two over the two horns, and one behind the earlobe.</start_of_turn
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And lastly touch your hand with the cautery lightly, until you leave an imprint in the bone, and the cortex is fractured: so as to alleviate the emission of foul vapors from it. And cauterize also over the spleen as before.</start_of_turn
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	If however the Lepra is scattered over the patient and appears obvious: then you must cauterize with these cauteries which we have mentioned in the head, and a cautery over the tip of the nose, and two over the two cheekbones, and two over the collarbones, and six over the vertebrae of the back, and one large one over the fatty tissue at the base of the buttocks and one over the middle of the thigh: and two over the armpits: namely one over every armpit, and two over the knees: one over every knee, and two over the upper arms, and two over the elbows, and two over the chest.</start_of_turn
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And take care of the nerves that are above the heel, so that you do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	When you cauterize with the cautery above the anklebone, and also above the stomach bone, and also above the spleen.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	Know that the more you add cautery, the greater the bleeding, and the greater the risk of harm
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And you know that the sickly man does not feel pain in the cautery, just as he does not feel it in health: because his body is already stunned
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	It is necessary that the cautery be of moderate size, and of smallness in accordance with the parts and the joints: in accordance with what precedes from the kinds of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the cautery from the flour of herbs with honey, and the rest of the treatment, until the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	In this way, cauterize in the groin.
Caput L.	Head L
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When some limb is stiff, and is being treated with physicians, and oils, and plasters, and it does not heal, then cauterize the stiffened limb with cautery, according to the greatness of the limb or its thinness
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	Let your cautery not go through the thickness of the skin lightly
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with unguent until it is healed
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	When you cauterize anything of stiffness of the hand, and the foot, on the spine of the back near the exit of the nerves that move that limb: and you will remove the stiffness.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But do not be proud of this, except for one who is learned in the anatomy of the limbs, and the exit of the nerves that move the body
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	How to cauterize in Albaras.
Caput LI.	How to cauterize in Albaras.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albaras has hardened, and no oil from the surgeon's art remains in it: then cauterize above with a deep-seated cautery, according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin, until the white is removed, and the colour changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with barley flour, lentils with oil of rose, and leaves of arnica, and blood from columbine, and blood from hyacinth: from each take one part: mix all these things together, and smear over the wound, and bind in place, until healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	How to cauterize in Cancer
Caput LII.	How to cauterize in Cancer
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When Cancer is beginning, and you wish to stop it: then cauterize it with a circular cautery around its circumference, as it returns
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	But some wise men say, that the last cautery should be in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	I do not see that. Because I fear that it will ulcerate: and I have seen that happen many times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	It is better to cauterize around it with a circle, as we have said: or with multiple cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	How to cauterize in Adubelati
Caput LIII.	How to cauterize in Adubelati
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When anyone has Adubelati, and it is delayed in maturity, or because of excessive fatness, or because of age which is feeble, or because of time, and wishes to hasten the maturity of Adubelati: then cauterize around its circumference with many small punctures
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then depart from it.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	Then depart from it. For it will hasten with maturity
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If however you wish to perforate it with a cautery, then ignite the cautery, which has this shape.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the Adubelat, until it penetrates the skin: and let the cautery be from that which follows the diseased, in order to soothe the course of the pure blood
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	Thus cauterizing in a soft ulcer.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 14.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A soft ulcer is not except a corruption in a movable limb, and corrupts it: just as fire consumes dry wood
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If therefore you wish to cauterize the soft ulcer in a place where you can use fire with the cautery, then ignite the cautery with many small and large sparks, according as will be convenient in the place where the soft ulcer is
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from all sides until you have removed the whole corruption, and let nothing remain of it inside
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then depart from it for three days, and place upon the cauterized place sulfur which has been ground with oil, until all the eschars have been eradicated, and all the corruption is gone
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for it with nourishing unguents which generate flesh
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If therefore you see that after three days new flesh has been born which is healthy and has no corruption, it is good
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then repeat the cautery over that which remains from the corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And the soft ulcer is treated sometimes with acute medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery.
Caput LV.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	The fire itself arises from the place of the cautery
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then release it [the clot], for the bladder is erased with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do so with one hand after the other, until you have gone over all that is in the body from hand to hand
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for the wound after it has been eradicated, when it generates flesh from its roots.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	Regarding cautery in Tremore.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 66.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When it happens to anyone to have a tremor from cold in the nerve, or from a quartan fever, or from something else: then it is necessary to cauterize it four times with the cautery, or five on the vertebrae of the back, and between every vertebra cauterize, and in its belly cauterize, and on its stomach cauterize.</start_of_turn>
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	The tremor will rest with olive cautery, and the health will quickly recover from cold sickness.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	Regarding cautery of the Albathir.</start_of_turn
Caput LVII.	Chapter 67.</start_of_turn
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	When there are expelled from the body of the Albathir pus-like boils, which are caused by corrupted thick matter.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	It is necessary therefore in the first place when they appear to cauterize over every head of the boils with fine cautery with a twig of myrtle whose extremity is kindled with fire.</start_of_turn
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of long aristolochia.</start_of_turn
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with lenticular cautery.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And when they have been cauterized enough at the beginning of their expulsion in this way: and they do not increase: they break through the superabundance making the swelling cease, and they are healed from the residue.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	Truth be told, it is necessary that this be done after evacuation with a bloodletting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	In the flow of blood from the artery to the wound, cauterization must be done.</start_of_turn>
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII.</start_of_turn>
