Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Many times, blood flows from the artery that has been cut at the wound, which occurs either externally, at the incision of the skin, or by cauterization of the limb, and the like: and this makes it difficult to close it.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	When this happens to anyone, then do as I have said concerning the orifice of the artery, and place your finger over it: and tighten it much, until the blood is held under your finger and does not flow out of it.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put in the fire a small piece of olive oil cauterium, and many in number: and blow over them, until they are ignited gently.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from among these one, or a few, or many, according to the wound and the place where the artery is ruptured, and place the cauterium upon the wound itself: and when you have moved your finger away quickly, hold the cauterium until the blood is closed.</start_of_turn
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	And if it comes out with the finger from the orifice of the artery, and you extinguish the cauterium, then take another cauterium quickly, from those which are prepared in the fire.</start_of_turn
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Do not cease doing this until the blood is closed.</start_of_turn
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	Take care, lest you burn the nerve that is there, and do not add any other harmful thing to the wound.</start_of_turn
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know this, that when blood flows from an artery, it is impossible to clamp it off: especially when the artery is large, except with four fingers.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or as with a cautery, as we have already said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or by extraction, when it is not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, the extremities recoil, and the blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is bound with a strong ligature
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or there are placed above it medical instruments which have the property of cutting off the blood, and are bound with a finger constriction
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whosoever performs an excision with a ligature and a tightening with a bandage, or by position of the burning things, and the like, does not give it sufficient pain, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If, however, this happens to anyone who has no physician or medicine present: then he should take hold of the tip of the index finger over the opening of the vein, as we have said, and constrict it downwards, until the blood is overcome from the upper part of the wound, and over the artery itself
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be moved, but should be held down with cold water or ice, always, until the blood is congealed, and has swollen, and is cut off
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile consider whether it is necessary to use a cautery or medicine
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	Of Incision, Perforation, and Phlebotomy in wounds, and like things.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have said in the first chapter that all ailments in which it is expedient to use a cautery or burning medicine, and the occasions, causes, and instruments of these things
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I place the head there from the vertex to the foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I proceed in this chapter in the same way: as when I am treating the cause of the ailment.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	Before I begin this, it is necessary to add that which is in this chapter is from the error of the first chapter concerning cauterization
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	Therefore it is necessary to be cautious in this handling, because in the operation which is in this chapter, there often falls evacuation of blood with the gut, with which there is pain at the opening of the belly, or incision over the swelling, or opening of the fistula, or cure of the wound, or extraction of an arrow, or incision over a stone, and these things are similar: from all of which is associated with tremor, and fear, and falls in many of them.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	I warn you, do not be deceived by the appearance of ease in this matter, for often they fall to you in this art as in the case of men with diseases like those of women
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For there is he who flees with his ailment, and is light to you in the matter: because of the great violence of his disease and the length of his suffering
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when the ailment is from fear, it signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And he who gives you his word, and says to you, hoping for your health, while his ailment is malicious.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	It is not proper for you to consent to him who comes to you from that side, whose way of life is like this
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And be more cautious than your eagerness and your impetuosity
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume anything about it from that, except after a certain knowledge has been proved to you which confirms that this is the consequence of a successful procedure
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And be diligent in the care of all female patients, in prognostication and indication of that to which it is convenient that health should be directed.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in this lies your aid to the attainment of fame and glory, and the memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, son, your intellect, and do not take away from you direction and inspiration: for this is in his hand
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I have ordered this chapter to be distinguished by chapters, following that which preceded in the chapter of Cautery, from the groin to the feet: that you may be able to learn what you wish from it, and for what you desire
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Of the care of water which accumulates in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this ailment often happens to children at birth: or when the midwife tightens the head of the child without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And sometimes also from an occult cause which is not known
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I have not seen this ailment in anyone except children: and concerning all those whom I have seen suffer from it, I have seen no benefit from surgery in it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I have seen among children whose head was full of water, and the head would swell up every day, until they could not sit on their own because of the size of their head: and the moisture increased until they died
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture is either accumulated between the skin and the bone: or is accumulated under the bone over the cartilage
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in this case, if the moisture is between the skin and the bone, and the swelling is slight, then it is necessary to make a single incision in the middle of the head, of the length of two knots, until the moisture is cured
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	This is the shape of a sponge.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If there is too much moisture, and the sponge is large, then make two incisions, according to this shape
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	If the moisture is under the bone, and its sign is that the fluid spills out from every part of the head: and the water is drained when you press your hand into the inside, and it does not remain hidden: then it is necessary to make three incisions in the middle of the head, according to this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, extract all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then string the incisions with silk and wool
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then suture it up from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the ligament, and care for the wound with tension and oiling.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not make the head tight with the stitches.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the patient with little dry food until the limb is comfortable and healed
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another way of making an incision is to consider the size of the abscess and the collection of water
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes it is in the back more, or in the cheek, or in the right, or in the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Proceed therefore with the incision where you see the abscess and the collection of water: and cut it according to what you are able to do
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, that you do not cut an artery, and there is no excessive bleeding, and the patient dies from that bleeding along with the evacuation of the moisture
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Of the incisions of the arteries which are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When any swelling occurs in the eyes or chest, and the same persists, and no remedy befits it by means of medicines: then the last remedy is that of cutting through both of those arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	It is necessary therefore when one desires to cut through them, that the patient abate his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then let friction be made with rough cloth, that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then let the patient tighten his neck with whatever cloth he has.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the pulse is to be found.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places where both of them are to be found are those which lie under the ears depressed: and they are rarely hidden, except in some men
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with a cautery above each: and cut through both of them with a knife as keen as possible, incision being made to the bone: and do this through the breadth of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if one wishes, introduce a sponge under the artery, and cut through towards the upper parts with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be like two joined fingers
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the artery is cut, blood flows out with the pulsation, which leaps inside in great quantity.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If however the artery does not appear to the sense, then it is necessary to measure from the ear to the quantity of three fingers' breadth.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with a cautery, and find until the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which must be emitted from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps more or less is emitted from it
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	The whole of that depends on the quantity which appears to you from the pain of the patient and the distension of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Consider the wound then.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if anything remains on the bone from the scraping, then cut that away so that a callous abscess does not form: then bind up the wound with linen strips
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound with ointment until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	Concerning the extraction of arteries which are in temporary pain.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man that he has an ancient headache, or an acute catarrh because of sour humours, and heat in the lacerations of the times, or an old soda, or vinegar, or things like these: and it is not to be cured with the methods of medical treatment, then we are experts in extracting arteries from the times, or cauterizing them as we have narrated
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of the operation in the extraction of these is that the patient shaves the hair that is in the times, and grasps the apparent artery in the time.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	It itself is shown to you by its pulse, and rarely is it hidden except in a few people, or because of the cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden from you, then the patient should bind up his head with anything he has: then rub the place with rough linen cloth
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or pour water over the place with hot water, until the artery appears to you visibly
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take hold of the forceps, as I said before the form.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape with it the skin with ease, until you reach the artery
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then project the thumb forward into the hook, and draw it out towards the upper parts, until you have drawn it out from the root, and make the thumb lie flat against the tunics which are under it from all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the vessel is slender: then encircle the thumb with the tip of the hook.</start_of_turn>
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut away from that part according to the quantity that the extremities extend, and contract, and the blood flow does not increase.</start_of_turn>
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut away, and if it is not severed, the blood does not ascend fully.</start_of_turn>
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then evacuate from the blood about six ounces, up to three.</start_of_turn
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the vessel is large: then it is necessary that you tie the thumb in two places with a strong thread, from silk: or from horsehair, so that it does not become putrid before the wound is consolidated, and the blood flow increases.</start_of_turn>
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the excess, which is between the two ligatures.</start_of_turn
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this in an hour, or after an hour.</start_of_turn
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, burn the thumb with a cautery until it reaches the bone, with a cautery knife: until the extremities of it are severed, and it remains in the place of the work.</start_of_turn
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better to do the work if the patient has a fever, or high complexion.</start_of_turn
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For the cautery is from a substance that dries up humors.</start_of_turn
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better to suture.</start_of_turn>
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of the arteries, that the place be closed with old cotton: and that some coarse wool be placed above it.</start_of_turn
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And afterwards, it is cared for with dry physicians, who make meat to grow, and with plasters, until it is healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If during the operation blood flows out from an artery, then it must be immediately cauterized, or that the opening be closed with silk: and hold your hand tight, until the bleeding stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If nothing of these is present, then place over the place your finger, until the blood clots
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And bind the place with cold water or ice, until the pain subsides, and tighten according to what is necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And from this it is easier and more convenient to extract the artery, that is to say, that you cauterize the vein with this cautery which has two blades: and let the pain be similar to an almond
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	Indeed they are of much less pain than two blades.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are acute, like two blades, they prepare both with cold: and they do not bite the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	When therefore in the case of this, there is some extent of thickness, it is held in the hand of the fire, and is severed more quickly: with this therefore work is better in every way, and easier, and more convenient.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space which is between the two blades be equal to the thickness of a finger, after you have signed the two points with the cautery: and remove both the flames from the hand, until they reach the bone, and bite the vein in two places: so that it is elongated which is between the extremities of it
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For with this cautery the vessel is not closed tightly
Et haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	Concerning the care of acute and persistent eye tears.
Caput IIII.	Concerning the care of acute and persistent eye tears.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are persistent and there is discharge from the eyes which are above the external part of the head: there is no need for any medical treatment with doctors, and one should moisten the face of the patient so that it becomes red, and he feels himself walking like ants: and his eyes are swollen, wet, because they are corroded by the tears: and the palpebrae are inflamed from the intensity of the tears. Then the ancients said that this treatment would be performed for these operations and they called it Ense.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is necessary to pluck the hairs which are in front of his face for the patient
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three equal incisions on the forehead, according to the length of the forehead: and the length of the incision should be like two fingers, and one incision should be equidistant from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second according to the length of the lower part of the wound, and the third from the other side: and take care to avoid cutting any arteries which are on both sides: and extend your hand from the continuation of your two mandibles, and let the space between the incisions be as much as three fingers together: and prepare a sponge or dry cloth with which to absorb the blood.</start_of_turn>
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce the sponge or two acute extremities into the wound, whose following form is like this.</start_of_turn
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is from the temporal part, up to the second incision: and scrape with it the whole skin which is between the two incisions, with sponge, which is over the bone.</start_of_turn
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	And do the same from the middle incision up to the second incision.</start_of_turn
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract the sponge from this [wound], and introduce into the first incision once more an instrument which is called the cultellare acute, from one blunt end, not from the acute end.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its acute side towards the meat and the blunt side towards the bone: and press it in, until it reaches the middle seam: and cut through everything that hangs down from the head to the eyes: except that which appears from the skin itself
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do the same in the middle seam until another incision.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when blood has drained out an equal amount, express the place from coagulated blood clots
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then put in every incision a piece of old cotton, and put upon them soaked wool plugs in wine, and oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that there is no formation of a cold abscess.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day dissolve the ligament, and give a large infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the wound from its base, and leave the rest to heal: until it is healed
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	Concerning the care of acute tears and catarrh of the eyes from the inside of the head.
Caput V.	Chapter V
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When these acute, acrid, and severe tears occur: and you see their eyes extended, parched, and their aspect weakened: and the eyelids ulcerated, and hairs falling out from the eye, and acute pain in the depth of the head, causing pain and sneezing: then take away from these causes whatever does not cause tears, for tears alone are not sufficient.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	The best treatment for wounds is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	The best treatment for wounds is to scrape off the front of the wound from the patient.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make an incision in the middle of the front of the wound, or at the side somewhat by its width, and commence the incision from the left side towards the right side: and let the incision reach the bone: and keep your hand away from the wound which moves with chewing: until the bone is detected: and dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate the two lips of the wound with cotton wool or strips of linen
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind up above with sponges: and soak the sponges in wine and oil, so that no blood clots form
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you have finished with that, and you see that the wound is bleeding excessively: then it is necessary to anoint the bone until new flesh begins to grow in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	And then care for the wound with the care of drying which makes flesh grow: like if you took two parts wheat and four parts colophony and prepared from them a plaster: and administer it to the wound when the flesh is growing in it
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	And concerning the care of the wound in the autumn.
Caput VI.	(The provided text does not include the content of Chapter VI, so I am unable to translate it.)
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Every wound in the autumn falls into four kinds: either a mineral stone, or one like stone, such as iron and lead: or it is of plant origin, such as chickpea and beans: or it is a fluid substance, such as water, vinegar and blood, and things like these: or something that comes from an animal
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When a wound in the autumn falls upon a stone, or a kind of stone that does not come from the earth, and does not grow in the autumn, it exposes the autumn to the earth: if you wash away the stone, then distil from the oil of violets or sage something from the vinegar
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then manage the extraction of it [the foreign body], and make it firm with pressure, and apply ointment to the nostrils beside the pressure, after you have placed around the circumference of the ear a plug of linen or wool, and extended the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Many things proceed with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If they do not come out, then manage the extraction of it with force, that is, with fine needles: which are of this shape.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If they come out with the pressure, that is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then manage the extraction of it with a blunt needle of small diameter
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If they do not come out by this, then make a hole in the ear with a wire, and introduce the end of the wire into the opening of the ear many times, and apply ointment that is around the wire with fat, so that there is no air except for the wire: then draw it out with your hand with strong traction
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Many things proceed with this that we have said
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If it does not come out in this way: then take from barley or from vomit, that is, prepared gluten, with which ducks are caught, with which you should make the head slippery: and put it in the extremity of the radius after you have enclosed over the heel the middle of the bone downwards: then introduce it into the opening of the ear with ease, after you have evacuated the ear of moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If it does not come out with all that we have said, then prepare to break it, before the bone becomes stiff, or a spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the method of breaking is as follows: as with a phlebotomy of an infirm person in the first place in the skull: and draw out for him from the blood according to the measure of his courage.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make him sit down between your hands, and support his golden [ear] towards the upper part, and find the opening of the earwax in the root of the ear near the fatty substance in the depressed part: and let the opening be in the shape of a crescent, until you reach the stone. Then remove it with the instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then remove it with your hand as quickly as possible, and take care of it, until it heals
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If anything falling into the ear is from one of the grains which grow and swell: then carry out its extraction.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not yield to extraction, then grasp a thin, flexible sponge according to this shape
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And carry out the excision of that kind from the grains that fall into the ear, and do not make it so, when you think that one of them is already softened by the moisture of the ear, until you have put it against many hurdles: then remove it with hooks, or with fine tweezers, or with suction, as we have said, for its extraction alleviates it.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	However, in water which enters the ear, it is necessary that the patient perform a sneeze with the head downwards: and immediately pour a little warm fat over the ear: and let it rest upon that ear which is in the water
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If thereby it comes out, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then grasp many stones, according to the length of a finger, tight, soft, and warm them with fire: and let the patient put one of his ears into the opening of the ear: and let him spit out one of his toes from that side, and strike with another stone upon the stone which is in the ear
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Do not cease doing this until all the water is expelled
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And thus water goes out like this, so that you take from the charcoal or from the sponge one, and introduce its extremity one into the ear: and raise up the other extremity with fire, until most of it is consumed by fire.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	And do thus again with another sponge, and make this one much larger, until all the water has gone out: and draw out the same with a tube according as it is said in the stone
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction of an animal that is within the ear, if it is small of body, as a flea, and such as it, take care of it as I said in the explanation.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of great body, which appears to sense: then manage the extraction of it with the hand and with hooks: and thus it is easier for all who hold it in the ear
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	And when worms are generated in the ear, when you have treated it as we said in the explanation, and in the treatise on distillations, and it does not yield: then it is necessary to burn the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If anything appears there from the worms, then draw it out with the hand, or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If nothing appears there, then take a tube, which has a narrow lower part and a wide upper part: and introduce its lower extremity into the ear according to the capacity which the sick ear tolerates: then withdraw it with great suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do thus repeatedly until all the worms have gone out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If they do not obey you in their exit, then smear around the circumference of the tube with grease, as I said in the stone
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	When they do not go out as we said: then manage distillations which the ancient ones are experts in for the extermination of worms: and you will find it in the treatise on distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your effusion be such as that which flows out with oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose shape is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	Like wax, which is made from silver or gold, lower it tightly, in which there is a small hole, wide above
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let it be such that the driving force which is in the curvature of the tube is made of air centered
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a ball of cotton, and place it at the end of the tube: then pour oil, or gum, or whatever you wish of these medicines into the tube: and let it be in the ear: then insert the ball of cotton onto the cotton and compress it moderately, until the oil is driven into the curvature of the ear, and the patient feels it inside: and that which is poured into the ear, let it be already warmed with a little fire: and beware that nothing is distilled in it which is cold and wet: for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	As for the care of an inflamed auricle.
Caput VII.	(The provided text does not include any content for Chapter VII, so I am unable to translate the subsequent sentence.)
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	When some infants emerge from the mother's womb unpierced.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And sometimes it happens to some people that their earwax is in the ear from a wound, or from being born with it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this earwax, when it is in the deep part of the ear canal, does not follow usual methods: and when it happens at the outer part of the ear canal, and follows the usual methods.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which happens in the deep part of the ear, and which does not understand the aspect of it, is in many situations difficult to heal
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And as for that which follows the usual methods, it is necessary to put the ear of the patient in the sun, and to press in it: then if you see the apparent earwax, open it with a fine spatula, whose form is this which follows, let its extremity be in which there is a slight width, whose part is acute: and the rest of the spatula should be soft on both sides: so that it does not hurt the ear
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If there is a swelling from meat that has risen in the ear: then hold one finger under the ear, and press with ease until the whole flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the swelling is deep in the ear: then take a slender needle, thread it, and burnish it with fire: then pass it into the ear meat
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you feel swelling with pain, which an infirm person has with difficulty hearing, try to open it with ease: and be careful, lest you damage the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put into the ear a wick according to the quantity of the hole you have opened in the eardrum: do this for a few days, until you are certain of the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take a wick, soak it in rosewater, sprinkle it over charcoal that has been ground to powder, and use it like that.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you have put the wick in the ear and it has become loose: then you must take out the wick, and put in another one, which you will put in a vessel containing rosewater, until the swelling has subsided: then care for it until it has healed
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If blood flows: then immerse a sponge or bandage in cold water, and put it on the ear: and use the rest of the treatment which expels the blood stated in the treatise on distillation.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Note: The provided text does not include information regarding the care of the eyes, so I am unable to translate this portion of the sentence.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These are the Althelis that happen in the eyes, when they are wet, and when they are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	You must hold them with pins or with a finger, and press them out with the thumb from their roots
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place above the wound a piece of sponge.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If blood flows from the wound, then cauterize it with a fine lancet.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	Cautering is better after the incision has been made.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	Many things return when something remains at its root
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	When cauterized with fire, those roots burn and do not return
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	Regarding the care of the large palpebrae of the eye
Caput IX.	Chapter IX
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Many things happen in the palpebrae of the eye that assimilate with Crandinis in its hardness and its roughness, and because of this it is called Grand: and it is the accumulation of thick moisture in the upper and lower palpebrae.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation is thus done in the eye, as you will consider, if there is a Grand proceeding from the palpebra, which appears from the palpebra and moves to all parts, and this is easy to do
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Find thus above the wound along its width
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape away from all around with ease, until it comes loose
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend the wound with a thread, and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If it is not prepared for cutting, namely when you penetrate the palpebra with an incision that is too small, then it will be harmful to the patient in some way
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the incision is large: then gather it with a suture: and care for it until it heals
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, it will not cause any harm from it
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	The ointment restores itself and nourishes the body.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	If it is large, it hangs downwards into the inner part of the ear, then I reverse the eyelid and suspend the large quantity with a thread: for besides that, I do not approve of incision, and I press from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	For if the eyelid is elongated by incision, that does not harm in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then I wash out the eye after the incision with salt water: and I care for the place with that which nourishes, until the patient is healed
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	About the care of the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	The secret is a kind of grease which is generated in the upper eyelid: and most of all it happens in children: and it weighs down the eyes of them, and causes them to be blind in the mornings, and they are not able to see the light of the sun, because the tears run down their faces always, and because of that the tears lie over their face always, and over their eyes they are always wet, and their eyelids are always soft because of the swelling: and the prominence of the secret is seen in the eye, and when you press with your fingers, you feel the secret between your fingers.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the way to treat it is for the patient to put his head on your lap
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a piece of linen and prepare it with oil, and make from it a circle according to the quantity which contains the secret from all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then put it on the eye, and press with your fingers from all sides, so that the secret is collected in the middle of the circle
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that humidity with the spatula some slippery matter that has come out during the incision, and do not make a larger wound than that which is made in phlebotomy in depth
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Either it is necessary to find the whole skin, until it reaches Axirnath, in various positions, or Axirnath proceeds from a fissure following the shape of a white frothy substance.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Extract the blood from the hand with the towel which you have plunged between your fingers towards the outside: and you will turn your hand to the right and left, until it is scattered: and be careful, lest you should pierce the thumb, lest you should reach the eye, and cause damage to it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If, however, you do not see Axirnath at the beginning of the fissure, you add in the fissure a little with ease, until Axirnath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract the blood, as we have said before
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse the towels in vinegar and water, and place them over the place, and bind them with threads.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And from men there are some who wipe away the salt, and put it into the hollow of the fissure, that the moisture which remains from that humidity may liquefy
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If, however, there should happen in the place of the wound a soft swelling, then take care of it with cold packs but soothing, until it is healed
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	Regarding the methods of treating the eye, that is, when the eyelid is softened, from which it results that the eye becomes red as it should not be.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When the hair of the eyelashes has been added beyond its normal course beneath the natural hair, and is excessive: then it does harm the eye, and makes the methods of treatment of ailments such as excessive tears, the softening of the eyelids, and pus, the cause of the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	The eye inflammation is treated in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with acute medicine, as has been mentioned in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or by incision and stitching of the Ataxmir
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by means of needles, as I shall say
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You must place the head of the patient in your lap
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then grasp the eyelid of the eye with your left hand
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it grasps it, that is good
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: insert the needle through the skin at the lower part of the eyelid, and pass the needle along with the thread to the upper part of the eyelid, and grasp the needle with the forceps.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find under the added eyelashes inside the eye, with the tip of the needle at the greater lachrymal gland until it reaches the smaller lachrymal gland
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then draw out the thread, and put under the eyelid a small piece of cotton or gauze: then suture over the eyelid with a burn, which should be like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, you must know that the figure should be made according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: for this varies in different people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	From this it is evident that the quantity which should be incisions from the eyelid is great, according to the quantity which is softened by the eyelid itself.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then when the eyelashes are found between two lines which you have marked, and you have reached from the greater lachrymal gland to the smaller lachrymal gland, and there is one suture close to the natural eyelashes, like the thickness of a radius
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of the two skin angles.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then excise the whole area
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then join together the two lips with a suture, using a needle and a fine thread: and drain the blood, and make fast what has protruded from the threads above the two eyebrows, with some useful substance, if you wish to do so: or if not, do not worry
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then remove the suture and the thread for three days, or four: then care for it
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, remove the swelling without a suture, and care for it with that which dries and contracts it
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelids swell up at the sealing of the wound and the gathering of its parts: but this is better in the future
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	Such is the way of treating Ataxmir, as the ancients taught us
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	But indeed, in this is solicitude over the sick person, and it is from a good operation, and not from fear.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another way is in Ataxmir also: and it is that there should appear on the eyelid a sign like the figure of a myrtle leaf, as we have narrated.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then elevate the eyelid with three separate hooks, or gathered together, according to the shape of this sign, and then cut away what is superfluous with small scissors, according to this shape, with equality of the incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If, however, it is not possible to hold the hook, and it does not agree: then grasp the point where the thread is and insert it in the middle of the sign: and insert another thread near the greater lacrimal gland, and a third thread near the lesser lacrimal gland: and join together the threads between your fingers with equality
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand equally high; and elevate the skin above that which is signed for the wound, as we have said.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join together two lips of the wound with sutures: and care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If there should happen to be swelling at the incision or tear: stop that swelling with an ointment, and do the same with things like it, from settled unguents.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And when the eyelashes also swell, as their hairs are turned inward.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is therefore necessary to use that which we mentioned concerning the incision: but the suture of both is an artificial one.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	About care for Ataxmir with a dog.</start_of_turn
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is, that you cover the eyelashes, and split the tear which is inside, as I have said.</start_of_turn
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two needles, or two thin sticks: of which the length is according to the length of the eyelashes, and the width of them is less than the width of the pupil: and put the thread through at the extremities of both from both parts where you hold the thread.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then join together each one with some substance over that which remains from the eyelash of the eye, and string two needles from both parts firmly, and let go of it every few days.</start_of_turn
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	The skin will therefore be stretched out to die, and will become dark, and will decay, until it falls away by itself.</start_of_turn
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If therefore it is delayed, then cut it away with scissors.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When the tissue is firm, raise the eyelids: the hairs do not pierce them.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	This is the shape of two nails which you make according to this figure and the quantity in length and breadth.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Regarding the elevation of hairs piercing the eye with the needle
Caput XII.	Chapter XII
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in this is that you take a fine needle and introduce it into the silk thread, which is soft
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then you join the extremities of it and make knots at each end with a fine knot: and let the length of the thread be as much as a palm of the hand
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then you make another fine thread and pass it under this one in a short space, and knot the extremities of it if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then you place the patient's head in your hand, and it should be near the cheek so that the operation is clear: because the operation is slight, or even almost negligible
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with the thread at the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly, until you have pulled out the natural hair
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw out the hair until above the thread: and introduce into the thread the tip of the hair: if there is one, or two, or three, not more
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand away with it, until the hair with the thread comes out of the eyelid with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If, however, the thread is drawn out and the hair does not come out with it: draw out the thread to the lower part, with the thread which you made in it, until the thread comes out of the upper hole, and you see the eye: then you draw out the thread and the needle, and close the eye: and leave the eye closed for two days, or three, until the hair has grown back in its place, and has become stronger than before
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, either associate with it a long hair from natural hair, and elevate with it: or dismiss it, until it extends after space, and then elevate it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	If the hair is short, either join to it a long hair from natural hair and elevate with it: or dismiss it until it extends after space, and then elevate it.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this happens to the eye, it is called the Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	This phenomenon is either natural or accidental
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Accidental, therefore, is from the consolidation of a wound, or a section, or a cauterization, and the like
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the mode of operation in this is that you find the consolidation, and separate the edges, and place between them a bandage of lint, and bind them together, until it heals
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And do not use in the care of it those things which irritate and harden: for if you do, the Alxatrati will deteriorate more than before: rather use those things which soften, such as barley-straw: and embrocate with water in which aloes are boiled, seed of flax: and oil of thyme, which is liquefied with some oil: and mix with it the bandage, and care for it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your skill in care is such that you can prepare everything with ingenuity, so that it does not harden, according to the form which it had at first
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this, indeed, is the operation which we have mentioned, is not without some rectification of the Alxatrati, so that it does not return to its original form
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Regarding the care of the Alxatrati which happens in the lower eyelid, and is a wrinkling or contraction upwards to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 123.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	The one that is below [the head], which is truly called Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	It is accidental from a wound, or a fissure, or a burn, and things like these
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way to operate in this is that you take hold of the needle, which has a doubled thread, and pass it under the flesh, and make it penetrate from the left lacrimal gland until it reaches the right lacrimal gland, until the thread passes through both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the flesh upwards with the needle, and cut the thread with a wide knife.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the figure of the eyelashes returns according to what is required, it is good.</start_of_turn>
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take hold of the radix, and put it in the fissure, and close it with it: and find two incisions on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the two ends of the incisions meet at two angles: until when they gather together they make the figure of these letters, and this is the Greek laudation.</start_of_turn>
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then take away the flesh by the amount which is the width of its apex below, from that which follows the eyelash.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separated parts: sew them with a thread.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them as we have said, of soothing medicines, and ointments, until they are healed.</start_of_turn
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if Alxatrati occurs from a fissure, and suture, or burn: then you must find a flat wound under the eyelashes, even as before.</start_of_turn
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with a linen strip, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And thus the sum of the discourse concerning the care of Alxatrati is this: when it is above or below, that is, when it is in this operation, it is done in the form of Alxatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For itself, it is a matter of various forms: and the skillful artist prepares the wit with whatever method he deems suitable, until he makes the figure resemble the natural form, or almost so, even the patient himself, according as it agrees with the operation and the instruments in their various arrangements
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Concerning the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva, or the cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	When this happens to many people, it is necessary to consolidate the upper eyelid with the white of the eye, and to keep it away from its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	It is necessary therefore to introduce the end of the radius under the eyelid, and to lift it up: or to stretch it out with a hook: then cut through the adhesion with a fine spatula, which should not be as acute as the incision of the spatula, but rather obtuse and gentle: so that it does not irritate the patient during the operation, and that the spatula be easily withdrawn, and that the eye be healed with its own sharpness: and that your incision be such that you seem to be merely scraping away the adhesion with ease, until the eyelid returns to its natural shape, and the adhesion is completely healed
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour water salt into the eye, when the eye has bled: or distill it from the sieve which you have made, from zinc dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a linen strip: and place over the eye lanolin infused with alum: and on the third day use the sieve and solid dressings, until it is healed
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	On the incision of the nail and the elevation of the carnis lachrymarum.
Caput XVI.	On the incision of the nail and the elevation of the carnis lachrymarum.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	You know that the nail is according to two modes.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is fleshy: and it is similar to soft wax, delicate
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to frozen white moisture: which when it touches iron, or when you grasp it with a hook, it is broken off and does not remain in it
