Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both of these kinds do not begin, except from the greater lacrimal gland, until it has proceeded slowly, until it covers the useful thing, and excludes light and the movement of the eye
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the manner of working in its incision is: as you place your sickly head in your lap
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open its eyes, and elevate the eyelid with your hand
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then gather the nail with a hook of a few doubloons, and stretch it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then grasp the point with a needle, and introduce it into the hair of the horse, and blood, or fat: and let the thread be strong, and double the end of the needle thin, and fix it in the middle of the nail: and pierce the nail with the needle, and ligate the nail with the thread, and stretch the nail upwards: and remove the outer layer of the nail following the pupil, as if you were shaving it with the nail until the last of it
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	And then cut the remainder in the root of the lacrimal gland with fine scissors, or with small forceps: and release the natural carnis lachrymalis, so that it does not cause excessive flow of tears from its incision
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	When the nail extends with a single loop: or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it is to be pared back with a blunt spatula, whose form is like this
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	Beware, lest you touch the sensitive membrane of the cornea with the spatula, and cause a rupture, and perforate the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then, after the incision, pour some powdered salt or mix it from barley flour, and leave it in for until tomorrow.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it as is necessary, until it is healed
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the nail is neither sensitive nor does it contain marrow within, and if it does not bleed, then it is to be treated with many medicines, and it will heal as I have mentioned before
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish to make an incision, then open the eye of the patient, and take out the sharp and fine spatula, of moderate sharpness, according to this form.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And remove the nail from above with care and precision
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it is becoming pale and brittle, and that it is cracking, and that it has split in two, then wash it out of your eye with barley flour or with red ochre or with salt: and instill the eye with something until tomorrow.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat the operation until it is complete
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Except that there is a soft callus in the eye: then leave it in place, and care for the callus until it is healed
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation above with care until it is healed
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	The swelling of the tear gland, if it causes great pain in the eye, is to be suspended with a loop, and a portion of it is to be cut away: and do not make the incision at the end, lest you cause the tears to leak out
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then stay in the tear duct with a red sponge, or made from spongewort, until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	Since the incision of the Algardene, and the native tissue in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.</start_of_turn>
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Sometimes in the eyes of men red flesh is composed, or superposed, until it covers the pupil, or approaches, or tightens over the eyelids, and perhaps turns the eyelids outwards: and it absorbs the scarlet of the rose petal.</start_of_turn>
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation in this also is that you put your hand in his head.</start_of_turn
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes, and collect all the flesh with the needles which agree with that: and hold that with a forceps or by hand.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh first, until you finish all of it with the chisel.</start_of_turn
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And burn from the eye, so that you do not damage it during the operation: and let your incision be as we have said in the incision of the nail: or with small forceps, with which you collect the fat, as it will appear after this chapter.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When you have finished your incision, and have moved all the Algardene, then put the eye out from salt mixed with sand: or distill into it some powdered red ochre, and similar things from the physicians of corrosive matters: and put over the eye a bandage of cotton with alum or gypsum: so as to secure it from the heat of the afterburn.</start_of_turn
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If anything remains of the Algardene, and you dominate the warm blood, and time the fever: then let go of the eye, and care for it as it lies down the fever.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat over the said part with the operation until it is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	Do the same with the added flesh as is done with the natural flesh of the eye of that kind
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	It is necessary to know, that other treatments for all diseases of the eye are excluded from this operation, both natural and accidental, operating with the instruments: and do not introduce your hand into any part of the operation, until you have verified that the limb can tolerate this operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	On the collection of the fat from the eye
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	The fat is a red wax which covers the eye, and hinders its operation: and it weakens the eye with the length of the days.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore you must first consider, if the eye in which the fat is, is strong, and is not in any other illness besides the fat: then collect the fat from it
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is necessary to command the patient to keep his head in your lap
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those waxes with one or two hooks, according to your prudence: and let the hook be of fine wire, doubled, according to this form, or two hooks graduated in one body, according to this form.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then collect with fine forceps those waxes with diligence, and wash away the blood an hour after an hour, until you have verified that those waxes have been removed from the eye, and have dissolved: and beware lest you wound the eye with the edges of the spatula
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your operation be in the middle of the day before the sun, and be firm in your operation so that you do not injure anything except the waxes.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	When you have finished [administering the medicine], then distill into the eye a little of the green or red unguent: so that its sharpness may eat away what remains from the wound.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	When it is not possible to collect all of that in an hour, then smear the eye with this [ointment], which will soothe the pain of the eye: and leave it for a few days, until the pain has subsided. And keep it away from heat: then repeat the procedure above until the eye is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	This is the form of the scissors.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	On the reduction of the Arissa to the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Physicians call the Arissa Fistula which is treated with cautery, or with acute medicine which burns, as she has previously mentioned
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	If it does not heal, then there is no skill in it: except that you should find the abscess at its origin and evacuate all the moisture which is in it and pus, until the bone is clean
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When the bone is thus cleansed, and the cavity is filled with corruption or blackness, then seal it up with an instrument of this shape
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	This is called the Asperation of the head
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Make it from iron without a handle, and let its head be round like an egg, which is pierced with the point of a lime-stone, or with the point of an awl or with a fine point: and put it on the place of the corrupted bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then rotate it between your fingers, and press your hand lightly, until you know that the corruption is gone: and do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with astringent substances.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If therefore the locus is solidified and a carbuncle arises in it, and the course of the disease is severed: and it remains for forty days, and does not recur, and does not abate, and does not happen in that place again: then you know that the patient is already healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	If not, then it is not in that part, except to reduce the swelling to the size of a pinhole, according to this fashion.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is thus, that you perceive the second bone with iron, or with acute medicine: and when it is detected, then grasp firmly according to this fashion, whether the outer extremity be of iron, triangular: and its wood be extended as far as the extremity, like urine
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place that upon the bone itself: and let it be near the tear-duct: and extend your hand from the eye a little.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then withdraw your hand with the instrument until it penetrates the bone, and feel that it is infirm: thereby that you will know that the wound has come out through that, when you keep your hand on your nose
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then restore the place with astringent medicines that exude, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When therefore a carbuncle arises in the flesh, and the place is solidified: then the matter which flowed outwards returns to the nose: thus indeed is it easier for it to be over the infirmity
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	On the reduction of the swelling of the eye.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye swells up completely, and does not yield to any document, neither by diminution: then it is necessary to dissolve the swelling: then perform a phlebotomy: afterwards apply warm compresses to the sky without making an incision, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then apply upon the eye a unguent made from acacia, aloe, oil, and ochre.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind over the eye a patch with many feathers
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And as for the feathers, take fine wool, many of them, and fold every feather over four: make many of them: then put one over the other, as many as are needed for the eye: then bind over them with a strong cloth
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	Do it again with gentle pressure without cutting
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the swelling, and keep the eye closed day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If, however, the ligament is again softened, then it must be bound much more tightly: then remove the ligament after a day and a night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If thus you see the eye again redden, it is good: and if not, then bind over the eye again, the feathers, and the cloth, and the swelling, until it is healed.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	About the incision of the edge of the eye
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When it happens that the ligament is ruptured in the eye, then it comes out and proceeds outside the eyelids like a grain of sand, and is injured in the shape of a man because of this, and one must cut it: then the operation in this is as follows: and it is that you insert a needle into the root of the ligament from the lower part to the upper part
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then insert another needle into which is double thread from the lachrymal part, and make it penetrate: and remove the first needle according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the place of the double thread, and bind with it the part of the ligament around the needle: and bind it tightly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then extract the [pointed object] and place above the eye a soaked lamb's wool in the albugine or on the wound: and let it go until the thread comes out with you.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the eye with this, which soothes it, until the wound is healed.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And when you have tied the thread from every part with a circle of cloth, until you have added the eye a great prominence
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then prick with a fine needle under the eyelid, which will reach the depth of the eye, and cover with moisture the albumin, and let the eye go down, and insert immediately: then tighten it up, until it is healed
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	On the care of the Alcomnatum.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This ailment which is called Alcomnatum, is not anything other than health which is gathered in the eye, like water that descends and is not the ailment itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the way to treat it is to make the patient sit on a prepared seat, or direct him to sit
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take his head in your hands from two parts and move it until you feel health going down to the lower parts of your eyes
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then fix it, and do not let it go down, and close your eyes: and the patient will see as well as before: and if it does not go down below, you know that it is water
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	If however the descent of health is not prepared with this which we have said, then make the patient sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a fine needle and find with it above the cornea the thickness of the conjunctiva with the tunica cornea in a circle, until the health comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When the patient departs, then distill into the eye a warm water in which was mixed honey: or water in which you have cast barley groats and honey: then care for it with the remaining treatment until it is healed.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	Concerning the care of water which descends into the eye, or a cataract.
Caput XXIII.	This section of the text is not included in the provided text, so I am unable to translate it.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have spoken of ten kinds of water which are useful in eye-drops, and which are declared and explained by the prescriber, then take that which is most suitable for the healing.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then you must make the patient sit between your hands square, opposite the light, near the lamp: and bind his eye firmly: then take your right hand, if the eye in which the water is, is the left eye: or take your left hand, if the eye is the right.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take your right hand almond-shaped, if the eye is the left: or your left hand, if the eye is the right
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the tip of the almond near the edge of the pupil over the smaller part of the apparent white of the eye: then push the almond with force: and you will draw back your hand until it penetrates the membrane of the eye: and you will feel that the almond has reached the bottom of the eye
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that the measure of the journey of the almond be to the depth, the measure of the space from the pupil to the end of the black part: and is the rim of the eye
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see this in the pupil of the eye by the clarity of the cornea.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then put the almond in the place where the water is
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then let the lower part of the wound be closed after the upper part.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If water descends immediately, the patient will suffer great damage above that which opened wide immediately, and the wound will be swollen in his eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If water descends again, then take hold of the wound a second time, before the swelling comes out.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When it has subsided, and does not ascend: then draw out the swelling with ease: and you will rotate your hand slowly.</start_of_turn>
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve in water something of clear salt of the seed: and bathe with it when the eye is closed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then put over the eye the whole bandage, or wool soaked in warm oil, and alum: and tie with it the sound eye.</start_of_turn
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	But we, and those who are of our time, put upon it a coarse plaster with alum.</start_of_turn
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If it does not obey you, the swelling at the entrance of the eye because of its hardness, because it is from a man whose eye is hard and cold: then you must take hold of the sponge, which is called Alberid, which has this shape.</start_of_turn
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Pull it out with the sponge together with it, and do not twist your hand in the hole: and do not omit that you make a little opening for the swelling.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the swelling, as we have said.</start_of_turn
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And in addition to this, prepare for the patient a comfortable bed, made in the center, in which he may sleep on his back in a dark room: and be kept away from all movement, and from coughing: and give him food that softens the nature of his condition: and do not move his head to the right or to the left at all.</start_of_turn
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the ligament be according to its usual position until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	And then dissolve it in that dark place, and experience its effect: and make it help the matter
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	And reduce the ligament until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it must not be done in the hour of treatment, or immediately after incision: but it must be done at some other time, for otherwise the water will ascend too quickly through the swelling area
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If however a cold abscess occurs: then it must be dissolved before the seventh day: and rectify it with that which settles the abscess, until it is settled: then dissolve its cause, and put on the oral bandage which should regulate its effect under that place for a few days, while it still exists in that dark place
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	And then gradually depart from that place and return to its own case.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know this, that in the field of surgery the pupil must not be absent for a long time: for otherwise he will hear about the operation
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed some of those from Alayrach have told us that in Alayrach a great magdanz was pierced, from which water suggets.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	But verily no one in our land has done this: neither have I read of it in any of the ancient books: and it is possible that it is new
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of the spirits of magdanz, as they remain over those who do not know them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be of their own air: and let their extremities be like those of a triangle with a hooked base, and acute ends
Formae magda.	The shapes of magdanz
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the care of the native flesh in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	When the native flesh of the nose has been cut by various instruments, there is something which is absorbed by the scorpion's feet: from this there is a cancerous tumor, a stone, and flesh of a dusky color: from this there is what is soft flesh, not of a dusky color.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	Therefore, in that which there is soft flesh, not fraudulent, neither cancerous, you must make the diseased part rest between your hands facing outwards, and open the nose through its opening, and push out the tongue into those flesh: then draw them out to the exterior, and cut away what you have seen with a fine sharp instrument from one side until you know that all the flesh has been removed
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	If anything remains of that from whose excision is impossible: then cut it away with a fine instrument with ease, until nothing remains of it
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If blood therefore dominates, or if there is a thick clot: then oppose it with something which will stop it: or with bad clots, then burn them with the cautery, until the blood is stopped, and remove all the flesh.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then throw into the nose after the incision of the flesh, water or liquid.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If the nose is opened, and there is humidity coming from it until the palate, then you know that it is healed
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If indeed the humidity does not penetrate, according to what is proper, then you know that there is still native flesh in the upper bones of the nose, which has not been removed with the instrument during the incision
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Therefore you must introduce a thread of fine caliber which has some thickness to it, and tie a knot in it: and place between every knot the quantity of digit, or less: and cause the diseased part to bleed, by sending one end of the thread into the nose with a hook, or in any other way that is possible for you to do after you have made it similar to a burn: and draw out the foul matter until it comes out to the outside, and go out from under the chin.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	Many do like him in schools, just as the young Attomus: and it is easy for him who wishes.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place two extremities of the child, one that projects over the nose and the other that remains in the nose
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	And hold the flesh closed with knots that are in the limb.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is closed with knots in the limb
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then draw out the thread: and put in the nose after draining blood the amount that you drank in the Egyptian unguent: do this three days, or more, until the unguent has eaten away all that remains of the flesh
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then put in the end of the matter in the nose a lead cannula for a few days, until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If, however, treatment is required that demands it, use it.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For the head wound, when oil and other medicines are distilled in the nose, do this from silver or from lead: and let it be like fine pepper, open like a conch, and similar in size
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed cannula, like a tube
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	The tube of the instrument for making the head wound is full, closed: which has a handle in its rear, with which you grasp it, when you heat it in oil, or when you wish to put some ointment in it, and in the fluxes.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	This is the form of the instrument
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	Of the care of the Thelulean nose.
Caput XXV.	Head wound.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Many are born in the extremity of the Thelulean nose, and grow large, and increase with days, until the wound becomes like its appearance
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And therefore it is necessary, that in the commencement of its apparition, it should penetrate all its tissues.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place above it, or cauterize, or apply a burning medicine which is in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If, however, its incision is delayed until it has increased in size, then consider whether it is stony, hard, dark brown, insensitive: then do not touch it with the iron: for the tumor is cancerous
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	Many therefore are the waters which issue from the tumor, which is the cause of great malice above that which it has had
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the tumor is soft to the touch, not dark brown, and the waters which issue from its incision are possible throughout all of it, then evacuate the patient, and cut it without fear, without pain: and care for the place which exudes and contracts, until it is healed
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	Concerning the suture of the nose, and the lip, and the ear.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You know that when resolution of continuity takes place in some cartilaginous matters, it causes little in that operation, except in some men.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore, when anything has happened from this, that you consider whether it is a wound which has adhered with its blood: and then join the two edges of the wound with suture: then care for it until it is healed
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the resolution of continuity of the lips has already been separated, and each part is sound: then it is necessary to strip away every part from its apparent skin, until the blood clots
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then join the two lips with suture, and string them, and smear above it the blood of a dragon, and olive oil, finely ground: and place above the ground the edge of a plaster of Paris, and any other solid plaster: and leave it bound for two days, or three
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then loosen the thing itself, and change the medicine: and discharge the thing, until the threads are severed by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the thing with the unguent, until it is healed.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The way of stitching is that you gather the solution of continuity together, or with an obtuse angle, as we say in the gut suture: or gather the solution together with the thread, as you have been told.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	About the extraction of lip knots.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.</start_of_turn>
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people suffer from swelling in the insides of their lips caused by hard bumps resembling grass seeds: and some of them are small, and some are large.</start_of_turn
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore it is necessary to cover the lips, and find over every bump of it, and suspend it with a thread, and cut it off from all sides.</start_of_turn
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then place the place after the incision with a little sponge, until the blood is clotted.</start_of_turn
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then bandage it with vinegar, and care for the place with that which has styptic properties, until the wound is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	About the incision of a natural carbuncle on the gum.</start_of_turn
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.</start_of_turn
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Many are born on the gum of meat which the ancients called abuluss.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	It is necessary therefore to suspend the thing with a thread: or to grasp the thing with forceps, and cut the thing at its root, and let the blood run, or the discharge.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then put over the place a little sponge, or other powdered astringents.</start_of_turn
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	If it returns again to its original state after treatment, for it returns often, then cut it again in the second instance and cauterize it: for it does not return after cauterization.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	Concerning the reason for teeth decaying with iron.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	When they gather together on the surfaces of teeth from both inside and outside, and between the gums, their outer layer becomes rough, dark, and sometimes they decay, and black spots appear, until this corruption reaches the gum and causes the teeth to become loose.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	It is necessary therefore that you make the patient sit upright between your hands, and hold his head in your lap, and move the tongue and the teeth, in which you see the outer layer, until something remains of it, and in the same way make of black spots, and yellowness, and brittleness, and other things until they disappear.</start_of_turn
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If therefore you remove what is in the beginning of the cause, that is good: and if not, then repeat the treatment on it every other day, second day, and third day, until finally the study of the thing is completed.</start_of_turn
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	You know that teeth need different rasps of various forms, many figures: according to the preparation of your operation: because the rasp with which the tooth is rasped from the lower part is different from the rasp with which the teeth are rasped between, according to other forms.</start_of_turn
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these forms of rasps are prepared for you, which you will use.</start_of_turn
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	Concerning the extraction of wisdom teeth.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.</start_of_turn
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary that the dentist remove the tooth from its pain with all his skill, and afterwards to eradicate it.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	It is not in his power to remedy the pain of the tooth when it is eradicated: for it is a sublime substance. Therefore, when there is no other remedy for the eradication of the tooth, it is necessary to eradicate it, even if the patient dislikes it, in order to establish his health and give him confidence concerning the painful tooth.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	Many patients dislike the patient when he eradicates the tooth, thinking that he thereby removes the cause of the pain. But the pain does not vanish until the diseased tooth is eradicated.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	We do not wish to be like those who are skilled in phlebotomy, but are ignorant of surgery.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When it is certified to you that the tooth is painful itself, then it is necessary to sacrifice around the tooth with sponges, in which there is some virtue, until the gum is severed from all sides: then move the tooth with your fingers, or with fine forceps at first slowly, until you have crushed it
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place the large forceps in a good place, and hold the patient's head between your knees: which you have done well, because it will not move. Then extract the tooth according to its right position, so that you do not break it
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If it does not come out, then grasp some of these instruments and introduce them under it from all sides with ease, and try to move it, as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If, however, the tooth is perforated or corroded: then it is necessary to fill the hole with cloth: and tie it with the end of a fine thread, so that it does not break in the hour of your haste with the forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And it is necessary to be skilled in the art of scarification around the gums from all sides much.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	Be strong, and guard your fortitude, lest you be overcome by it, and let some remain of it to return upon the infirm from that which is greater than its first pain.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	Do not do that which the unskilled do, the phlebotomists of your faction, in their frenzy, and do not be overbold in its eradication, for we give you that which we have mentioned
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	Many indeed make them grow worse upon great men's diseases, which are more difficult to cure, and leave none of them, or take away some of them: or take away the whole with some of the teeth of the jaw. Thus have we seen many do
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then it is to be joined after its eradication with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If blood flows from any place (for many indeed flow from its place), then there is something from the limb which must be taken away with it: and if this does not suffice, burn it if it does not yield the limb.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The tweezers which you must use to grasp the tooth in the first place are long-necked and have short handles, thick, so that they do not bend when pressure is put upon them: they are like robust handles of tongs, until when they are bound with the tooth, they do not bite themselves, nor bend: short-necked, and are made of iron or hammered out of sheet iron, directed towards the extremity: and in their extremities are teeth, some of which enter into some of them, and bind the constriction loosely, moderately strong
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And when the extremities become like the beak of a bird called a ciconia, and are strong constrictions.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	Of the eradication of teeth, and the extraction of fractured jaw bones.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 1.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When the tooth remains after eradication, and it breaks something, then it is necessary to apply butter to the surrounding area for one or two days until it softens: then introduce the forceps into the cavity, or graspers: whose extremities absorb the hairs which are called ciconia.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	This sentence describes the use of forceps in dental treatment. The forceps are used to grasp and remove any remaining tooth fragments or other debris from the treated area.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	The handles of the forceps are made like a file or like an awl
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, these do not suffice to remove the tooth, then it is necessary to cut above the root and remove the entire pulp, and introduce the small chisel, which is called a chisel, whose shape is like this
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	The handles of the forceps are short and thick: and they must not be wet, lest they break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If the root comes out through that, it is good: and if not, it is necessary to cut again with other instruments whose shape is like these
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The first triangle-shaped handle has some thickness in it
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The triangle-shaped handle is thin
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	It is also used with this instrument which has two branches, whose shape is like this
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and instruments which go before the teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	It is necessary to grasp with this instrument which absorbs a large single hair, of this shape, triangle-shaped handle twisted, which has some thickness, so that it does not break: and it must not be wet.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	You know that there are many instruments for teeth: and similarly the rest of the instruments do not agree: and a prudent artisan, skilled in his art, will himself find the best instrument for each operation and for the nature of the disease.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species
Caput XXXII.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Since they are instruments of ailments of which the ancients did not speak, because of the diversity of their species
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If the tooth is dense, from which a part is broken off and affects the tongue, it is necessary to ligate it until the sharpness of that fracture is removed, and it is equalized: and it is flattened, and does not affect the tongue, nor corrupt the speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On the Retension of Teeth with Wire.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When it happens that the front teeth are fractured by percussion or in any other way, and the patient cannot bite without pain: it is necessary to ligate them with wire. For silver is easily tarnished, and putrefies after a few days: but gold never changes.</start_of_turn>
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the wire be of medium thickness and of such a size as to grasp between the teeth.</start_of_turn
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the form of the ligation is that you take the wire and pass its double through between two healthy teeth: then you tie it with two extremities of the wire between the loose teeth, whether one or more, until you have secured it until you reach the healthy tooth of the other side.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	And do it again until you reach the part from which you began: and keep your hand steady with wisdom, so that it does not slip: and make your ligation as close as possible to the root of the teeth, so that it does not move.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	And cut off the excess of the wire with shears: and join each end together and bind them easily: and hide them between the healthy tooth and the moved tooth, so that it does not affect the tongue: then release the tension as much as remains.</start_of_turn
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If however it is resolved or fractured, ligate it with another wire and keep it stable in this way for a whole time.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	This is the shape of a tooth, and the figure of the return of two sound teeth and two moving teeth, like water.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	When one tooth, or two after a fall or inflammation in their places, returns as we have said, and remains: this does not happen except by a skillful and experienced artificer
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	When some bone or cartilage has been adjusted: and it is made like the shape of a tooth, and is placed in its place, from which the tooth is supported and attached, as we have said: and it remains, and serves its purpose for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	Concerning the incision of the ligament which happens under the tongue, and which hinders speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	When this ligament which happens under the tongue is cut, it is either natural, as it is born with man, or accidental, from an injury which has healed badly
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation in this case is to open the mouth of the patient in your hand, and lift up his tongue: then cut through that ligament of nerves across the breadth, until the tongue is freed from its retention
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is something hard and nodular in this, and if that comes from the consolidation of an injury: then pull out that piece of bone, and find that across the breadth, until you cut through the ligament and the knot is freed
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Take care that there be no perforation in the depth of the flesh, and that you do not cut an artery there, and that blood flow does not increase
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then wash the wound with rosewater, or with vinegar, or with cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then put under the tongue a piece of linen cloth, which will hold the patient throughout the night: so that it does not solidify again
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	If blood flow increases, then put a plug over the wound.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If blood flow increases, then cauterize the wound with a lancet, which is suitable for this purpose. Then care for the wound as usual until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	Of the extraction of the ranula which forms under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 5.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	When there occurs under the tongue a small swelling which absorbs the small ranula, hindering the natural action of the tongue: and perchance it may grow so large that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	The operation for this is to open the mouth wide open: and consider the swelling.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If there is blood of a red or black colour, hard, which does not yield to the touch of the infirm: do not touch it, for it is cancer
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	If it inclines towards white, in which there is moisture, then throw into it a fine sponge, and press it down with the thumb, and remove it from all sides
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If in the hour of your operation blood flow increases, then put over it a plug of felt, until the bleeding stops: then return to your operation, until you have removed it with its complement
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then it shall be bound up with vinegar and salt: and care for it with the usual treatment which is suitable for this, until it heals
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	Of the treatment of the swelling of two amygdals.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 6
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	When there occur between the tonsils, that is, the glands which resemble almonds, which occur outside: and which we call two Amygdals: when you have cured these as we said in the previous section, and they do not heal, then consider this
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If there is a hard abscess, of a dark colour, with little sensation: then do not touch it with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	If it is red in colour, and its root is large: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing the flow of blood, rather let it alone until it matures
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	Then either pierce it through, or let it rupture by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	If it is white in colour, round, and its root is thin: then it must be cut through
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation in it is as follows: consider before your operation whether the abscess has become completely calm or shows any decrease: then lie the patient with his head in your lap: open the opening of the abscess with an instrument, and take out the pus with your hands, and pull down the tongue with an instrument of this shape
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Do it with silver, or with air, which is subtle like a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When you have finished with the tongue, and the abscess is seen, and has fallen upon your hand: then grasp the instrument, and hold it securely, and extract the pus outwards as much as you can, without pulling out anything from the tunics.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then pierce the abscess with the instrument which has this shape
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	Like scissors: truly their extremities are curved, so that the opening of each of them is directly opposite the other at an angle: take care that it is not from iron, or wet wool
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If this instrument is not present, then pierce it with a needle, which has this shape.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	It is acute from one side, not from the other side.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you have cut one friend, cut the other according to the same kind of incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	And the patient shall drink cold water, or vinegar and water
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If blood flows, let him drink water in which are boiled almond shells: or leaves of myrtle, or things like these from styptics, until the bleeding stops: then care for him until he is healed.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And when there are produced in the gut two other swellings beside the two tonsils.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Cut these also according to what I said concerning the incision of the two tonsils equally
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	I have also treated a woman with a swelling that was born in her gut, which drew towards the stomach, little sense, which I thought would burst her gut: and the woman breathed from her navel, and I forbade her to eat and drink anything: and she died within one or two days
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	The swelling only ascended as far as it emitted two branches, until it went out through the two nasal passages.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	I bound these things together quickly and firmly in one of their hooks
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	And I pulled out from it a large piece of it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut off the root where it had come out of the nose
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	And I did the same for the other nostril
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	I opened his mouth and pressed his tongue: and afterwards I bound the hook in the swelling: then I cut off a part of it, and no blood flowed from it: the woman immediately began to drink water, and then she ate food again
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	The incision should not be made from that apophysis for a long time: and the apophysis follows the place which was incisioned until it is prolonged and with it.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	Therefore, we must make an incision and cauterize the apophysis between the intestines.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	It stood thus from the addition: then I went away from that side, and I do not know what God did with it after me
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	Concerning the incision of the small apophysis
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 7
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When the catarrh descends to the small intestine, and there is an apophysis, and it is long: then it is called a perpendicular one: and if it is in the lower part large and round, then it is called a loop
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is cured with what we said in the explanation, and the cure does not take hold: and the apophysis is softened from it, and is thin: then it is necessary to make an incision for it
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And what is aggregated round about it, and is not of its length, and is bloody, or of a yellowish color, or black, and has no sensation: then it is necessary to make an incision of it
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For in this there is fear of the sick person
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	It is necessary therefore when the blood flows according to the mode which I mentioned from the white, and its length, that you make the sick man sit facing the sun: and pull his tongue with an instrument, of which I spoke before: then fix the loop in one hand, and draw the other downwards: and make an incision with one of the two instruments which I mentioned in the incision of two friends
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary that you do not make an incision from that, except that which is added beyond the natural limit without addition
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	If you cut too deeply from this, it causes swelling and speechlessness.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	And thereafter, after the incision, use what we have said concerning the two amygdales: and take care of it until it has healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If, however, the patient becomes feverish from the incision: then it is necessary to use your skill in cauterization without fear or hesitation
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the manner of cauterization in this is not except with acute water: and it is that you place the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	And then grasp his tongue with the instrument which we have mentioned
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water which I have mentioned above and mix with it some burnt charcoal, and apply it not too thickly, neither too thinly, and press out from it the cavity of this instrument which has this shape
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	And the extremities of it on which the medicine is placed are like the cochlea of a radius
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine upon the limb itself: and the patient lies upon his side, so that the saliva may run out from his mouth from the medicine itself, and not go down into his gut and harm him
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	And hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first apply some quantity of an hour over the limb, until you see that it is becoming black, and stop the biting of the medicine.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take away the burn, and cover it over the extremity of the radius, and fill the burn with medicine, and introduce the radius with the burn into the tube, until the burn adheres to the limb itself.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times, until you achieve what you desire from the cauterization of the limb.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then discharge the dressing: for it itself will grow and fall away in three days, or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If you think it will be necessary to change the dressing, change it: after cauterization remove the surrounding skin with butter, and cool with water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	The outside should be dressed with stitches, and the inside with gargles, until healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This is a safer and more effective treatment than a deep incision and is less dangerous
