Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes even the wound itself will heal even better with this than with cautery or incision: for it is healed with fumigation in this way.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamine, hyssop, origanum, rue, saffron, chamomile, and fennel, and grind them together in a pot, and pour vinegar over them: let them boil: and cover the pot with a lid: and make a hole in the middle of the pot, above which place an instrument that is concave according to this manner
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Make it from silver or brass: and introduce the extremity, in which there is a pomegranate, into the bone of the patient, until the vapor reaches the wound above the canula, until the wound is much obscured
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over it many times, until it heals.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And be careful, do not make this treatment at the beginning of an abscess.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For in the abscess let the heat be added: and do not do this except when the abscess has cooled down
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If however this instrument is not present to you, then take a needle and make in the extremity of it bark of willow: so that the bone of the patient does not burn: for the bark of willow hinders the vapor from burning the bone: and this is from a good treatment with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the extraction of thorns and bones from the gullet.
Caput XXXVIII.	On the extraction of thorns and bones from the gullet.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	There are many bones or fish thorns that adhere to the gullet.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	It is necessary therefore to extract what is visible from the gut after the tongue has been moved with an instrument at the edge of the epiglottis, and it must be declared whether there is anything remaining in the gullet
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what is not visible to the eye but is hidden in the gullet, it is necessary to make the abdomen soft before food is eaten in the stomach
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps the attached things will go out by themselves.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the patient may swallow a soft fragment of bread or a piece of cheese, or swallow saliva; or take a sponge soaked in seawater and bind it in a thread, and then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When it has reached the place where the thorns or bones are, and they are extracted, they are ejected.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If they do not come out with it as we have said: then use an instrument like this made of lead
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	It should be thicker than a bean and have a hook at the end which will enter the gullet easily: and it should have its head raised above the level of the gut
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And take care not to touch its epiglottis, so that it does not suffer from spasm, and push with all your might so that the bone or thorn, or the thing which has been introduced, is driven out by the physician's hand
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	Indeed, when the patient has introduced something himself, this is better: because of his knowledge of the place of the attached thing: and he should push downwards or draw his hand upwards with the instrument, throughout all this according to the quantity which is prepared for him, until it comes out
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the Extraction of the Blood-Sucking Worm.
Caput XXXIX.	On the Extraction of the Blood-Sucking Worm.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the blood-sucking worm is treated with what I have mentioned in the preceding discourse concerning the care of physicians, and it does not yield, then consider in the belly of the patient the root of the worm alone, or at the root of the tongue after you have seized it with the instrument which I mentioned to you.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If, therefore, your hook slips over the blood-sucker, extract it with a small hook, or with fine forceps from the center
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If this is not possible with these means: then take a curved needle and introduce the worm into the belly of the patient as far as the belly itself: then introduce into the curve of the needle a burning iron with fire
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this several times: and let the patient abstain from all water for the whole day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then give the patient a complete treatment with cold water, and open his mouth with it: and close his mouth with it, and do not swallow anything from it: and drink water an hour after each meal with your hand
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	The blood-sucker will then depart when it feels the water falling.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If, however, it does not depart with what we have mentioned, then fumigate the patient with vinegar, or with an ass with the instrument which we mentioned in the fumigation of a wound
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this several times, for it will depart by itself
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the manner of operation in fumigation is that you take all the jars which have dates with fire in them: and the jars are covered with a cover, in the middle of which is a hole: and insert in that hole the extremity of the instrument.</start_of_turn>
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then project the fumes upwards, and place the diseased limb into the extremity of the tube, and close the limb, so that the fumes do not escape, until you know that the fumes have reached the blood.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the blood vessel immediately ruptures.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not rupture, repeat the fumigation many times.</start_of_turn>
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the patient can endure sitting, and eat salt, and garlic, and does not drink water.</start_of_turn>
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is necessary therefore that he depart with this regimen.</start_of_turn>
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the fashion of the instrument with which the blood vessel is extracted from the gut when it ruptures over the vessel itself.</start_of_turn>
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like pincers, thus: because it has that curvature which enters the gut.</start_of_turn
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is like the beak of a heron which is called ciconia, in which there is the roughness of lime: when it grasps something, it does not let it go at all.</start_of_turn
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	Of the opening of the intestines, and their section, and care in general.</start_of_turn>
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.</start_of_turn
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of intestines, of various modes, according as the memory of their origin comes to mind: and they are diverse in their perforation and their section into two modes.</start_of_turn
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of them is the kind of intestine which comprehends moisture.</start_of_turn
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the other kind is because of the place where it occurs in the body.</start_of_turn
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Since the apostema occurs in the head, it is different from the apostema of an accidental nature in the year: and the apostema occurring in a fleshy place is different from the apostema of an accidental nature in the joints: and each one of them has its own judgment from the operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from aposmata there are those which must not be pierced until after the completion of health in the body, and its complement: and there are those which must be pierced while they are raw and do not mature according to the complement.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like the aposmata which are adjacent to the joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Since the apostema when it occurs close to a joint and its duration is prolonged, until it putrefies which is around it, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint are corrupted: which is the cause of the closer contraction of that limb
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is the apostema of a principal limb: since if you delay its perforation until it matures, the bone will bite through either the skin or the bone of that principal limb.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is close to a joint, perforate it therefore while it is immature: and it must not be pierced, as regards the apostema of a raw, incomplete digestion, except when it is close to the joint, so that it does not putrefy deeply, and extends to the interior of the limb, and makes a fistula, or results in its termination which does not heal
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the time of perforation of the apostema, which is matured according to the complement: and it is in the sedation of pain, recession of fever, and decrease of redness, and pulse, and the sharpness of the apostema of the head: and the rest of the signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	It is necessary that you make the perforation in a lower place of the apostema, and of greater prominence: and let the perforation be wide in the length of the body, if the aposmata are in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of laceration, and strings, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all the places equally, in which there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In these, however, which reflect, use with perforation according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When indeed the swelling is in a carnous place: then it is better that you defer the perforation of it until its digestion has been confirmed, as we said according to the addition
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you perforate it before that, you prolong the course of the infection from it, and there is much pus and discharge, and it may swell up its lips, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some swellings are perforated according to the width of the body for necessity: or according to that which the limb requires
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	It is necessary, that you administer in small swellings a small perforation, and in large swellings a wide perforation: or multiple sections according to the likeness of the size of the swelling
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are some swellings in which it is necessary that the skin should be cauterized: and it happens when it is made like a piece of leather, and when it is made at the end, because it is dead: as it happens in many, as in a wound of the dubelet, and of the bubonis
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And there are some which are cut through by a section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And there are some which are like the shape of the leaf of a myrtle tree
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like the swelling of the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And there are some in which an round section and a lunar section are administered: and similar swellings to these are sectioned
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That which has no head, like the superficial lenious swellings, must be perforated with a superficial perforation, or only slightly
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary, when the swelling is great, and has collected much blood, and you perforate it, that you do not remain there and extract the pus throughout that hour: but extract from it a part of it immediately
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then apply the poultice until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then remove some of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this frequently according to the degree of the case: especially if the patient is feeble in spirit, or a woman in childbirth, or a young child, or an old man decrepitus: for the spirit of the animal is dissolved with the evacuation of the poison: and perhaps the patient will die, and you will not know it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore take heed of this chapter, for it contains great caution
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have pierced the abscess, which you will pierce with the poultice, you must drain the wound: and consider it
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If there is a small wound in the abscess, or if it is a flat section, then give an ointment of linen, or an old coat.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if there is a large abscess, and there are many holes of perforation, then you must introduce into every hole a piece of lint, until they reach the bottom
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have excised a part of the skin in the abscess, or if you have cauterized around it: then you must apply an old coat, or like when a bandage is taken off, or cover it with hair without moisture: and keep it tight until the third day
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it, and care for it until it is healed
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If however blood flows in your hour of operation, then give cold water, and vinegar, after it has been drunk in a cloth: and put it over the place where the blood is flowing liberally.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If the bleeding persists, then you must administer regimen, and care, and powders, which I have mentioned in many places of this book, and from experience
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If, however, it is in the season of the snows, and the seat of the apostematis is of many nerves: then it is necessary to infuse the inflamed swellings with wine, and apply warm compresses: and place them over the seat.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	If, however, it is in summer, and the seat is fleshy: then it is necessary to apply soaked sponges with water, or wine and oil, and keep it cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until then, as we have said, on the third day you must drain the apostema, and remove it, and administer for its care what is appropriate until it is healed
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is what is necessary to know concerning the treatment of apostemata in general
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the principles of this classification, as I have said concerning every apostematum, how it is possible to treat it appropriately in each case.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Of the excision of apostemata that occur in the head.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small apostemata occur in the head and are of the kind of nodules which contain veins, which are like sacks: as if they were the breasts of a hen
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	There are many kinds of them.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Some are fat: and some contain moisture like mud: and some contain moisture like wet earth and stones of various kinds
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the excision of all of them, and in their extraction, there is no fear, as long as during their excision there is no injury to the arteries
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	The operation in the excision of these is to learn how to use the instrument which has the form which comes after these, which is called the Intromissum, until you know what it contains
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	If it contains moisture, dry it out by sectioning according to the length of the superficial section: according to this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	If there is moisture in it, dry it out by cutting from point b to point g. When the moisture has gone, remove the membrane which contains it, without leaving any residue behind
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For much moisture returns if anything remains in it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the wound in Egyptian unguent if there is any: or in water and salt: and anoint with olive oil, and leave it until tomorrow.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	The wound itself consumes what remains of the membrane.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat over the wound with Egyptian unguent twice, and three times, and if you are confident that nothing remains of the membrane, then apply olive oil with unguent until it is healed
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If it has a swelling node: then dry it out by cutting according to this form, sectioning which has the shape of a cross: and project the veins between the two lobes of the section, and remove it from all sides: and try your skill in extracting the membrane which contains it
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If however it makes resistance, the artery is to be treated as I shall tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And do the same with a stone abscess, by cutting and curing in the same way, as we said before.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the cutting of a stone abscess is easier: because there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain abscesses in the head of some people, in which there is no moisture.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: because I saw over an abscess in the head of a maidservant, and I found the abscess like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if it was pierced with anything else, it burst open.</start_of_turn>
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other cases, however, in head injuries, besides these, there are also those which happen in the heads of children, and near the roots of the ears, the section should be superficial.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	The section should always be made from below upwards, so as to avoid injuring the course of the blood towards the lower parts
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	One must take care of these things which are suitable for the case.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Regarding the section of the tonsils in the throat.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Many wounds of this kind happen in the throat, under the tonsils, and in the groin: and sometimes in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And over these which arise in the throat, there is one, and many: and they are caused by a blow: and every tonsil is within its own tunic, just as in the nodes and wounds of the head, as we have mentioned
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	There are many kinds of tonsils
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from these there are fatty ones: and there are those which contain humours: and there are malignant ones, which do not obey treatment
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In this way, however, as regards the evacuation of a good portion of the humours, whose mark is a colour similar to that of the skin, and which moves to every part, and is not attached to the nerves of the throat, neither to the veins, nor to the arteries, nor is it deep: it should be performed by a superficial incision from the upper part downwards of the body along a line from the b. to the g., and the skin should be stretched out with two lips, or with many threads, if necessary, as we have said in the wounds of the head, and the humours should be extracted gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	It is very cautious to avoid the bone or the nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	It is not to be rash in dealing with the incisions: so as not to cause damage to the hand with the knife, nor to alarm or grieve the patient unnecessarily.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If however you do cut the bone, or the artery, or are forbidden from the operation, then put in the wound a soaked sponge, or some powder which absorbs blood, and bind up the wound, and leave it alone until the bleeding has ceased, and the wound has been softened: or begin again and let it gangrene.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For indeed blood stops only by tension. Return therefore to your operation, until you have completed it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire about your finger with your index finger, whether anything remains of the other small parts: so cut easily and wash away easily.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If indeed in the root of the phalanx there is a large bone: then it is necessary not to cut that phalanx from its root: but rather to bind it with a strong doubled thread, and leave it alone until it falls out by itself without any nourishment
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then apply to the wound a little of the Egyptian unguent which you have immersed.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Take care of yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole phalanx is cut through, then it is necessary to gather together the two lips of the wound: and hold them fast, after you have washed away because otherwise there will remain excess.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If indeed there remains excess because of the size of the phalanx, then it is necessary to bring to an end the cutting of its root and to extract it: and administer the suture as we said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And concerning the parts of the phalanx which contain moisture, pierce them with a superficial perforation: so as to make visible to you the place of maturity of that part: and put the perforation from that which follows below the body, as we said
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then manage after the perforation of the liver with unguent, and like this with other similar things, until when you see the wound has healed: then take care of the liver with the unguent of generation of flesh until it is healed.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	Then manage after the perforation of the liver with unguent, and like this with other similar things, until when you see the wound has healed: then take care of the liver with the unguent of generation of flesh until it is healed.
Caput XLIII.	Then manage after the perforation of the liver with unguent, and like this with other similar things, until when you see the wound has healed: then take care of the liver with the unguent of generation of flesh until it is healed.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	Then manage after the perforation of the liver with unguent, and like this with other similar things, until when you see the wound has healed: then take care of the liver with the unguent of generation of flesh until it is healed.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	Then manage after the perforation of the liver with unguent, and like this with other similar things, until when you see the wound has healed: then take care of the liver with the unguent of generation of flesh until it is healed
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	Then manage after the perforation of the liver with unguent, and like this with other similar things, until when you see the wound has healed: then take care of the liver with the unguent of generation of flesh until it is healed
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Then manage after the perforation of the liver with unguent, and like this with other similar things, until when you see the wound has healed: then take care of the liver with the unguent of generation of flesh until it is healed
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	Then manage after the perforation of the liver with unguent, and like this with other similar things, until when you see the wound has healed: then take care of the liver with the unguent of generation of flesh until it is healed
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then manage after the perforation of the liver with unguent, and like this with other similar things, until when you see the wound has healed: then take care of the liver with the unguent of generation of flesh until it is healed
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then the secret of the sponge is this: it signifies above the division of the canal from the phlegm which issues from it, when that which is broken is cut off, and the cutting of the piece.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	Leave the wound open for a while at some other time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the hour has passed in which the inflammation subsides, join together the two lips of the wound with skin only, without cartilage
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then give medicines which make new flesh grow, until the wound is healed
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis says.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	This is the end of Albucasis's explanation. The exposure is not complete until the patient has expired, because the patient is already dead as a result of the disease. The patient's breath is obstructed by the swelling of the epiglottis, which is why the patient is unable to breathe through the mouth. The patient is therefore suffocating. Therefore it is commanded to leave the wound open until the malice of the disease has passed. And the malice of the disease is three days, and almost like that. Therefore when the malice has passed, the swelling will be gone and the wound can be closed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And this which I have seen myself, that a handmaid took a knife and put it in her mouth, and it went down into her windpipe.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	I was called to care for her, and I found her dead, like a drowned man.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I saw that there was blood flowing out of the wound of her foot
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I am suspicious that it did not close by itself, nor did it guide itself: and the air was coming out of the wound
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	Properly, therefore, and of his own will, and cared for himself, until he was well: and nothing happened to the handmaid except that she was thrown into the water. She returned after a day to her former condition.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Accordingly: there is no fear in the Epiglottis section.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	Concerning the section of the hernia gutturis.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.</start_of_turn>
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This hernia is called the hernia gutturis, is a great swelling, according to the colour of the body: and it is very common among women.</start_of_turn
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	It is of two kinds: either it is natural: or it is accidental.</start_of_turn
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural kind there is no cause.</start_of_turn
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental kind is of two kinds: one of which is like a swelling of fat nodules.</start_of_turn
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	The other kind is like a swelling caused by the bursting of an artery.</start_of_turn
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in this there is fear, and it is not permissible to assume that it is only a wound, except in the case where it is slight: and you must examine it, and investigate it with an instrument.</start_of_turn
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If you find it like a swelling of fat, and it is not suspected of any other disease: then dry it up like fat knots: and extract it with the thing which contains it from the bag, if it is in a bag: and if not, then explore the whole of it.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Concerning the section of the upper parts of the nodes.</start_of_turn
Caput XLV.	Head Chapter XLV.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	The head is of great variety; and I have already spoken of all the varieties in detail: and it is necessary to state here the difference between the Node and the Exitus, since doubt arises concerning them.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore, that when the Exitus is hot, and there is fever and pain, until the ebullition of excess is settled and putrefaction is completed: then the fever and heat will cease
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But when the Node is concerned, there is neither heat nor fever nor pain, and it contains the black bile, which is the natural bag, and is according to the colour of the body: and is the commencement of their disease like barley, and causes swelling like a blister, and is greater or less.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And there are two kinds: either soft or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colours of moisture are many, as I have mentioned in detail before
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary therefore, when you are dealing with the Node, to examine it, and to inquire about it first with the instrument which is called the Intromissum, according to the form of the latter in the following chapter
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the way of inquiry concerning the apostemata, and all the Nodes, is that you take this instrument and introduce it into the moist place which you find in the apostemata: and you draw out your fingers gradually, until you know that the instrument has pierced the skin
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then lastly put your hand according to the measure of the size of the apostematum.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then draw out the Intromissum, and consider that which comes out in the mark of its incision
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore it comes out running moisture, whatever be its colour: then dry it with a superficial section, according as I have mentioned in the other apostemata
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	If moisture does not issue from the cavity of the Intromissi, then you know that it is fat: for it has a section above it resembling a cross, according to this form, as I have taught you. Suspend it with hooks and scour the skin from every part with ease. Keep the intestines away from it, so that you may extract them whole with the knot.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If, however, the intestine bursts during the operation and it is not possible to extract it whole, much is lost thereby. In such a case, extract it piecemeal until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if anything remains of it, little or much, it returns to the knot according to most
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it incites you, and something remains of it: then put a sponge moistened with corrosive powders on the completion of your work. Suspend the sponge and place above it the soft tissue which rests upon the hard seat, and care for it with the rest of the treatment until it is healed
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If there is a large knot, then split its two lips and care for it with that which adheres to it
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If, however, there is a pulsating or non-pulsating swelling: then correct it, and place a compress over the wound and let it go in two or three days, until the sponge decays and the blood boils over: then return to the work which remains from the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Of the instruments outside which are needed for cutting and perforating.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVII.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	These are the forms of the Intromissi, and there are three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	There are three of them: the large, the medium, and the small
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let iron nails be driven around the circumference of the square base, so that they hasten the entrance into the apostemate.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	These are the forms of experience, and no, that is, perforations: and one of them is called beris, which is, perforating: and there are three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	There is a great one, a medium one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They meet together, so that they may be investigated through the apostemata, and exits, and fistulas, and bubbles from what is between the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, third, flat, like a large needle which travels under its burr, from citrine, or from air, or iron, or silver
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the best of them are those which are made from citrine.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And there are also experiences made of black lead, which meet together so that they may investigate fistulas, the cavities of which are reflections, as they reflect with their smoothness with those reflections
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And there are three kinds of them again
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For since they are made from iron, they are long, medium, and short, according to the quantity of the diameter of the fistula and the tightness of its structure
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The shape of needles, and there are many kinds of them.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For since they are made from iron, they are simple, that is, those which have only one curve: and there are three kinds like liquids, large, medium, and small
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from iron nails are blind: and there are three kinds of them
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from iron nails are those which have two curves, and there are three kinds of them: and from iron nails are those which have three curves, and there are three kinds of them: and all of these are necessary in their place
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	These are the forms of scalpels which cut and scrape nodes, and their bases. There are three kinds: because they are from large, medium, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities which make the cut are acute, the other extremities are not acute: and they are not placed like this except when there is an intent to make an incision in the excision of nodes near the fear of the vein, or nerve: and in order that the patient may recover more quickly from the operation than from the excision of the base.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are large, and there are three kinds
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of air, and are like a rod with which alcohol is made: and at the wide end is a hidden Spatumili point: and in this runs inwards and outwards as desired, like liquid
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of the Spatumili which are conducted between the fingers at the perforation of the base: and the patient does not perceive them: and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The air bubbles which are broken when the flow of blood is cut: and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They are made of air, or lemon-yellow, round, of about the length of a liquid: and are transparent.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of air bubbles should be large and small with you: in order to cut through blood quickly when necessary, and then when it is not necessary there should be no doctor present.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	But do not use these instruments to cut blood in any place of the body, and do not use them except in places of carnation: such as wounds of the leg, and hip, and wounds of the arm, and breast, and belly, and groin, and similar wounds to these, from wounds of carnation, humidis.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And when small instruments like nails are sometimes found alongside the fists of the surgeons, according to their form: from which blood is separated when it flows from the site of the phlebotomy, or at the incision of the nail, or of an artery; and when they are sometimes found alongside the rounded instruments of this kind.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	And when sometimes small instruments like nails are found alongside the fists of the surgeons, according to their shape: from which blood is separated when it flows from the site of the phlebotomy, or at the incision of the nail, or of an artery; and when sometimes found alongside the rounded instruments of this kind.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the breasts of some men swell during sleep (that is, when they start to become soiled in sleep), until they resemble the breasts of women: and remain after the feeding has ceased.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever dislikes this thing, it is necessary to cut across the breasts with a lunar section, according to this shape from the ridge, to the line, to the edge. Then scrape away all the fat
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then apply a bandage of medicinal ointment
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join together the two lips of the wound with sutures, and care for it, until it heals
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If, however, the breast leans downwards and becomes softened because of its size, like women: then it is necessary to make two similar lunar incisions on the two upper sides, each containing the other at their ends, until one line is greater than the other, according to this shape from the ridge to the line, to the edge. Then scrape away the skin which is between the two lips, and remove the fat, and perform what has been said concerning the sutures and powders, which is necessary for healing, until it heals
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If, however, you do not wish to perform the incision which is necessary, because of the anxiety of the patient, or because of the flow of blood: then it is necessary to apply a soaked bandage under the nail and send it away, until that which remains of the fat has rotted away
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	After perforation of the apostematus, which happened under the heel.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.</start_of_turn>
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These apostemata which happen under the heel are of the kind of hard stromelas which contain vesicles, and from these are those which contain humors.</start_of_turn
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Which are from those which contain humors, must be sectioned with a lunar blade, in this form, from line b to line g, as when it is evacuated from the whole of that which is in the apostematus from the sound, then fill up the wound with wool and let it go until the next day.</start_of_turn
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.</start_of_turn
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the apostematus were of the kind of knots of stromelas, then split over it, as we said concerning the stromelas which are equal.</start_of_turn
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, pus comes out through this, then administer cautery in it, as we said before.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	Of the perforation of the apostematus which happens through the artery and the vein.</start_of_turn
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.</start_of_turn
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the artery is ruptured, and the skin above the wound is consolidated, then much blood comes out from the apostematus: and in the same way blood comes out of the vein also, as it happens in this apostematus and swelling.</start_of_turn
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is recognized that the apostematus and swelling are from the artery and the vein, are: because when the apostematus is from the artery, it is long and aggregated in the depth of the body: and when the inflamed apostematus touches your fingers, you feel as though there is a constriction.</start_of_turn
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is from the vein is round in the manifest body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section above this [apophysis] is an error, and especially that which is under the testicles, and the groin, and the neck, and in many places of the body: and it is great danger.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	It is necessary therefore that its care be taken with iron, and that from the veins also it is in the extremities, or in the head, it is necessary that its care be taken.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	And that which is from the veins is from the dilation of the orifice of the artery, is found in the cut section in length
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with hooks, afterwards the artery: and free the vein from the tunics, until it is severed
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce under these [acumen] the needle, and make the vein penetrate until it reaches the other side, and tighten the artery with a double thread in two places, according as you were taught in the extraction of two veins which are in the times
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then pierce the place which is between two ligaments with sponge, until the blood which is in it all comes out, and dissolve the swelling.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer the cure which generates pus, until the ligaments fall away: afterwards care for this with appropriate bandages until it is healed
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	And if there should be a swelling from the section of the Vein, then it is necessary that you keep your hand steady which is possible from the swelling with the cut
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce the needle under the place where you kept your hand steady, and make the vein penetrate: and be in it a double thread, until you extract it from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tighten with this the swelling the ligament with good thread: according as I have said to you concerning the ligation of the veins, from two parts with two extremities of thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If, however, the thread has been drawn out, then insert an awl with another thread under the whole of the incision: before doing so, tighten your thread in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry the wound in the middle of its course, until it has healed: then cut through the excess of the skin, and let go of what is bound from it
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place upon it the wool which you submerged in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer care, which is done with compresses and unguents, until it is healed.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	As for the swelling which arises from the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter L.</start_of_turn>
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Thus swelling occurs in the artery and the vein, in the same way it occurs in nerves: that which occurs in percussion, or which arises from excessive work, and in like manner: and it is for this reason that it is most frequent in the armpits, or the calves, and in every place where there is movement of the sutures: and it is a serious swelling.</start_of_turn>
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its colour is similar to that of the rest of the body, and is in various positions without pain: and when it is tightened with tension, it feels in it a feeble tremor similar to sleeplessness.</start_of_turn
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	It is not a swelling which is collected in the depths of the body, but is under the skin, and it moves to all parts, and does not go forward, nor backward, nor to the front, nor to the back.</start_of_turn
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Because it arises from the tissues in the sutures, it is not necessary to suture it with iron.</start_of_turn
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps therefore contraction will occur.</start_of_turn
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	In that case, in the head or in the face, find the skin with the nail.</start_of_turn
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If there is a small fistula, then hold it with forceps and cut it off from its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If it is large, then suspend it with one hand and excise it: then remove it and unite it with a suture: and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	As for the section of an fistula, which happens in the belly.</start_of_turn
Caput LI.	Chapter LI.</start_of_turn>
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Some people suffer from numerous fistulas in various parts of their bodies, such as the thighs, which are called Fungalia because of their resemblance to fungi.</start_of_turn
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Their root is fine and their head is large, and their lips are closed.</start_of_turn
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	They arise from a small opening and become large gradually.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And indeed I saw a man who had two of these fistulas in his belly, which were larger than any others. There was no difference between them, white or black, except for the fineness of the root. They protruded outwards and moisture always ran from them.</start_of_turn
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I cut them out and found in one about X and VIII ounces and in the other about six ounces. As for the operation of their incision, consider that if the patient is moist and the color of the fistula is white, moist and the root is fine, then cut it out with a broad spatula and keep your hands away from the fire.</start_of_turn
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	A great deal of blood is ejected at the incision. Be careful if you are stained with blood, then cauterize it.</start_of_turn
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see a faint and timid patient at the incision with a knife, then take a lead pencil made of lead and suspend it with the thread athelul: whose method is as we have said, and discharge it in two days.</start_of_turn
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add in stricture of lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Then add in stricture of lead. Do not cease to tighten the lead until it breaks by itself without toil.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If the great vessel is of the root, then in its incision there is something of fear and weakness: especially that which is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	It is true that it is possible to cut through the middle of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, so that it does not return
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for it until the wound is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And take heed lest you presume to cut through the vessel which is of the color of saffron, little sense, foul aspect: for it is the remnant of cancer: and I shall remind you of cancer afterwards
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	Of the care of the great vessel.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	The great vessel arises from multiple ulcers.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	It proceeds either from rents of the liver which are above the belly: or it proceeds from the intestines, according as happens in other ruptures
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from the blood which flows from the vein, or from the artery, according as is prescribed
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from the swelling which is contracted in it
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If it is because of a rent of the liver, and the outlet of the bile: then its color is similar to that of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and appears in various places
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	If it is because of the bursting of the intestines, then its site is as we have narrated, with great variety
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you thrust your finger into the wound, it is hidden; then it returns, and often makes a sound. And it swells greatly at the entrance of the bath, and causes great suffering.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If however it is because of moisture, it is soft, then it does not hide when you thrust your hand in, neither is it constricted, neither does it swell.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is because of blood, then with these signs the clot appears black at the edge of the nail
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If however it is because of dead flesh: then it is a large, thick, hard clot, and it forms according to the quantity of one
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If however it is because of wind, then its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in this is as you consider, if the prominence of the navel is because of blood of an artery or vein, or wind: then you must abstain from its care.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in this is fear and danger, as I told you in the chapter where I said that clots because of an artery or vein are dangerous.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If however the prominence of the navel is because of an intestine or a tumour: then you must extract the sick part, as long as it retains its natural tension, and remain extended
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then the signs with the cautery around the whole circumference of the navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then order him to lie between your hands over his back
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then go round with a sponge swab wide in the circumference of the navel over the place which you marked with the cautery.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then draw out the middle of the clot towards the upper part, with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind him around firmly with thread, or with a strong silk cord: and let the knot of the ligature be at the apex.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle of the extended bone above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you see that it has grasped itself by the ligament: then extract the apex, and introduce it into the finger index, and push the intestine into the belly: and if you see a bone, then grasp it with a hook, and cut off its surplus
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if the bone is an artery or a vein: then surround it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and introduce them into the two strong threads: and introduce two needles around the circumference which you made around the bone like a cross, which you make penetrate
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then bind the bone in four places above the needles: and if you will, take out the needles, and loosen the place, until the extended flesh putrefies: and it will fall away by itself: or cut it off when it subsides and putrefies
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with what is necessary from the unguents, until it is healed
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	Which if the navel-cord is emitted from the flesh near the bone, or from the humidity: then it is necessary to concave the bone as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And extract the blood, or the humidity, which you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for it with what is necessary to solidify the place.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	(End of text
Caput LIII.	(End of Book 53
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	As we have said in the explanation of the species of Cancer, and how it is to be treated by physicians: and caution must be taken with it in the treatment with iron, so that it does not ulcerate: and we have said that Cancer is generated in the matrix, and caution must be taken in its treatment.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And they [the ancients] said, when Cancer is in a place where it can be extirpated, as for instance when it is in the breast or the thigh, or in like cases, throughout the limb from the root to the tip: especially when it is in its early stages.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it is great and advanced, it is not right to approach it closely
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	I am unable to cure anyone from such a thing: neither can any other go before me who would attempt to do so
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation in such a case, when it is in the place mentioned above, is to precede [meaning to make an incision] and to evacuate the tumour by means of black bile several times over
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then a phlebotomy must be performed if the swelling persists.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient for the operation, in which he is placed alongside the operation itself.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then cover the Cancer with hooks which agree with it
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then bandage it from all sides with skin, according to the rule, until nothing remains of its roots: and let the blood flow, and do not bind it too tightly, but rather express the place, and evacuate the thick blood from your hands, or as much as is possible from the instruments.
