Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what has been said in the chapter of cauterization.
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	And then care for the knee until it heals.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	And if the anus does not come out, then instill the patient with a small enema in which there is a little biting, so that it may be driven out quickly, when the patient presses himself
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	If indeed the little ones are outside the anus, then the matter is easy and light: and it is as if you grasp them with your finger, or grasp them with a loop, and strike at them.
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	And then care for the knee as we have said, until it heals
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And he who dislikes incision with the sword, must know how to administer suture according to this manner.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Grasp the slippery thread and introduce it into the wound.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw out the little thread towards the upper part, and make it penetrate with the needle at its root from the opposite side: and pass two extremities of the thread through the lower part of the needle, and let them lie parallel: and tighten the little thread with a strong suture.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then knot the thread and draw out the needle.
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the little threads, and let go of one: do not keep it, as it may cause excessive bleeding.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place above any soaked dressing on the blood-soaked area, or on cotton wool, and place it above the wound: and command the patient to rest.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then let go of it, until it is healed.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When the little threads are healed, care for the incisions with unguents, and remain with the patient until healed
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	(End of excerpt
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Many times these occur from the swelling of the bowels, and the constriction of the natural order.)
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When these things are present, and do not yield to medical treatment: then it is necessary to apply sponges soaked in vinegar or with your finger, until they become soft, and the outer layer is removed, which hinders the healing.)
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for the wound, until it is consolidated as it should be.)
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If, however, they do not consolidate: then repeat the wound with greater reason than before, until they bleed much, and are then cleansed; care for the wound again until it is healed.)
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	(End of excerpt
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter 82.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	Know that the Almirmar is not except a round node according to the colour of the body, like the head of a nail: and it is found throughout the body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and the fingers: and it arises from the matter of pain in walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	Therefore it is necessary to cut away what is around the nail, and to hold it with forceps or with a needle, and to eradicate it from its root
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then care for it: and if you wish, cauterize it according to what is before mentioned in its chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	And from the heel there is a small, rough, filtered, round elevation on the surface of the body.
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And they often happen in the hands of children.
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And its care is to extend the heel and cut it through: or to ligate it with a silken thread: or with a hair, until it falls off.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what has been said before with fire, or with acute medicine: and thus the heel will be eradicated both forwards and backwards, not backwards only with the instrument which I have mentioned.</start_of_turn>
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	There is also a small, filtered elevation, large, on the surface of the body, which is wide downwards: and when it is affected by cold, it is felt in it like the bite of a flea, and it is found throughout the body: and most of it happens in the hands.</start_of_turn
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its care is to take a needle from the wing of a gull, or a strong feather: and put it on the Flea, until the circle of the needle contains the circumference of the Flea.</start_of_turn
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then withdraw your hand with the cannula until you have severed what is around the ant: and place it into the depth of the flesh, and extract the ant from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish, do this with an air cannula or a metallic one, according to this form.</start_of_turn>
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the cannula be at the level of the nail which is being grasped, so that it may be both grasped and withdrawn easily.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish, burn the ant according to what is stated concerning the cautery of the mole in the chapter on cautery.</start_of_turn>
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	Concerning the forms of the instruments which are administered to the testicles in ailments of the animal, and the solution of the belly, and the colic.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter 83.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	When the testicles are swollen from silver, or gold, or blown glass, or malleated.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And when these instruments are of small or large size, according to those in which they are administered.</start_of_turn
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	This is done in the treatment of young boys with inflamed testicles, as they are small: and of those animals which are weak or painful, thus also the testicles of these.</start_of_turn
Clistere magnum.	Large testicles.</start_of_turn
Cistere paruum.	Small testicles.</start_of_turn
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The upper part of this cannula, that is, the head in which the uterus is tied, should be broad according to this manner: and there should be a distinction so that the uterus is tied like water, and the lower extremity which enters the belly should be deaf, that is, not open, soft, yielding, drawn to thinness: and on one side there are two holes, and on the other side a single hole.</start_of_turn
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	The width of the opening should be according to the length of the rays, neither too large nor too small. And let there be a space in which to place the instruments from the belly of the animal: or from parchment of the wing, which is according to the form of the asofrat of the hen. And its root is the palm of one.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	The hole is pierced with many holes as it turns around, and there is space between every hole the size of a finger
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into the hole a strong thread from a strong thread, which is from ten threads, or about these, and join with it as with an asofrat.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When it is thus placed in that space, string it in the head of the clip between two points of constriction.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	And then clip it with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	This is the form of the circle which is here depicted, and of the holes
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of the clipping with it is: that you implement both the belly or the belly from the medicine, which is warmed according to the quantity of the patient's tolerance: and take care that it is neither too hot nor too cold, nor too cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the patient is placed on his back, and lifts his legs upwards: and place under it the intestines, that is, the skin over which people lie, or linen.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then join the extremity of the clip with bile, or with alum or with the mucilage of barley, or similar.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then insert it into the belly with ease
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then take hold of the belly with two hands and press it out with your thumbs, until it has evacuated all that is in the clip into the intestine
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then extract the Clistere, and elevate the patient's limbs towards the wall.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If the physician thinks it is necessary to remove it, then hold it as much as possible.</start_of_turn>
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	If he sleeps all night with it, it is the most harmful thing.</start_of_turn>
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if you wash the Clistere with the solution of the bowels, and it comes out: then repeat the Clistere until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are hemorrhoids or painful swelling in the rectum, then let the Clistere be gentle and soft, from the Clisteres which are used to treat children.</start_of_turn
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the way of the gentle Clistere which is not strict on the skin.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the treatment of wounds of the head without fracture of the bone.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXXIIII.	Head wound.</start_of_turn
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have spoken in the discourse about the treatment of wounds which agrees with the book, and I will speak here of the treatment of them with the hand and with the help of physicians.</start_of_turn
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say therefore, that wounds are varied according to that from which they arise, and according to the place where the wound falls.</start_of_turn
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	The wounds which arise from many things are like the blows of a stone: or the cutting of a sword or knife: or the percussion with a spear or wood or arrow: and like these from many things.</start_of_turn
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	But wounds which arise from the place of the body are like a wound which falls on the head, or the neck, or the chest, or the belly, or the limb: and like these from many things.</start_of_turn
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	I am also reporting on the treatment of certain wounds, in order to set out the ratiocination and rule concerning the rest of the wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	I shall begin with simple head wounds: for the memory of compound wounds will arise at the commencement of the third chapter
Dico ergo.	Thus I say.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When a simple wound occurs in the head and there is no fracture of the bone: consider then, if it is from a piece of stone or something similar, and if only the skin is torn: and it is a great wound, and the time is great for an inflamed swelling to increase: then stop, and perform a cephalic phlebotomy immediately: and do not delay this: and extract from him from the blood according to the quantity of his virtue: if there be nothing to prevent it, especially if there be little blood issuing from the wound.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be from the opposite side of the wound
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the patient be warned against repletion, and wine, and coarse food
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If, however, anything hinders the reduction [of the swelling], then let him abstain from food, and not approach meat or drink water
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And place upon the wound if it happens to him a swelling of blood, a bandage infused in saffron alone, or with wine in which there is a styptic.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	If, however, you are secure from the swelling being increased, then place upon the wound, if it is accompanied by blood, and it has not changed its nature, powder which I will tell you of later: and if it has changed its nature, then place upon it some unguent, until it is healed
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If, however, the wound is great, or is from a cut with a knife, and the like: and the lips of it do not adhere by means of little hairs, then adhere them together with sutures, according as I shall tell you in the chapters concerning the sutures of wounds within
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If, however, a vein has been detected by the bone, and hangs loose, and its retention is not possible, except in a small suspension: then cut it off.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Care for the vein with the physicians, and restore it in the place of the skin, and command the patient to eat nourishing food, such as heads of garlic and cooked wheat, until the pulse returns: and similar things.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find in the flesh putrefaction, and it does not adhere to the bone: then cut off the whole putrefied part, and throw it away: then care for the remainder
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If, however, in his veins is an artery, or a vein from which blood flows: and it is not severed by the physicians, then inquire about the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If, therefore, you find it unseamed, then sew it up with Spatumili, or bind it up.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If necessity compels you when it does not confer what we have said, then burn it, until the blood is severed
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If, however, these wounds are small and simple: then the matter is easy and light: so that you may powder over them this powder: because it consolidates them before they change them with air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of applying the powdered medication.</start_of_turn>
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Recipe for olive oil, dragon's blood and burnt lime. Take one part of each, mix them thoroughly, and sprinkle over it: apply it to the wound and bind tightly, until it adheres well and clots with the blood.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then stretch it out over feathers, and let it go, and do not soak it until it remains, for it will not adhere.</start_of_turn
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	So it is not erased by this medicine until it has healed.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	When it has made the stone sole, when there is neither of these in the present [ointment], and even dragon's blood does the same operation in many great wounds, when it happens that it is put on these and bound over, and there are recent wounds with their own blood, which have not altered the air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	When it has altered the air somewhat by its alteration, especially when it is in summer, then it is not in the position of this powder to retain its efficacy: therefore you must care for it along with this [medicine], so that you put upon it some digestive unguent: or you put upon it balls made of barley flour, made with water and honey, until they discharge pus
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If indeed it happens with a fractured bone in a limb, and it is small, then extract that with a hook: and I will tell you about the treatment of head fractures in this [text].
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Of wounds of the head.
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter 85.
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	If indeed a wound happens in the head, then there is no difference between it and a wound of the head when it is simple.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	If indeed a nerve or an artery is cut: then if it is a nerve, it is not in its wisdom to remove it, except as a remedy for its causing excessive bleeding, such as saffron, and rue, and things of that kind.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	For they know nerves, and they drive them away.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not put anything cold upon the wound in any way: for the substance of nerves is cold, and their continuity is with the brain, which is the soul of members: and this is how it is healed by physicians, such as stone dust with sweet water infused with some oil of almond, or with rose oil, and thiosin, when it is washed away even with sweet water: and the rest of the mineral stones, in this way, and moist unguents.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	If, however, a wound is large, then manage the suture: or bind its lips with wool.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	If, however, the wound is deep, or if it lies in a recess of its lower part, in which pus is collected, then perforate it at a depressed place in that area.</start_of_turn
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If, however, it has been cut in the wound, and blood flows from it: then separate it, or dry up the blood, and bind it: or cauterize it, if need be.</start_of_turn>
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If, however, some of the intestines or all of them have been cut through, and the guts are hanging out: then gather the lip of the skin with the suture over the top of the gut, and do not touch the gut, but rather equalize it, and reduce it to its natural position.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it tightly with a bandage, and let it go in a few days.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents in which there is stypticity and drying, until it heals.</start_of_turn
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If, however, a wound has made an imprint in the bone, then examine it: then if there are fragments of bone in it, extract them all, or whatever can be separated from it: and what cannot be prepared, leave it, until the wound has healed, and the swelling has subsided.</start_of_turn
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If, however, the wound has been burned, then powder over it the powder which I have mentioned.</start_of_turn
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If, however, bone is seen in the wound, and a fistula has formed: then care for it as is mentioned in its own chapter.</start_of_turn>
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	Of an ulcer in Spatulis.
Caput LXXXVI.	Of an ulcer in Spatulis.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is percussion of the lance or knife, and its blood is deep, then consider it seriously.
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If blood comes from the ulcer when the patient breathes, then you know that the ulcer is mortal
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it is not deep and blood comes with it: do not at once put powder on it, neither bind it up, lest the blood remain in its depth and be fatal. Put on it a strong unguentum and heal it in two days.</start_of_turn>
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If there is no unguentum there, then put in the mouth of the ulcer a little wool, so that it may absorb what comes out of it from the humilities: and make the patient sleep over the ulcer so that it may heal what is gathered in it.</start_of_turn
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If after three days, or more, the patient does not have a spasmus or tremor of the cord, nor a bad stricture in his breath, and has all the other symptoms good, then you know that the ulcer is healed.</start_of_turn
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Treat it with care and with remedies, and with other cures, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If in the end its healing is excused, and it always opens, then you know that there is a fistula.</start_of_turn
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Treat it from its chapter.</start_of_turn
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the ulcer is from a wound of a sword or knife, and is simple on the surface of the chest or back: then treat it as if it were sutured, if it is large: or with powder if it is small.</start_of_turn
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	If, however, he has made an imprint in the bone, and it breaks off from it: then inquire about the nail, and prepare to extract that fragment, if it is separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	If it is not separated, then leave it, until the nail softens, so that the extraction may be easier.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	The rest of the nails which have become loose in the other limbs, judgment concerning these is in the treatment, is the judgment which we have mentioned.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Concerning the nails of the belly, and the exit of the intestine, and the evacuation of them.
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter 87.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The fracture which happens in the belly is great, medium, or small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	From the great, indeed when the intestine comes out, or the number of intestines.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore comes the introduction of the intestines, and the suture is more difficult and arduous
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And the small fracture also becomes difficult in another way
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore, it follows that the reduction of these is more difficult if you do not promptly restore them to their place in their introduction: for they become swollen, open, and thickened: therefore the entrance of them becomes difficult
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore, it is better to fracture the medium than the large or small: for with the medium, the reduction of the intestine is not difficult, as it is with the other two kinds
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	You know that the suture of the belly is according to four modes
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two sutures are common for the suture of the belly, and for the suture of the rest of the limbs: and two other sutures communicate with the rest of the limbs alone
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	Truly are these things proper with the sutures of the belly: and I tell you one also with its explanation and declaration.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	When a wound is small and something comes out of the intestine through it, it is difficult to reduce it: then that is because of one of two things.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the disruption, as we have said: or because there is an inflation in the intestine because of the cold of the air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When it is like this, it is necessary to heat it up, so as to soak the sponge or the cloth wet in warm water only
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or boil in water a little barley, some pepper and some spike, and embrace with these the intestine, until the inflation is resolved.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	When it makes this drink which has a astringency: and it is better than plain water in resolving the inflation.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When the inflation has been resolved, then moisten the intestine with the water in which it has been boiled, or with oil
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For in this way it makes the entrance of it with a little thing more gentle.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	If however it is excused its return after this cure, then find in the disruption a little thing, with the instrument with which hemorrhoids are cut.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	The first cure is better when it is prepared, than a section: and does not make a forcing to cut after necessity and the defect of the instrument.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part be acute, which is a circle, and the other part not acute, and the extremity soft should not be like that of Spatumilis, but rather be more obtuse like chaff: and that is like the almond, as the drink is like that.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When the wound is thus increased, and the intestine is introduced, then it is necessary to reduce it according to its natural form in its own place, if possible above it: for that is better.</start_of_turn>
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When the disruption is wide in the lower part of the belly: then it is necessary that you make the patient lie upon his back, and raise his legs higher than his head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	If it is in the upper part of the belly: then place his head high, and his chest higher than his lower parts
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	Similarly, if the disruption is in one of the two parts of the belly: then place your intention and your consideration always in this, that the part in which the wound is should be higher than the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	It is necessary in large wounds and in medium wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	In small wounds, place it according to what is prepared for you
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make present between your hands a more pious minister who holds the entire disruption with his hand: and join his lips together.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then draw from it that which follows the suture something after something: and this is the common way of stitching one.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is necessary to take an awl or the number of awls according to the quantity of the wound's breadth
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then let go from the extremity of the disruption the quantity of the little finger, that is, the physician: and fix the awl one beyond what you put into the vein in two extremities of the skin, when two extremities are put through the skin from the inside, until you make it penetrate from another part, and you have gathered up two extremities of the skin, and two of the veins: and there are four orders formed
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then string with double thread around the circumference of the awl several times from two parts together, until two lips of the wound are gathered together by a decent aggregation.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let go of the length of the finger also, and fix in its place another one: afterwards draw back the thread with the needle, as you did with the first needle.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Do not cease to do this until you have completed the constriction of the whole wound
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let there be medium-sized needles between the length and the thickness: because the fine needles easily slip through flesh: and the thick ones are difficult to pass through the skin: therefore it is necessary that there be medium-sized ones in the thickness, and length.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	It is not to be permitted that the needle be fixed at two contiguous parts of the skin close to each other: that the flesh should not be pierced too quickly, and that the wound should not be opened before its consolidation, and that it should not be prolonged even with the suture, for fear of hindering the consolidation of the wound
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut off the ends of the needles, so that they do not injure the patient during his sleep: and put over it little balls of wool from all around, which will hold the ends of the needles: and let go of them, until you know that the wound is consolidated
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this kind of suture with needles of this sort is more convenient in small wounds
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For it is sufficient in the suture of these to make use of one needle, or two, or about as many as are needed.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second suture is more common, that it joins together four extremities: two of skin and two of fat in one wound, with a needle in which the thread is equally distributed in thickness and length.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have pierced with the needle the four extremities, reduce the needle from the part from which you began, so that the retouched thread may fall from the upper part of the wound: so that the suture be like the suture of cloth which we make when we string up cloth, and put between every suture as much of the length of the smaller finger as is necessary
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	Men know this suture.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	When such a suture has been made, men know that it is sufficient to bind up what has been wounded by the knife, which has caused a wound on the belly, and which has been torn away from its substance by the greater part of the palm of one hand: and that it has escaped from the intestines about two palms from the middle intestine, and that there is a tear in the middle of the belly.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	Therefore, I put it outside the wound for twenty-four hours
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	It was consolidated in the space of about fifteen days: and I cared for it, and it healed: and afterwards it remained sound for many years, being in its proper place.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the doctors said that it would not heal
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And by a miracle, I cured it without ointment
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because I was in a place where unguent was not to be found, neither was there any of the physicians there
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	I put upon the wound a coat of wool twice a day, and I bathed it with honey water until it healed
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	There are two kinds of sutures which I shall tell you about according to the narration of the sermon.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is like this: you begin with a sharp suture: and you pass the point from outside to the inside part
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When you have thus pierced the skin, and in the wound you have made a loop according to the length and breadth of the whole body: you draw out the point of the needle in the side in which you put it in, and you make the point penetrate from the inside part to the outside in the opposite side.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When you have thus made the point penetrate, then make it penetrate once more in the same place from the outside part to the inside: and draw out the point which is in this side, and make the needle penetrate from the inside part to the outside in the opposite side: and make it penetrate just as you made it penetrate in the point of the needle which is in the side, until it penetrates the whole thing
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then commence from this side also from the same limb, and bring your finger along with the extremity, which is from the heel on the other side, and extract the point from the skin as it has penetrated.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then reduce the limb to this side also, and bring your finger along with the extremity which is on the other side, with the heel: and extract the point from the skin which has penetrated, and make that part whole again and the other: and make that part whole after the other, until your entire limb is whole according to this example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the end of this suture is that you make your sutures like those which are made for the skin: so that you make one from one side of the limb and the other from the other side, until you have completed it.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of proper suture which Gale has said.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This is how he has said it, that you must make your sutures like some of the physicians do, because they collect every part in proportion to itself, and apply one extremity to the other extremity, and the heel to the other heel.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And that is how it is done according to what I have told you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	It is necessary that you make the point of the needle penetrate from the outside inwards in this part, and that you draw out two extremities of the limb.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then withdraw the point and make the needle penetrate from the outside inwards through two extremities of the limb, namely both of them
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then withdraw both of them, and make them penetrate both from the inside outwards through the two other extremities which are on the opposite side
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this is the best way of making a suture, and is the suture which requires remembering
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is indeed the word of Galen.
Et dixerunt quidam.	Some have said this.
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture of the belly is corrected with two squares.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is, insert one thread into each of the two squares: and begin with the insertion of the needle from the side which is towards you, and make it penetrate until it reaches the opposite side, according to the suture which is to be made in the skin equally
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when the rupture is in the middle of the belly: then the suture of that is more difficult than that of the rest of the belly
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgment of the healing of a wound is the judgment of the rest of the wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is, when you follow the wound with its own blood, before it changes itself: and reduce the intestines, and touch it, and place over it the powder of burnt barley.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	If the air has already changed the wound: then place over it some unguents which are present, until they make pus: and the threads fall out, and they are solidified with earth, and the matter is healed.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it in the same way as the care of the rest of the wounds, until it is healed.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if there are no medicines at hand, then place over it immediately, from which it begins to emit pus, a little bit wet: and change it twice a day, as I have taught you, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you will not find any other medicine in many conditions, when the wounds are simple.</start_of_turn>
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	If however you are afraid that the wound communicates with the principal parts in the lesion, then you must plunge fine wool yarn into lukewarm oil, or in rose oil: and put it around the circumference of the parts which are between the groin and the flanks.</start_of_turn
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain, or swelling, or corruption in his intestines (for such things often happen to him), then let him drink a cluster of black vinegar, warm: especially if the corruption has already progressed in the intestine, and an opening has been made through to its cavity.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	You know that that which is from the great intestine is easier of healing: and that which is from the small intestine is more difficult of healing.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	But the intestine which is called the jejunum, does not recover from a wound which has happened to it throughout: and this is because of the multitude of its veins, and the magnitude of them, and because of the fineness of its body, and nearness to its own nature of nerves
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If however the wound proceeds from the spleen, and follows this, then reduce it according to your reduction which you make of the intestines equally
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If however it has passed beyond that space, and has become black, or dark: then it is necessary that you tie it up with a thread above the place which has been denigrated by it, so that the blood does not flow.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in the spleen are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut through that which is beyond that ligament, and place two hanging threads from the lower part of the wound outside of it: so as to support above its attraction, and extraction of it from the case of the spleen, and the emission of the pus of the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remember the wound which has happened in the Intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When a disruption happens in the Intestine, and it is small: then it is possible, that it may be healed in some people: because I saw that which was wounded in the middle of his stomach with the lance, and was ancient: and the wound was made into a fistula, and came out of it through egestion, and there was swelling
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	I appoint the treatment until such time as I am not occupied with his/her cure: neither shall I cease to subtilize him/her until he/she is cured and his/her place is consolidated.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	When I have completed my task and consolidated my place, I fear over the patient lest something should happen to him through the action of some evil thing in his body: and nothing should happen to him from that evil thing.</start_of_turn>
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And I remain in better arrangements, eating and drinking, and hoping, and I have bathed, and I have exercised myself in my diet.</start_of_turn>
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some of the experimenters say that when a wound occurs in the intestine and is small: then it is necessary to bind it in this manner.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is like taking large ants.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then join together two lips of the wound, and put an ant on one of those which have an open bone over two lips of the wound.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When you have done this, and have bound up the bone, cut off its head, and it will adhere to it, and will not dissolve.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then put another ant near the first one, and do not cease doing this until you have done as much as the whole wound.</start_of_turn
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce the wound and its pain.</start_of_turn
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	These ants remain annexed to the intestine until the intestine is healed, and is not injured by any sharp thing.</start_of_turn
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And it is possible to bind the intestine also with a fine thread: which has been taken from the intestine of an animal, and is annexed to it when it is introduced into the belly.</start_of_turn
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is thus, that thou shalt receive the extremity of this son from the intestine, and it shall be excarned much.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then bind in the extremity of his limb a thin linen thread which is wrapped around it
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then introduce that limb into the gut, and sew it together with it.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then reduce it to disruption.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this manner of stitching with hooks and gut is not without risk, save according to the measure of trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Thou knowest, a great and bulky wound, especially if it be in one of the fine intestines: then there is no wisdom save a slight cutting, and there is no healing of it altogether
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	About care for wounds and fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 88.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Thou knowest, that every wound, or abscess when it grows old and becomes hardened, and becomes a wound, and does not consolidate, and emits pus always, and does not burst: then it is called generally in every part of the body a fistula, and we call it Zuchemen.</start_of_turn>
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula is indeed according to truth a filtered nodulation, hard, white: with which there is no pain, which has the nature of the wing of a bird: and for that reason they call some of them Risati, that is, wings.</start_of_turn
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And in some hours it is humid, which emits pus.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps it bursts in some hours.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And when it is this humid matter is much, and is little, and is large, and is soft.</start_of_turn
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I say before you, whenever I have mentioned an ulcer, that no ulcer whatsoever that does not heal by natural means, neither is it born in that flesh, is anything other than through one new cause.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	And one of these is because of the scarcity of blood in the body: or because of the wickedness of the blood: or because between itself and over the lips there is tough flesh, hindering the birth of flesh: or because there is much pus and dirt: or because the ulcer itself is putrid, and the material that issues from it is of bad quality: or because the medicine is inappropriate for its treatment: or because corruption is falling in the region, which is a kind of pestilence: or by the nature of the region itself, as it happens in Caesaraugusta, in which there is great difficulty in digesting food and the healing of wounds is delayed by nature: or because there is one bone, or many bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have stated all of these causes and signs and their treatments with the physicians in the discourse: and it is fitting for you to write the treatment of fistula and hernia, which is done by one operation with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	You know therefore that fistula can occur in all the members of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For there are fistulas which extend to great veins and arteries, or nerves, or fat: or to the intestine, or the bladder, or to some of the ribs: or to some of the vertebrae, or to some composition of joints: such as the hand and foot. And there are those which arise from the proximity of the principal limb and the like
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	For such fistulas are according to this manner: they arise from difficult and non-healing ailments, and do not receive treatment, and the care for them is laborious and ignorant
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	If, however, any fistula does not reach these parts which I have mentioned, and if you hope for its recovery and trust in its treatment, and wish to attempt its healing, then attempt it from the air or from the iron, for the fistula tends in this way. Inquire about it with the physician herself.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	If, however, in the Fistula there is tortuositas, then you must investigate it with a slight weight of lead.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	For the lead, on account of its slightness, will alleviate the harshness of its body and will curve around the tortuositas.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	If the Fistula has many orificia, it is not possible to make a significant sign upon it with a slight weight
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore clench from the opening of the orificia towards the other opening of the orificia.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the humidity that you clench with will go forth from the other opening of the orificia and will run out from the body.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then inquire precisely in what way it is possible for you: whether it is an os or a nerve, and whether the Fistula is long or short: or whether it is a single Fistula which has many orificia, and is stretched over all of it, with the sum of your strength: with your inquiry which you make to the patient, and the finding of pain in compression with your hand over the place, and similar signs and symptoms of the accident.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When you have stood in all these positions truly, then you will come to the cure according to your confidence: and it is that you consider then, if the apparent Fistula is close to the juncture, or far from the juncture from a nerve, artery, vein, or any place which I have mentioned to you: then dry the Fistula according to what has been said before in this narration, and take away what is in it from filtration, and corrupted blood, which is born from the tissue in its opening, or the pus, and similar things: and care for it until it is healed
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If, however, the Fistula is of great depth and is according to the rule: then it is necessary to cut away the part in depth as much as is possible
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then loosen her from all corrupted flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer unguents bound up in acute medicines: and introduce them until they reach the depth of the fistula which you have comprehended with the iron: do this until the acute medicine has eaten away everything that remains in the depth of the fistula from corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore her with unguents which generate healthy flesh, until she is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If she does not heal thereby, then burn her according to what we have narrated
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If indeed the cause of the fistula is bone, and you suspect this: then inquire about it, and dry it up as I have told you: if you are not forbidden by anything from the bone, or nerve, or main limb, as we said
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If indeed it is found that the bone is in some degree corrupted and black: then burn it until the corruption is entirely gone
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for her with that which nourishes her, until she is healed.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	For if she does not heal, and pus comes out like she used to: then you know that you have not reached the entire eradication of the corruption.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore take care of this secondarily, and make an investigation of the cause of it, and loosen her with all your strength
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore her.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If indeed she heals, that is good: and if not, then you know that the corruption is in a deep part of the body, which you have not followed.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	It is not enough for you in this matter, except you dismiss her like the nature of things.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	If indeed the small bone is corrupted, and you think it possible for you, draw it out with fine forceps which fit to it
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then you must perform attraction on them all, and do not leave anything out with your skill.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If, however, there is some moisture in them [the bones], and there is no fear of incision, or of error: then you must cut through those moist parts and flesh, if there are any, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If you are not prepared to extract the bones at this hour, then put over them something which will cause putrefaction to it: and leave it until it has putrefied, that is until the soft parts surrounding the bones have rotted away from the bones and the moisture
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And keep the cloth so that it does not harden.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And be cautious as you make the incision in your operation.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	If you wish, put over it, if you will, some sulfur which has been ground with oil: or immerse it in Egyptian unguent, or in some other unguents of your choosing
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when these moist parts putrefy, and are separated from the bones, the swelling will subside, and the attraction of the bones will be restored
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If, however, there is a large bone, such as the shin bone or the thigh bone, which are corrupted: then take away that part entirely, until the blackness and corruption have vanished
Deinde restaura uulnus.	And then restore the cloth.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If, however, that which is corrupted is a large part, and the corruption has extended to the marrow of the bone: then it is necessary to cut through it completely, and to cut away all that is corrupted: then care for it until it has healed
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you, what happened to me in my leg: that you may take it as an example and an assistant for your operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	A youth of about thirty years of age suffered pain in his leg, because something had become loose within his body, that is, from within, until it reached the thigh, and there was discharge of great quantity: there was no external cause.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	It has been prolonged thus long as with the mistake of the physicians, until the abscess opened, and many materials came out together with it.</start_of_turn>
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after that, his recovery took place, until the thigh was ligated, and many holes were made in it: from which all sorts of pus and moisture were emitted, and the body was moistened.</start_of_turn>
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	He was treated by many physicians for two years, and no art of hand was found in this matter until I saw him, and I saw that his thigh was black, and that various matters were flowing from his holes in great quantity: even all the hair of his body was falling out, and his complexion was yellow.</start_of_turn>
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	There was an attempt to reach the cavity of one of his wounds, and the attempt reached the bone.</start_of_turn
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all his holes: and I found that they were all communicating with each other throughout the thigh.</start_of_turn
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I treated him accordingly, and I cauterized over one of those holes, until I reached a part of the bone: and I found that it was corrupted: it was corroded, discoloured, rotten, and perforated, until it had penetrated as far as the marrow.</start_of_turn
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I extracted what was detected from the bone, and prepared it from the corrupted bone.</start_of_turn
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I concluded that there was no other blemish in the bone except that corruption, which I excised and cauterized.</start_of_turn>
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	I have eradicated it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I order restoration of the wound with consolidated spaces for a long time with the physicians.
Et non est consolidatum.	It is not consolidated yet.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I tried, and found upon the second examination: and I observed continuous corruption with the bone: and I saw that there appeared to me also from that corruption
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	I am making an attempt to restore it
Et non est restauratum.	It is not restored yet
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I found therefore again on it, and I did not cease to cut the bone piecemeal, and I attempted to restore it: and it is not restored, until I cut from the bone round about the palm of the hand, and I extracted that with the marrow
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with the physicians, and it was consolidated quickly, and healed: and no further operation was necessary concerning this matter, except for the disposition of the weakness of the patient, and his little tolerance, and my fear of death for him: because it was happening to him at all hours from the excess of vomiting of bad evacuations.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He is now healed completely: and was made in the place of the broken bone, and a good disposition was made of the body: and its strength returned: and it rested in its dispositions: and did not cause him any hindrance in walking or any other movement from that time forward
