Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw out the arrow: for itself becomes easy to extract
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If indeed it remains in the bone, then twist your hand according to the circumference, until you impress the Sagitta in the bone, and increase it: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	If not: depart for a few days: then return again, until he departs.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow of Sagitta is in it, then pull it out with that itself.</start_of_turn>
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If, however, the arrow has broken, and you wish to give an impulse: then introduce into the instrument a concave tool, so that the concavity of the tool may be included in the head of the arrow: then pull out the arrow with that itself.</start_of_turn>
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then pull out the arrow with the instrument entering it.</start_of_turn
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow will be freed by that.</start_of_turn
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisonous, then it is necessary to remove the entire flesh in which the poison is, if possible.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for the wound with that which is suitable for it.</start_of_turn
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is falling in the chest, or in the belly, or in the flank, or on the side: and it is close to that which you touch with your finger, and it is possible for you to dry above the wound: then dry, and burn from the edge of the wound, the vein or the nerve, and extract the arrow.</start_of_turn
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then wash the wound, if necessary, and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	This is the form of forceps by which arrows are extracted.</start_of_turn
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	There are two similar extremities like the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not slip from it.</start_of_turn
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And there are many kinds of forceps, large, small, medium, according to the quantity of the arrow, and the thinness or thickness of the wound, and the constriction of the wound.</start_of_turn
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of an implanted concavity.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	The form of an implanted prominence.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the shape of the extremities like radii, so that its entrance into the concave arch is facilitated, and is propelled by it
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremities of the implant are concave like the pen of a bird: so as to facilitate the entrance of the arrow into the very thing and the driving force of it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Of the phlebotomy of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 147.</start_of_turn>
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins which are to be phlebotomized, which abound in the body, are thirty in number.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these there are six in the head: two pulse veins which are behind the ears, called the Herbae: and two arteries which appear in two temporal regions: and two veins which are in the two tear-ducts of the two eyes, which are called the Aspicientes: and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegi which are in the neck
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called the Algecherich
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins which are phlebotomized in the arms, are five in every arm
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalica, and is from the side of the shoulder: and it is called the vein of the head
Et Fusca.	And sponges.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And sponges.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And sponges.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And sponges.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And sponges
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And sponges
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And sponges
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	And sponges
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And sponges
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And sponges
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And sponges
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	And sponges. After the Golden Age, two veins are bled from.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	And sponges. For these two veins which are bled after the Golden Age, their juice is useful for ancient cataracts, and for migraine, and for haemorrhoids, and for a bad headache of the capitis.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the bleeding of these two veins is according to what is said above.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, that the head of the sick person is to be placed on a cushion: and the skin of his head is to be abraded in the place of the two veins with rough cloth.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the patient shall be bound about the neck with a cord, until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their places are behind the Golden Age in two depressed places of the head
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Inquire therefore where your finger is touching, and where you feel their pulse beneath your finger, there is a sign of the scar.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the lancet of the phlebotomist and that is called Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the nail into the palm, until the phlebotomist reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then raise your hand with the nail and palm towards the upper parts, and cut the nail with the incision that is made in the middle
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be that of two joined fingers, or about that: and let blood flow out as much as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind the blood vessel with ligatures, and let the blood vessel go, until it is healed
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And thus it is necessary at the beginning of the book to speak of the incisions and their cauterization
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	As for the two arteries of the hand in their time
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	There are two arteries in the hand which are to be opened in two times of phlebotomy: the ancient haematoma, the immediate bruise, the persistent haematoma, and the excessive flow of acute blood towards the eyes
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And as for the quality of the bleeding which is to be known to you in this book
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	Let the sickly person grasp his neck greatly, until two nails appear to be sensible in their appearance: and let the pulse of them be shown under your finger
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then signs are made with the cautery.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then raise the skin above the nail with your index finger, and insert the phlebotomy there under the skin, and raise the nail upwards
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut the blood vessel, just as you did in the two preceding fingers: and let blood flow out according to the quantity that you need
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then solve the coarseness of the patient, and place your finger upon the hour mark for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place your finger upon the butt and the calves, and tighten it above the constriction strongly: and release it when it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And thus it is necessary to remember the incision and the extraction of the parts at the beginning of the book.</start_of_turn>
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	After the cephalic phlebotomy, from the vein of the front.</start_of_turn
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The advantage of phlebotomy of the front vein after cephalic phlebotomy is for the ancient ailments of the face: and for migraine, and redness: and bedsores.</start_of_turn>
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is as I have mentioned to you.</start_of_turn
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The patient tightens his neck with his hand, until the vein appears.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument called Fossorium.</start_of_turn
Cuius haec est forma.	What is its shape like?</start_of_turn
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent point at the head of the Fossorium on the vein, and pierce it with the hook or with something else in the same way: and let the blood flow according to the quantity you wish.</start_of_turn
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then solve the perforation of the patient, and tighten it, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it is opened with the wide phlebotomy.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	It is not right that the acute extremity should be phlebotomized, like the rest of the phlebotomies, but rather the wide extremity.</start_of_turn
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the phlebotomy is done according to the passage of the blood: because the bone is close by: and perhaps in this it may break the phlebotomist when it is slight.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	And the phlebotomy of the veins in two tears.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The application of two veins which are in the two tears of the two eyes is to the eye from the scab and redness: and behind the eye, and the pain in the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of them is that it tightens the sick man's neck with might
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the phlebotomy is easy: and you remain standing over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And it is done according to the passage of the blood to a small length, with a small phlebotomist, broad, because there is no flesh in the place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the phlebotomist is slight at the extremity, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let him run from the blood as much as you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put over his head the footstool, and bind up his neck once, and leave him for the night.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of the phlebotomy of the veins of the nose
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose are phlebotomized because of acute fever, and swelling of the gums, and pains in the face, such as a migraine, and redness that happens in the face: especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of them is that it tightens the sick man's neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take his nose with your left hand, and make a small incision under the tip of the nose, long: and hold it in the middle of the nose, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its straightness
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the vulva does not appear to the sense there, and because blood immediately begins to flow.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	It is necessary, therefore, to take hold of the hand lastly with the needle holder and to make blood flow freely according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it once at night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	The wound itself will soon restore itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Of the cutting of the veins Guidegi speaks
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	But Guidegi speaks of phlebotomy in two cases: for constriction of the spirit, for the in-ception of leprosy, for melancholy, for itching and ulcers, and for corrosiveness, that is, for wounds caused by herpetiform eruptions
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of phlebotomy in these cases is that it should tighten the sickly person under both arms in his neck with a ligature: and let the artist stand over the head of the sickly person, and the sickly person should sit upon a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then make the vein bleed to the length of the wide phlebotomy.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out from the blood a quantity as warm, or as much as you need for this purpose
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other vein
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then loosen the ligature, and tighten two veins with medium tension: so as not to injure the sickly person.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And keep him until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The wound will then heal
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Of the cutting of the veins Algeberich speaks
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins, however, Algeberich speaks of phlebotomy in these cases: because it relieves the hiccup in the throat, and corruption of the gums: and bad ulcers: and wounds of the lips, and bad ulcers, also those which are in the nose, and in the circumference of the eye
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And what is the quality of the phlebotomy of these, that you make the sick man sit before thee: and tighten his neck with a cloth.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then draw out the lip of him, and look to his two veins: one of which is at the right side of the lip, and the other at the left side of it: and the sign of both is by the blackening of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And truly it is: because around their circumference are small veins, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Incise therefore each one with an incision that is appropriate to it.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If however doubt exists for you, and you do not know which of them it is: then you must resort to the incision of the greater of them, and their sign.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And thus do the same with the two veins which are in the upper lip: and most frequently it runs in custom with this: and incision the two veins which are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Of phlebotomy of the vein under the tongue after the cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	For indeed the veins which are under the tongue phlebotomize: that is to say, the cephalic phlebotomy is for the affections which are in the gut, and the swelling of the tongue, and the pains of the mouth
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of the mandible is this, that you make the sick man sit between your hands towards the sun: and elevate his tongue, and look under the tongue at the side of him one vein, and at the side of him the other: and the color of both approaches to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Phlebotomy therefore each one: and hold, do not put your last hand in the phlebotomy of him.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under them are arteries, and perhaps there will flow blood from these arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of three veins in the cubit.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	Three veins are found in the cubit that are commonly bled during phlebotomy in all humans.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	Phlebotomy of these veins is performed in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	The puncture is either with a broad lancet: or with an olive oil-soaked swab: or with a knife, which is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is suitable for incision
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	There are both broad and fine species according to the width of the veins and the tension of their form. The manner of phlebotomy with the lancet is broad like blood
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	It is suitable for opening wide veins, full of blood, protruding, apparent, large, and those containing thick blood
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	This phlebotomy is of smaller width and finer extremity
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	It is suitable for bleeding small, delicate veins containing thin, yellow blood
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Of the phlebotomy of the basilica (vein of the forearm).
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The basilica is one of the three veins commonly bled during phlebotomy
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the ailments that are under the gut and the throat, from that which follows the chest, and the hand: and it is suitable for the phlebotomist with the needle, as it causes no great fear, and is above all the artery
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore it is mistaken, and the phlebotomist is too deep in the puncture of the phlebotomy, the artery will be injured, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Wherever necessary, do not use the phlebotome with a sharp point: rather let it be dry as with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the swelling does not appear to recede by itself, then it is necessary to drain it away; or to substitute for it another, or to search for some branch of it. Or to make use of the phlebotome in its place at the elbow of the arm.</start_of_turn>
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	The swelling is itself a manifestation; therefore let it be dry with the phlebotome as with Alnesil, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you must use the phlebotome for its own purpose, then do so before tightening the bandage, so that you may mark the place, until you know the place of the pulse.</start_of_turn
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark over the place with grease, afterwards the arm, and dry the area with the concave section of the phlebotome as with Alnesil, as we have said.</start_of_turn
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	Take care that the puncture does not break through to the artery.</start_of_turn>
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you have finished, when you bind up the ligature, the swelling in the place which you marked with grease, then that swelling is the swelling of the artery: you must therefore bind it up.</start_of_turn
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood dripping from the phlebotome like urine from a boy, and it is thin, red: then you know that it is from the artery.</start_of_turn
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then do so quickly, and put your finger over the wide space, then remove your finger.</start_of_turn
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If blood is therefore shed (for it is shed very often), then tighten the arm and let it go: and take care that the patient be at rest: and be over his fear.</start_of_turn
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Neither does it eat for a few days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	Unless the blood is stopped, and the pain persists: if there is no physician present at that moment, then cut the artery if necessary.</start_of_turn>
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities recoil from it, and the blood is stopped.</start_of_turn>
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the bark of the beech tree, and find it: take half an inch, and bind it over the place of the tight swelling, with ligature and threads until the next day.</start_of_turn>
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is stopped, that is good.</start_of_turn
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then care for it as before, remembering from the place of the scattered fragments the flow of blood: and the cutting of the blood in these matters is not difficult on account of the small size of the wound, and the possibility of the ligature from the arm.</start_of_turn
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Of the phlebotomy of the wrist.</start_of_turn>
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The veins of the wrist for phlebotomy are deemed to be those which draw blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because they are composed of the basilica branch and the cephalic branch, as we have said.</start_of_turn
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is convenient for the phlebotomist that there should be some fear of the phlebotomy, for under it is a nerve.</start_of_turn
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy, and finds the nerve, there happens in that a stupor, and the healing of it is difficult, and perhaps it will not heal at all.</start_of_turn
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve is very sensitive to sensation.</start_of_turn
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If, however, it is concealed in some people and is slight and does not manifest itself: then it is necessary that you perform a vein-cutting [procedure] as you would perform a phlebotomy, with a section according to Alnesil, and with a due degree of force.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If it is between two nerves, then find the vein along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomies of the cephalic vein are useful, because they draw blood from the head and confer it to the eyes
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	It is necessary in this vein alone, if you will, that you perform the phlebotomy with a needle like that of an olive-cutter, or with that of Myrtle: for it is safer for all the veins, because neither an artery nor a nerve is beneath them
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	But indeed it is fitting with the phlebotomy that you take hold of the head only as much as is necessary, and that you seek a softer place: and it does not harm if it is not found on the first percussion, as it will return with subsequent phlebotomies
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Perhaps sometimes it will be delayed in some people when it is not performed on the first percussion, but it does not harm that in anything.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Of the usefulness of phlebotomy, and of the precautions to be observed in its performance.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy, and the accidents which may arise from it, demand that you reflect upon them
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, know that phlebotomy is not to be used except in the preservation of health, and for the treatment of diseases, and for the prevention of ailments.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that it should be performed in the three veins which are in the elbow, namely the cephalic, the basilic, and the cubital.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And thus shall phlebotomy be performed at the beginning of spring upon the feast of Pentecost, in summer and autumn, and in winter after a meal, when signs of repletion appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And thus shall phlebotomy be performed on the first or third day, after three hours have passed
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy, however, which is administered in fevers, has no fixed hour: but when convenience and necessity demand it, in the night or day, and at all hours, at all times.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not proper to perform phlebotomy on children until they are over fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Neither is phlebotomy to be performed on a pregnant woman except from the fourth month until the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Neither is phlebotomy to be performed on the aged who are already past sixty years of age
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When, however, anyone wishes to undergo phlebotomy for whatever reason, it is necessary to administer a cathartic prior to phlebotomy with a gentle enema, if there is much retained stool: that the intestines do not excrete foul matter onto the principal limbs during phlebotomy.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Neither shall phlebotomy be performed on a patient who is suffering from acute nausea, nor on a drunkard, nor on one suffering from a hangover, until these symptoms have passed from the body
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Neither on a patient with dropsy
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be omitted after a fit of colic, vomiting, or flux of the bowels, and after exercise, sexual intercourse, and journeys, and overeating, and fasting, and all that dissolves virtue from the body or from the animal itself
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Consider then the viscosity of the humors before this, if the blood is thick with food and drink, and the physicians: if it is possible for it.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Consider then the bath, if it does not forbid it: or some exercise is performed, to refine the blood.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And perform a phlebotomy of it in the chest, around the third of the day, as we have said: and strive that it be evacuated from the chest on that day from all accidental things harmful: such as distress, and anger, and fear: and from all bodily things, such as labor, and pain, and excess, and like things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let its scent be present with things that customarily accompany men from aromaticness, and fragrance, and delight and like things to that extent which is possible
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then sit the phlebotomist above the ankle, which is higher than the ankle of the phlebotomist: then draw out his arm, and wipe it with the phlebotomist's hand twice, or three times
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tighten the ligament with a bandage, and tie it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the tightening be moderate, for when the tightening is unequal, or by excessive tightening, then it hinders the course of the blood: or in softening, then it hinders the course of the blood as well
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the tightening let him wipe the phlebotomized hand with his other hand until the veins are filled and the sense returns.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then remove the phlebotomist from the phlebotomy with a little oil, as before.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then put his index finger of his left hand on the same vein under the place where the phlebotomy was made, slightly: so that it does not flee, and that there be no percussion
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because from veins is as it is from intestines like a running cord at a phlebotomy: and from flesh is that which is filled with air: and when you place a phlebotomy above this, it contracts under the phlebotomy, and tears the phlebotomist, and does not open the vein: and if it does open, it is strict. Because of this, it is necessary that the phlebotomist should be firm and attentive in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then withdraw the phlebotomy
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If indeed a vein opens from the vein one, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat this vein a little lower or above with force: if the place does not yield
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	Which if it yields, or if the patient becomes faint, then let him go either today or tomorrow: and do not tighten the ligament.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps the clot will be drawn out by the attraction.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither put in a compress.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if necessary.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or blood runs slowly: and take care that it does not escape from the blood more than is necessary: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same place according to the rule, and add a little to the operation
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	Do it with force before the clot is formed: for the clot is in many people in the operation after the operation is finished
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If indeed you see the clot coming out, then do not repeat over it at all, for this excuses you from the matter altogether.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put over it something of the fat of oil: because it will calm the running of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	It is better here than the oil itself and than any other oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	Similarly, administer the face of the oil in every phlebotomy you make, except for those where you wish to impede the flow of blood: and they will make that which is above become dry and brittle.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood is refined and dissolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If, however, this happens in the place of the phlebotomy after the great swelling, namely when it happens too often, especially when it is not a phlebotomy except for a slight opening of a small vein, then cleanse and put upon the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed up: and bind for an hour: because it will dissolve
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the blood has gone out of the vein from the vein itself, with the addition of some of its own, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If anything black or yellow remains in the place after a few days, it does not harm: and if it does, put upon it some aloe or balm of cassia or something of the juice of mint, that is, calamine or something like that.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many times swelling and swellings happen at the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put your hand upon it [the swelling] then, if you find softness under your compression of it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Because of that, put upon it something of what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps the blood will flow from that artery
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster of it with that which has a styptic action, so that the place is bound up
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself with the rest of the treatment, until you are healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	It is also necessary to remove from every man from the blood according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the burning color over the blood
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For the blood is black, then let it go out: when it is red, let it go out: and in the same way if it is thick, let it go out: when it is thin, let it go out: and in the same way if it is sharp, let its sharpness be removed
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and indigent of blood extraction to take one, in order to amplify the phlebotomy and make the phlebotomist wide: and in him who is weak, it is the contrary of him
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to extract it in vessels, and that the hole be narrow: and it is better that it be administered in phlebotomy by a cut, not by a puncture
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood, and from the cutting of nerves: and it is more commendable and safer than phlebotomy by a wide area and depth.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it has happened to faint during phlebotomy, it is necessary that he should be given a spoonful of bread soaked in pomegranate juice before phlebotomy: or barley bread, if he is feverish: and extract from him from the blood in three or four vessels.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if the complexion is pale, then he should take before phlebotomy bread soaked in honey or in scented honey syrup with spices, or in scented fragrant syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If syncope occurs during phlebotomy, and the cause of it is excessive bleeding: then it is necessary to take in the pot water of meat, and fragrant syrup slightly thick: and flavor it with spices, and cool the chest with these things: and do the rest that we mentioned in the chapter on syncope from evacuation
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to empty out his arm and dissolve his blood in the second place must perform upon him a phlebotomy because of the great evacuation, and his nature is weak, so that he may gradually dissolve the blood in proportion to the amount of weakness in the days that follow.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to empty out his arm and dissolve his blood in the second place, and his body is strong: then let him do this after seven hours or nine from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body towards the opposite side of which it hangs down: let him do this on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body is much blood already heated and acute, and causes a rise in fever: let him expel it from this blood in one portion, and extract from it a great quantity: and increase the opening until syncope occurs: after which you must restore the patient to his normal condition, and place his hand over the pulse of his wrist in order that there be no fainting at the place of the syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Many times this happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant, and neglects the matter.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not proper when one wishes to empty out the arm and dissolve the blood in the second place, when the opening of the vein is closed, and there is difficulty in the exit of the blood, as it may happen too soon over that which is desired, and cause swelling to extend quickly
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For indeed that is bad, indeed let him defer it until the second phlebotomy
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or move with the acuteness of the phlebotomy that which has coagulated from the blood in the opening of the vein, and put upon it some salt dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put above it something from tyriaca alfaroch, or sage, and put it under compression lightly, until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed the bone is fractured, then let it go, and do not hold it tightly, until the fracture settles down.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If indeed the need compels to stop the bleeding by means of a second application, and there is no excuse, then either perform phlebotomy above the place, or in the arm or in another limb.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	As for the vein of the arm, phlebotomy is done at the place of the cubitus and the elbow, when they cannot be found, because they are hidden, since they are composed of bones.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that the patient dips his hand into warm water, until the wound turns red, and the limb appears pale.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it is bound up over it with a bandage with moderate constriction medium
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then phlebotomy is done in a descending direction rather than horizontally or along the length: and let the opening be wide, and your phlebotomy be as high as the hand that you are lancing beside
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If it is forbidden for the blood to flow out, then do it again with the hand in warm water, and let the blood run into the water until you have accomplished your need
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If indeed you are in the summer days, then you are excused from the repetition of the hand in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And most of all blood is put to flow in warm water in the cold season.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this limb is safer than all the limbs, because there is no pulsating vein or nerve under it
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy of the right hand is useful for ailments of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	The quality of the phlebotomy is such that you should tie the vein close to the hand with a ligature, or your finger, after you have plunged the needle into the water, until the vein has swollen and the patient has felt a sensation of coldness.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then the phlebotomy should be performed across the vein.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut the vein completely, it will not harm him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And preserve your hand from the phlebotomy.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under these are the nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh from the bone.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then put the hand into the warm water, and let the blood flow out of it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not put your hand into the warm water, the blood will coagulate in the opening of the vein, and will be hindered from its course.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have drawn out from the blood the quantity necessary, then put on the vein oil and salt: so that it does not clot too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And thus it is necessary to do with every strict limb.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The treatment of the phlebotomy of the left hand is: because it is useful for ailments of the spleen: and do the same in the phlebotomy of the right hand as you did in the second equally
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The saphenous phlebotomy is useful for ailments that are in the lower part of the body, such as ailments of the uterus, and retention of menstruation, and weakness of the kidneys, and ulcers of the groin and buttocks, and similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	The quality of the saphenous phlebotomy is such that you must insert the sick limb into the warm water: and make above it friction, until the vein swells: and tie above the junction of the limb with a bandage
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	The heel is the proper place for the nails, which appear towards the thumb: and they are pulled out from it on the face of the foot in many places.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	The veins are to be let out more widely on the greater branch of it, or at the heel in its collection: for this is better and safer
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If the veins are let out on the face of the foot, then take care of the nerves which are under them over the face of the foot
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And put your vein-cutting through from the transversely, like the one you wish to make: and let the vein be wide.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If, however, the blood is prohibited from coming out, then repeat the foot in hot water: and let the blood run in it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the nail-cutter has gone wrong in the first attempt, then repeat the vein-cutting with the upper part of the limb, for the place is safe and not liable to cause any mischief, when you take care of the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the other foot like the saphenous vein of the foot.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The veins of the sciatica nerve are to be found at the heel from the lateral aspect of the ankle bone
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the sign of the vein-cutting of this is for the relief of the pain of the heel, when there is because of the thick blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of the vein-cutting of this is that it should contain an infirm ball, and hasten: and bind up the limb from the side of the heel to above the heel for four fingers, with a fine long bandage: for it does not appear except for this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then the vein-cutting is to be done according to whatever skill you have in your hand, or by means of a transverse section: and it is better either to make an incision or to cut through with a section
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The place of its [disease] is in the blood, and it is hidden in many men.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If it is not found in the blood, and does not appear to the senses at all: then let a bloodletting be made at some point of its [disease], and let it appear at the ankle or on the heel: and let it run from the blood as much as you will.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the tight dressing, and place over the point of the bloodletting the skin, and bind the place firmly.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	And the disease will soon be healed.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	(The text continues with another paragraph.)
Caput XCVIII.	(End of document.)
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Diseases arise from the humours, and from the air, and from bile.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And the temperaments are two in kind.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	One is by scarification, and by extraction of blood: and the other is by temperaments without scarification
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this temperaments which is without scarification is of two kinds
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the temperaments which are administered with scarification and extraction of blood are fourteen in number in the body
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	And there are fourteen temperaments which are administered with scarification and extraction of blood: of which one is the temperaments of Alocri, and is the most remote of the head: and Alkhel, and is the middle of the neck: and the temperaments of Alhagdahim, and are two layers of the neck from two parts together: and the temperaments of menti, and is under the mandible in the lower part of the mouth: and the temperaments of the two palates: and the temperaments of Alachosos over the end of the tail: and the temperaments of the two spleen, and are medium of the two arms: and the temperaments of the two knees: and the temperaments of the two heels.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	The wind does not draw blood from small veins scattered throughout the flesh, and because of this it does not cause the production of pus like that which follows phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Neither is it necessary to apply the wind either with fire or without fire in any ailment which originates from congestion, until the whole body has been evacuated.</start_of_turn>
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If need compels the application of the wind in an ailment, either from the ailment itself or from custom, we administer it at every hour in the beginning, in the end, and in the middle of the month, and whenever it is necessary.</start_of_turn>
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	For in men when their blood multiplies in it, until it needs to be extracted by the wind, it finds its greatest burden in the head.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from pus is that which fills the face, the head, and the neck with repletion and redness.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from pus is that which causes itching on the face, the forehead, and the eyebrows, and darkness and blurriness in the eyes.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from pus is that which makes the area of the wind's action scaly.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from pus is that which multiplies laughter.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from pus is that which gives a taste of blood in the mouth: either the tongue becomes floppy and expels blood.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from pus is that which multiplies sleep.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from pus is that which causes vomiting of blood and redness, and itching and swelling, and things which are similar to these.</start_of_turn>
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see any of these things, and especially if they appear in the middle of the month: we immediately order the application of the wind, after two or three hours have passed.</start_of_turn
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The application of the Ventosation of the Neck is as follows: because it itself contributes to the gravity in the head, and what flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	It should be performed after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this is indeed a Ventosation of the Cephalic vein.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	It is not permitted to perform it on those who are of a cold complexion, or in whom there is a discharge.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it causes great pain.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	It is not permitted to perform it on the elderly, or in whom there is a cold fever in the head
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever does it frequently generates above him an aversion
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And it is necessary to push the hand downwards with the palm towards the lower parts, fearing the generation of aversion
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The Ventosation or Alkehel is a place of phlebotomy of the Vein of the Fusca and of the Vein of the Basilica, and because of this it contributes to asthma, and constriction of the chest, and splitting of the instruments of inspiration, and cough, and distension.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary to perform the Alkehel Ventosation downwards, because if it is placed downwards, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The alhagdahim Ventosation contributes to headaches, and ophthalmia, and migraine, and perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is a place of phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary to command the practitioner of the Ventosation to delay the hand with the scarification: so that it does not cut the artery, and cause the flow of blood to be cut off
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The blowing of air under the chin causes swelling of the saliva in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar ailments which are in the mouth: and it stands in the place of phlebotomy which is in two veins.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The blowing of air from the lungs causes swelling of the saliva, which is reflected back, and heat
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The blowing of air from the lungs causes swelling of the saliva, which is reflected back, and heat.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	It is necessary, therefore, that the practitioner of the blowing of air should not make too deep a scarification: because the place is stripped of flesh, and under that are nerves and blood vessels.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The blowing of air which is over the teeth causes hemorrhoids of the anus, and ulcers below.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	It is necessary, therefore, that the practitioner of the blowing of air should make a great blowing, and that it should be of air: because the place requires strong suction, and perhaps the fine bubbles of the air are broken: and it is made by a great scarification
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The bubbles of air from the lungs diminish in size: because they draw blood from the whole body, and cause ancient pains in the ribs, and the uterus, and the testicles: they provoke menstruation, and cause swelling, and redness: and they stand in the place of phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins, and the marrow bone
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	They really weaken the body very much, and cause fainting spells in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The phlebotomy of the marrow bone is near to the phlebotomy of the two veins of the legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the veins is such that you should place the inflated bladder in the first cavity and perform temperate suction: and do not prolong the position of the bladder, but place it quickly, and move it quickly, so that the humors come to their proper place in accordance with their natural inclination: and do not cease iterating until the place is already red and distended, and the red blood appears. Then indeed shall you scarify, and repeat the suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For he who has little flesh and few hairs from among men, it is necessary that he scarifies himself once, not more: so that he does not ulcerate the place
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And command the surgeon, that he may amplify the scarification, and deepen slightly: and temper the suction with ease, and speed, and movement of his hand
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	And if there is thickness in the blood, then it is necessary that he scarifies himself twice
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first indeed opens a small opening for the release of the blood, and its swelling: and in the second indeed precise excision of the thick blood
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If indeed the blood is black and foul, then make a third incision: in order to achieve the end.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And finally, when we wish to extract the blood gradually, or little by little, sufficeth us one incision.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	And if we wish to extract much blood, we shall make many incisions
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure, that the blood is thick: then it is necessary that he be scarred deeply: and the equal end of the incision is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is that which it is necessary to administer from oils concerning the position of the veins, and what is the cause of the swelling?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	When the skin is large, hard, tough, and its pores are narrow, it is necessary to anoint the area with open, softening, and resolving oils: such as the oil of almond, or oil of marigold, or sweet fennel oil, or oil of pumpkin seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is winter, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or camomile oil, or mastic: and such like these.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If there is excessive fat that is cold: then olive oil, or balsam oil, or almond oil, or nut oil: and such like these.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If there is swelling that is full of pores, tough meat: then it is necessary to prevent the oil from adhering, and to wash the area with rose water, or cold water, or warm water, or cucumber water, or vinegar water: and such like these.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He who has blood of much moisture should bathe the swelling with vinegar, or Myrtle water, and sage: and such like these.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	He whose fat is thick, bathe the swelling with old wine, or chamomile tea, or fennel decoction, or camomile: and such like these.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary to heat the swelling in a bath, or in a bathhouse, and it is better to give medication after coming out of the bath for an hour, or two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And let no one sleep after the treatment
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is necessary before treating the swelling, or performing a bloodletting before the treatment?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after that it is necessary to consider: then if the swelling is choleric, or the bloodletting is excessive, and the colour of the blood is increased and inflamed: then it is necessary to take cold, such as pomegranate seeds: and also garlic with vinegar and lettuce, and rue, and chamomile: and such like these.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	Place the cushions under the head and the body, and the meats of the wounds will grow soft, and the contents of the wounds with barley: and thus are they similar.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	If the swelling is cold, it is necessary to take in a pot of honey syrup, or of aloes, or of rue seeds made: and take a moderate-smelling liquid, which is between urine and blood: and it is prescribed that it should be taken sparingly of food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	Place the cushions under the head and the body, and the meats: and passeroes, that is, feathers of doves: and the cushions of wool shall be made soft.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	It is necessary that the liquid of the drink should be more than the food: and it is necessary that it be taken in a vessel with some people in the hours of twilight, or a medicine of musk, that is, myrrh, or alum before vomiting, or after: so as to comfort the principal parts and to temper the blood.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	It is not necessary to take anything hot in the pot.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	Of swelling without incision.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Swelling, however, which is without incision, are Venous which are placed over the spleen, and kidney, and heel, and over the belly, belly-button, and the place of the kidney: because these members do not suffer incision over themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.
